Fast travel, waiting, and loading screens. Oblivion is the worst of the typical Bethesda experience.

Oblivion is an underbaked 6/10 game with its saving grace being how rich and extensive the lore is. Somehow the game is compelling enough to continue playing until the end, but overall it leaves a lot to be desired. Spongy combat, bad levelling design, and outside of the main cities, the world is bland and dull.

Where the game falls down in a huge way is the quest design is unbelievably heinous. It is standard fare that quests take place over multiple stages, and in a majority of cases, entail heading from one end of the map to the other just to trigger a 30-60 second conversation to be told to do something or go speak to someone else at another location just as far away again. The game makes it too labourous to be enjoyable solely relying on the horse or walking when it can often take 8-15 minutes to travel between the locations you need to get to. So, in the end it’s just far too convenient to fast travel all the time leaving you with an unfulfilling experience.

I’m sure people will get on at me saying, “Ah! But the game is 18 years old!” My response to that is; Morrowind is 4 years older and a better game that wasn’t plagued with the same issue. If you ask me, Morrowind is akin to meeting a girl for the first time and falling in love with each other, and Oblivion is the stage in the relationship where you get married and she begins to let herself go.

I don’t think I could recommend this game to new-comers. Oblivion, shows its age in a bad way and I would find it hard to believe if Bethesda claim they put serious efforts into playtesting. I’ve seen what people have been saying about Starfield since release, and it looks like nothing has really changed for two decades. They’ve extended themselves into a company happy to rest on their laurels because people will lap up anything they release.

Anyway, for me personally, it’s the last time I play an Elder Scrolls game. There’s a reason why people will tell you to mod their games, and if you can be bothered messing around with all that; jump in. Otherwise, don’t bother.

This game is today a mixed bag, but it's definitely a great game. Its main quest is a bit dull, and it abuses in the number of oblivion gates to close, but the world itself is great to explore. It's like, the world was made, and then a main quest was added as an afterthought. So, if you play that game, don't focus too much on the main quest, and explore around instead.
It is obvious today that mods are necessary to really enjoy the game. Especially the NorthernUI and the loot menu, which completely change the interface and makes it way more modern and nicer to play. And of course, the texture overhaul. Once you made the essential mods, you can truly enjoy the game, even in 2024.
Fights are also feeling good. Instead of Morrowind, each of your attacks connect and give damage. 

By the way, I played it on Ubuntu with Proton, and aside from a few crash to desktop, typical of ES games, it worked perfectly well at full speed.

Overall, Oblivion with mods is like a Skyrim in golden-green lands and forests. If Skyrim is themed on winter, then Oblivion is themed on summer.
So, if you like medieval-fantasy open worlds where you can play in first person view your character, this game is for you.

Dont listen to people saying the graphics are bad, its buggy , leveling system bluh bluh bluh.
Played Oblivion for the first time in 2024 and this is my opinion.
GRAPHICS: They are okay, its playable and enjoyable.
LEVELING: You do stuff like running, jumping, hitting, getting hits , spells etc, you sleep and you get leveling points. You go to jail, you lose leveling points. So dont go to jail.
STORY: 10/10 
SIDE QUESTS: 11/10. Have done quite a few of them, and i have found a list on google with all of them ,and i m trying to complete them.
BUGS: Encountered only on in one of the last main quests. Found the solution on google and it was very simple. I have to type a command on the game , and everything was back to normal. Bugs will not ruin your experience.
CONTROLS: Very easy. Played with keyboard and mouse.
MUSIC: Epic. From the battles to roaming the map.
I played it a lot and I keep it playing again and again. 10/10

This game has lots of cool story's in it, there are cool quest lines to follow and I like listening to the characters talk as they explain what's going on. It's got all kinds of unique items to earn by doing the missions in the game and lots of other cool items you'll find just exploring as you go along. You can even create your own spells, enchant your own items, and create your own potions. There is so much to do, and lots of ways to fight your way through the game.

Best Elder Scrolls. You had to be there to experience its true glory. The first time we seen this game it was just, "Holy shit. You gotta see this." I played this game so much that I went through over 5 discs, bought brand new. I wore the 360 right into the ground. Skyrim doesn't even come close and neither does the time-wasting Morrowind next to this masterpiece. This game has a very special feeling to it and it is also more articulate with town design, quest design and reward than any other elder scrolls. Skyrim is janky and the magic system is god awful. I truly cannot stand the systems in Skyrim. With Oblivion, you can be a literal god with god powers without mods... You can walk across water like jesus, you can make your own spells etc. They go out of there way to even place the constellations in the damn sky. They didn't do that with skyrim! With some mods, Oblivion is still the greatest game ever made to date. There is no contest, don't care what you think, I study this business with an undying passion. This is still the greatest game to date. Kids make fun of the AI but weren't there to experience how new it was to even have  a conversation with someone at all. Back then, audio files were massive, the audio files alone cover half of the disc space of this game. This game inspired me to have a career in game development.
I have been playing this game since 2008. It's just the best.

Retro now, I suppose, but still a classic open-world adventure and one of the best in the Elder Scrolls series.

I dont think any game will replace this one.... even the recent ones this same company creates.... Ive never found one to the quality of this game. Sure skyrim does some things graphically better, the kill moves, the marriage stuff, and some of the home locations. But the quest lines for this game felt so much more indepth and unique. And I really loved that the guilds never went out of their way to find you. You always had to go find them. With minimal direction. My first few play through's of oblivion were so exciting as I tried to find all the guilds. Playing through the arena to win my first real money. The accomplishment of buying the first property after saving up. It was such a unique experience. No game has really replicated that. The only thing I wish is that they gave you more options to run the flip side of some of the guilds. Such as the necromancers or the Blackwood company. Though even with out these options, the modding opportunity really gives you a chance to experience these elements and it really opens up that RP side of the game. Overall I cannot say enough good things about oblivion, I find myself coming back to it every now and then to play the hell out of it. Dont let the graphics push you away, its worth the play.

[h1] Review of TESIV: Oblivion [/h1]

The fourth part Oblivion, is my second favorite... I still can't decide which game has a better story, whether Skyrim or Oblivion. You might recognize significant story excerpts from Oblivion in Skyrim.
I also have to praise its soundtrack, which gives the game the right atmosphere.

[h2] Story [/h2]

The game takes place in Cyrodiil in the last days of the Third Era, about 5-6 years after Morrowind. You wake up as a prisoner in the Imperial City, where you meet Emperor Uriel Septim, with the understanding that your cell should be unoccupied.
The Emperor is accompanied by members of the Blades, who accompany him out of the city because he is being targeted for assassination by the Mythic Dawn cult. His sons have long since died. Unfortunately, the group falls into a trap, and the Emperor is killed by the cult's assassin.
Before that, he gives you the Amulet of Kings (an amulet that maintains barriers between the World and Oblivion... assuming it's worn by the Throne's Successor with dragon blood.)
The player receives a task from the Emperor to deliver the Amulet of Kings to Jauffre, Grandmaster of the Blades. Jauffre knows where to find Uriel Septim's illegitimate son.

Jauffre informs the player about the Emperor's son, who is located in Kvatch acting as a priest of the god Akatosh. The player finds Martin, but he agrees to go with Jauffre only if he closes the Oblivion gate that has appeared outside Kvatch, which is currently in ruins.
After the player closes the Oblivion gate, Martin sets out on a journey with them. However, in the meantime, Jauffre has been ambushed by the cult, and the Amulet of Kings has been stolen. Here begins the quest to retrieve the Amulet of Kings, with which Martin Septim can ignite the dragonfires and seal the barriers between Oblivion and Nirn.

[h2] Ratings [/h2]
Oblivion was incredibly enjoyable for me, with its excellent story, gameplay, and soundtrack... Even from a graphical standpoint, the game is beginning to resemble newer generation games, and its gameplay is even better than in previous installments.
Exploring Cyrodiil and delving deeper into The Elder Scrolls lore is truly engaging.

[h3] Graphics: 7/10 [/h3]
[h3] Story: 9/10 [/h3]
[h3] Gameplay: 8/10 [/h3]
[h3] Overall rating: 8.5/10 [/h3]

[h1] Recenze TESIV: Oblivion [/h1]

Čtvrtý díl, Oblivion, je můj druhý nejoblíbenější.. doteď se nemohu rozhodnout, která hra má lepší příběh, zdali Skyrim nebo Oblivion. Značné úryvky příběhu z Oblivionu můžete znát z Skyrimu.
Musím taky vychválit její soundtrack, který hře dodává tu správnou atmosféru. 

[h2] Příběh [/h2]
Hra se odehrává v Cyrodilu v posledních dnech třetího věku tuším, že 5-6 let po Morrowindu. Jako vězeň se vzbudíte ve vězení v Císařském městě, kdy se potkáte s Císařem Urielem Septimem, s tím, že vaše cela má být neobsazená.
Císař má doprovod ze společnosti Čepelí, kteří doprovázejí Císaře z města, protože se ho chystá zavraždit kult Bajného úsvitu. Jeho synové jsou v tu dobu dávno po smrti. Bohužel se skupina dostane do pasti a Císař je zabit vrahem kultu.
Před tím, ještě dá Amulet králů (Amulet, díky němuž jsou bariéry mezi Světem a Oblivionem... tedy za předpokladu, že ho má na sobě Následovník trůnu s dračí krví.)
Hráč dostane úkol od Císaře dostat Amulet králů k Jauffremu Velmistrem Čepelí. S tím, že Jauffrem ví, kde najít Nemanželského syna Uriela Septima.

Jauffremu informuje hráče o Synovi císaře, který se nachází ve Kvatchi jakož to kněz boha Akatoshe. Hráč Martina najde, ale půjde s ním za Jauffrem jen za to, že uzavře Bránu Oblivionu, která se zjevila před Kvatchem, který je v tu dobu v Troskách.
Po tom co hráč zavře bránu Oblivionu, tak se s ním Martin vydá na cestu za Jauffrem. Ale mezitím byl Jauffrem napaden kultem a Amulet králů byl ukraden. Zde začíná cesta získat zpět Amulet králů, s jehož pomocí může Martin Septim zapálit dračí oheň a zacelit bariéry mezi Oblivionem a Nirnem.

[h2] Hodnocení [/h2]
Oblivion mě neskutečně bavil, skrze vynikající příběh, hratelnost a jeho soundtrack... Už i z grafické stránky se hra začíná podobat hrám novější generace a její hratelnost je zase o něco lepší než u předchozích dílů.
Člověka pak baví prozkoumávat Cyrodill a více se ponořovat do Lore The Elder Scrolls série.

[h3] Grafika 7/10 [/h3]
[h3] Příběh 9/10 [/h3]
[h3] Hratelnost 8/10 [/h3]
[h3] Celkové hodnocení: 8,5/10 [/h3]

Love this game and grew up on it and Morrowind but the fact that they are 20 year old games on here for $15 should be a crime. Wait for a sale. I am talking like below $5. If this was gamestop this shit would be like $3. Besides the price point though, this is from an era when Todd wasn't a walking, talking meme. This edition to TES is the best one imo. Probably not saying Morrowind because I played this one first. Skyrim just doesn't have the replayability that Oblivion has and was too stream-lined for the typical COD enjoyer. If you are a DnD nerd that likes fully voice acted long and branching questlines, this is the game for you(just don't pay attention to all the potato heads). If you are a DnD nerd that is like 45 years old now then Morrowind is probably more of your cup of tea. And if you are just a COD enjoyer, nothing against you bud but go buy your tenth version of Skyrim.
The amount of character skills means that you have far more freedom of playstyle than most modern RPGs.

I grew up playing this game. It was the first game I played that I actually cared about. I recall hours and hours of just exploring the world, finding all the nooks and crannies, learning all the game had to offer. I probably put over 200 hours on my PS3 playing this.

Even now today I find myself coming back to it. Sure the faces are silly, sure the dialogue is mostly terrible, sure its buggy. But man do I love this game. Graphically its old sure, but the visuals have a somewhat timeless quality to them. Cresting a hill coming out of Chorrol in the early evening and seeing the White Gold tower in the distance will never lose its charm.

If Skyrim was your first elder scrolls game (as im sure it was for many), don't approach this game thinking its going to be some breathtaking modern gaming experience, because you will be disappointing. Approach this game knowing It was made in a time when most games cost less than 50M to make (exact numbers for the budget in this game prove hard to find lol), and computer programming was being done on PCs that weigh more than you average infant. This game was made with passion, and the limited resources it was made with are utilised to the fullest.

Also, main story line in the game is actually good.

anyway, buy Oblivion you wont regret it.

Timeless classic, even though it's an old game and has funny bugs, it's perfect that way. There is so much soul in the art style and the game really provides a universe to escape into. Yea, the dungeons can get repetitive, but revisiting this game many years later -- my appreciation for the game only goes up. Atmosphere and music in the game are wonderful. It's difficult to say exactly what it is about this game, as any feature in particular does not stand out; it's more the overall synthesis of many otherwise mundane things which combine into something greater than its individual parts. Similar to Super Mario 64 being forever relevant, this game has a similar charm to it. You have my ear, citizen ~

I previously played Morrowind and Oblivion on Series X, and was looking forward to be able to play them on the go on my Steam Deck. Unfortunately I had to give up on the idea since the controls of the Steam versions were made for the PC version first and not for regular controllers, and in turn, not for the Steam Deck.

Being perfectly honest, I don't know how easy or difficult it is to enable an option to use the same control settings as the Xbox versions, though seeing how later games like Fallout 3 & Skyrim do have proper controller settings and I'm able to play those perfectly fine on my Steam Deck, I'm hoping these can also be added to Morrowind and Oblivion, in which case I will gladly change my reviews.

6.5/10. If you love Bethesda games and love RPGs, you'll likely like this game. The setting is nice, and has some pretty unique and fun side quests. Both of the DLCs are solid, and add interesting stories and characters (especially Shivering Isles). The game does greatly falter when it comes to the main story, cookie cutter dungeon designs, terrible AI and lackluster voice acting, and most of all, the horrendous leveling system that almost requires you to either efficiently level or use mods to fix the leveling.

Knights of the Nine: 6/10. Very short, and if you're not running a heavy armor or one-handed build, the rewards are essentially useless.

Shivering Isles: 7.5/10. Very good DLC that adds a good amount of quests, a great story, and the best character in the game. It has pretty good enemy variety for a DLC, with the only negative being that it's an Oblivion DLC.

Where to start? For money I paid for it is a good game. I played it as a kid, didn't like it, tried few more times, same problem. This time it clicked, so I started playing, and it is just not a good game. Skyrim did what this game should have done, because  despite all of its problem Skyrim is a fun game to play, this isn't. So what's the main problem? Leveling, that is, leveling of the enemy. As you advance, your enemies advance with you, but the problem is, they don't become more stronger, they don't pose more of a challenge, it is just that now they have more health. So what happens is that you will have hit normal enemies 1023929038 times for them to die, and with this combat system, it is tedious. They said level until level 30, than stop, but the problem starts way earlier in the game. It makes no sense to level up, and that should be one of the main focuses of an RPG game. So combat system is, either I will jump around them and pray to god that they don't stagger me, because then animation will start, I won't be able to move, and that will happen 5 times during a normal combat, against one opponent. So what you can do is hit him twice, defend yourself, hit him twice, defend yourself, and now imagine doing this shit with almost every opponent, and there hp is high, it takes ages. I will try to finish the game, but at this point I'm killing only enemies that I absolutely must kill. Because I won't find an item that will change the game if I kill them, nothing I do with weapons matters, because I'm blade master, my strength is 100, endurance is 100, other stats are not 100, but are high enough of a level, goblin with a small sword, knife, ax or something similar attacks me, I need to spend like 3 minutes killing this dude, because I will hit his block with a great sword, he will stagger me, and it's incredibly annoying. Which brings us to weapons that could maybe make your game easier, if it wasn't for a goddamn charging system. Let's say that your sword is charged at 100 and that from every hits it takes 1 energy point from your sword, so when it hits 0, you have to recharge it (doesn't work this way, you will have like 1200 energy, or 3000, or something similar, I'm just using it for simplicity, and it uses more energy per hit, so you lose charge much faster). If I would let's say need 5 hits to kill a normal enemy, and I would lose 5 energy, it wouldn't be a problem, but you will have to hit 1 enemy 100 times, so you will start a battle with fully charged weapon against couple of enemies, and during this battle you will have to recharge weapons 5 times, and then you will have to recharge the stones, find new ones, or develop a different build where you can charge weapons with your power, but it is still tedious work, even if you get that power it won't change for better, because you will still have to recharge it every time. There are other problems, bugs and similar things that come with Bethesda, I could have overlooked that if it wasn't for this leveling up and battle system problems. If you are an masochist, I would recommend this game, if not, and especially if you didn't play it as a kid, I can't recommend it.

-11. Not much cut Content.
-12. Expensive ass house deeds and Stuff you can pay for 2000 Coins each.
-13. Kvatch is attacked For no reason, giving us less of an city to actually live at.
-14. Playing as an Vampire Sucks.







Conclusion: 
This Game is Amazing, and i Hope this Classic Game will never Die.

My name is Walter Hartwell White. I live at 308 Negra Arroyo Lane, Albuquerque, New Mexico, 87104. This is my confession. If you're watching this tape, I'm probably dead, murdered by my brother-in-law Hank Schrader. Hank has been building a meth empire for over a year now and using me as his chemist. Shortly after my 50th birthday, Hank came to me with a rather, shocking proposition. He asked that I use my chemistry knowledge to cook methamphetamine, which he would then sell using his connections in the drug world. Connections that he made through his career with the DEA. I was... astounded, I... I always thought that Hank was a very moral man and I was... thrown, confused, but I was also particularly vulnerable at the time, something he knew and took advantage of. I was reeling from a cancer diagnosis that was poised to bankrupt my family. Hank took me on a ride along, and showed me just how much money even a small meth operation could make. And I was weak. I didn't want my family to go into financial ruin so I agreed. Every day, I think back at that moment with regret. I quickly realized that I was in way over my head, and Hank had a partner, a man named Gustavo Fring, a businessman. Hank essentially sold me into servitude to this man, and when I tried to quit, Fring threatened my family. I didn't know where to turn.
Eventually, Hank and Fring had a falling out. From what I can gather, Hank was always pushing for a greater share of the business, to which Fring flatly refused to give him, and things escalated. Fring was able to arrange, uh I guess I guess you call it a "hit" on my brother-in-law, and failed, but Hank was seriously injured, and I wound up paying his medical bills which amounted to a little over $177,000. Upon recovery, Hank was bent on revenge, working with a man named Hector Salamanca, he plotted to kill Fring, and did so. In fact, the bomb that he used was built by me, and he gave me no option in it. I have often contemplated suicide, but I'm a coward. I wanted to go to the police, but I was frightened. Hank had risen in the ranks to become the head of the Albuquerque DEA, and about that time, to keep me in line, he took my children from me. For 3 months he kept them. My wife, who up until that point, had no idea of my criminal activities, was horrified to learn what I had done, why Hank had taken our children. We were scared. I was in Hell, I hated myself for what I had brought upon my family. Recently, I tried once again to quit, to end this nightmare, and in response, he gave me this. I can't take this anymore. I live in fear every day that Hank will kill me, or worse, hurt my family. I... All I could think to do was to make this video in hope that the world will finally see this man, for what he really is.

The character models and movements look a bit dated and you will hear a lot of the same voices for different characters, but if you can look past that what you get is a great open world game. It has high replay value with tons of lore and depth. Many people, including myself, believe this game to be peak Elder Scrolls because it is as accessible to new players as Skyrim while preserving many of the skills, choices, and features of previous games - such as athletics, spellcrafting and stats to build up other than stamina and magicka. The symphonic soundtrack is one of my favorites,
Finally beat this gem of a game, its goofy and quirky nature makes Oblivion feel rather unique compared to other TES. Shivering Isles is my love.

I recently started playing Oblivion and have been thoroughly enjoying it. I have already completed the main quest line, or at least it seems that way, and have been exploring the side content ever since. Thanks to the use of mods, the game has been elevated to a Skyrim level of quality and I have not experienced any motion sickness while playing.

As with many Bethesda games, Oblivion is known for its bugs and glitches. However, with the installation of 485 mods, the game has been running smoothly with only occasional crashes occurring every 3-6 hours. The only other issue I encountered was with HDR on my monitor, which made dark areas like caves difficult to navigate. Despite my attempts to turn off HDR, the game refused to listen and forced it on. I eventually had to use the console command TLB to make the game playable in these areas.

Overall, the game has been very enjoyable and is still very playable in 2024. While the story was shorter than I expected, it was very entertaining.

Of course, it has some bright moments, but in 2016 it's obviously clear that Morrowind is far more attractive as an RPG and Skyrim is far more evolved as an action-oriented RPG. TES IV seems more like abortive brat. So if your're new to the series, try to familiarize yourself with Bethesda's third and fifth sons. 
As to "outdated" side -- I don't care about graphics, but solid gameplay and story can't really grow old. The obsolescence, however, a very characteristic feature of overhyped games.

A Classic

Oblivion GOTY enhances an already outstanding 9 out of 10 game, smoothing out glitches and extending the immersive experience. Just a glance at the game's visuals compared to other early Xbox 360 titles reveals its stunning quality. Its expansive, intricate world is everything you'd expect from an Elder Scrolls game—beautiful, vast, and captivating. Before Skyrim's arrival, Oblivion reigned as the pinnacle of gaming excellence for many, myself included. Even today, it retains its charm and allure.

With the inclusion of two expansion packs, Shivering Isles and Knights of the Nine, the Game of the Year Edition offers over 30 additional hours of gameplay, ensuring long-lasting enjoyment. Personally, I've sunk 180 hours into my character, completing every mission and meticulously exploring every location. Its replay value remains high, prompting me to purchase the original release and later the Game of the Year edition just to delve into the new expansions.

Oblivion GOTY is undeniably addictive, ranking among the finest RPGs I've ever experienced. Until the release of Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim in November 2011, it stands as a beacon of adventure, inviting players to immerse themselves in its richly crafted world of hacking, slashing, and spellcasting. A must-play for RPG enthusiasts, it promises an unforgettable journey through its enchanting realms.

I feel that the main strength of this game is the gameplay. While it can take a very long time to do, grinding up to maximum power and having the ability to just stomp your opposition or sneak around literally in front of people because your sneak skill is maxed is a ton of fun and really scratches that itch to feel overpowered that many games have gone away from.

One thing that can get a little frustrating is the time it can take to get to a new area, but if that's more of an issue if you are looking for instant gratification. [h1]Unveiling the Gates of Cyrodiil: A Journey into Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion[/h1]

[h2]Story[/h2]
Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion opens its gates to a world rich in lore, where the fate of Cyrodiil lies in your hands. With a narrative as expansive as the landscape itself, the game thrusts you into a gripping tale of prophecies, daedric influences, and political intrigue. The story weaves a tapestry of choices, moral dilemmas, and unexpected twists that will leave you questioning alliances and your own moral compass.

From the haunting words of Emperor Uriel Septim VII, "Close shut the jaws of Oblivion," to the enigmatic words of Sheogorath, the Daedric Prince of Madness, the dialogue is a treasure trove of memorable lines. Each character you encounter feels like a piece of a larger puzzle, and your decisions resonate throughout the world, shaping the destiny of Tamriel. The humor is sly and well-placed, providing a welcome respite from the weighty decisions you're forced to make.

[h2]Gameplay[/h2]
Venturing into the heart of Oblivion is a joyous romp through a vibrant and dynamic world. The gameplay is the meat of this epic, offering a sandbox of possibilities. Whether you're casting spells, swinging a sword, or sneaking through the shadows, the controls are intuitive, allowing you to lose yourself in the immersive experience.

The attention to detail is staggering, from the bustling cities to the serene landscapes. Quests are diverse and enthralling, each contributing to the rich tapestry of your character's journey. The radiant AI system ensures that NPCs have lives of their own, creating a living, breathing world that reacts to your choices. The freedom to approach challenges in your own way adds layers of replayability.

In the true spirit of open-world RPGs, Oblivion excels in providing a canvas for emergent storytelling. The unpredictable encounters with wildlife, bandits, or wandering adventurers add spice to your travels. It's a dance of swords and spells, with each confrontation feeling unique and satisfying.

[h2]Graphics[/h2]
While not without flaws, Oblivion's graphics were groundbreaking in their time. The stylized visuals capture the essence of a fantasy realm, and the attention to detail in character models and environments is commendable. Sure, some textures may show their age, but the overall aesthetic charm prevails. The sweeping landscapes of Cyrodiil still manage to evoke a sense of wonder.

Considering its release date, the game's graphics hold up well, especially when you consider the vibrant modding community that has breathed new life into Oblivion's visuals. Mods can transform the game into a breathtaking spectacle, proving that even in the realm of graphics, the modding community is a force to be reckoned with.

[h2]Sound[/h2]
From the haunting melodies of Jeremy Soule's score to the nuanced voice acting, Oblivion's sound design is a symphony that enhances the overall experience. The ambient sounds of the wilderness, the echoes of footsteps in the Imperial City, and the resonant echoes of spells all contribute to a world that feels alive.

Voice acting, a potential pitfall in many games, shines here. The characters' voices convey emotion and personality, making your interactions with them all the more engaging. The soundtrack, with its iconic theme, stays with you long after you've left Cyrodiil. It's a testament to the power of audio in creating an immersive gaming experience.

[h2]Overall[/h2]
Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion is a masterpiece that has aged like fine wine. Its narrative depth, expansive gameplay, and enchanting world make it a classic in the RPG genre. While the graphics may show their age, the vibrant modding community ensures that the game can still compete with more modern titles.

Should you embark on this journey into Cyrodiil? Without a doubt. Whether you're a seasoned adventurer or a newcomer to the realm of open-world RPGs, Oblivion offers an unforgettable experience. Lose yourself in the grandeur of Tamriel, let the echoes of Uriel Septim VII guide you, and revel in the madness of Sheogorath. Oblivion awaits, and it's a journey worth taking.

Easily one of my favourite games of all time! This was my first ever RPG as a teen as I remember my friends bringing this game to school to show it off. With the leaks about an Oblivion Remake/Remaster plus the Skyblivion mod coming out, I thought it would be a great time to review the original game! Many of Oblivion's aspects can be viewed as outdated to its dungeon design, potato looking character models and its levelling system. Do I care? Not really no. Oblivion is honestly magic and there's no game that has made me want it to explore its world more then this one! But I will dive into these aspects and critique them.

Firstly we have the dungeon design that felt interesting to revisit after Starfield pretty much copy and pasted all of its dungeons imo. This was back when Bethesda was still really small and they only had one developer to make all of the dungeons. Exploring them, I could definitely feel the repetitive nature but again it felt more varied then a certain other game I have already mentioned. That said, the dungeons are definitely one of the weaker aspects. The world exploration is fantastic though as the draw distances look beautiful despite the texture pop in. When you first step out of the dungeon and see the small dock along with the Ayelid ruins in the background. That will always be iconic to me! One quest that also relates to that is "The Collector" quest-line which sees you diving into the ruins to find statues for a rich benefactor. I honestly thought that was great and it gives you a reason to dive into them so you can get rich quick!

The levelling system is another thing to critique as it can be broken at times in how you build you're character. I also go for skills like Athletics, no matter what kind of character I'm making since its easy to level up since all you have to do is run around which you will be doing a lot of. Enemies also level with you which can be annoying, when you see a bandit in full ebony armour attack you on the road for 100 gold. That man should be retired at this point! If they do remake oblivion and not just remaster it, like the leak suggests, I feel like this is an aspect they will have to fix!

The music is absolutely amazing and its something I listen to almost every day since it always makes me feel relaxed and calm. The battle music can get a little repetitive, especially when you sink as many hours as I have into this game. The sound design overall is decent but you can definitely see the small team size and not big budget like they would have now. The voice acting also is great, even if they have a small cast voicing all of the NPCs. Me and my sister would always laugh when we would speak to a beggar as they asked us for a coin with an old, tired voice. But then when you asked them rumors their voice would suddenly change and be normal lol

That's a good segue into the dialogue system, which Bethesda took inspiration from for Starfield. It has the infamous zoom into an NPC while the world in the background freezes as you talk to them. I have never really minded that style of interaction and in many ways I prefer that to the more dynamic interaction of Skyrim and Fallout 4, mainly in that you don't get attacked or interrupted mid conversation like the after mentioned games do. The persuasion mechanic would be laughed at today as you basically just recycle a bunch of options like compliment, intimidate etc until the the relationship meter with that NPC is as full as it can get. Me, I have a lot of nostalgia for this mechanic as it again always seemed funny to me how the NPCs reacted to whatever I said to them. In any other game, I would hate this but in Oblivion, I am blissfully happy with it!

Second to last, I wanted to talk about gameplay. The combat is very much just as bad as Skyrim was as Bethesda has just never been good with FPS melee combat. I don't mind it again, but replaying this game made me see how its very bland in how you basically block and then swing to hit, rinse and repeat. I also hate how some enemies can just keep swinging at you even though your hitting them, like theirs no stagger or visual feedback from your hits. This is especially bad in the goblins and also some of the enemies from the Shivering Isles expansion which I will rant about, when I review that. Its also just annoying because you have a stamina bar that runs out, but the enemies just seem to have unlimited stamina. The spells are a cool addition though and I love the enchantments that you can put on your weapons in this game. I just wish their was a way to enchant weapons other then doing the Oblivion gates which get repetitive very quickly. If I were to give a pass on the dungeon design, I will not on the Oblivion Gates, as they are always just confusing to explore and feel very thrown together last minute.

Lastly, the story. The main story is decent in its execution as I like the tale of the Blades trying to protect the emperor against a cult that worship the daedra. It is however still the most forgettable part and it is epic to hear the voices of both Patrick Stewart and Sean Bean as the Emperor and prince respectively. Where the writing does shine though, is in the faction and side quests that are really well done in this game. It definitely made the tedium of dealing with all of the previously mentioned mechanics much more durable. I feel like developers have just put less effort these days into side quests in games and replaying this made me see how much they can add to an open world game. The Fighters Guild and Dark Brotherhood will always be my favourites!

Overall, this review may have read as very jumbled but its just because its hard for me to express how much I love this game! It introduced me to the RPG genre, and it always provided an amazing level of escapism, whenever things IRL became hard for me. I owe a lot to Oblivion and I will happily replay this and any remake, mod or remaster that we get in the future!

Oblivion is an experience that cannot be described. If you appreciate the nostalgia of early RPGs, Oblivion is for you. If I could, I would wipe my memory to experience it again for the first time. 10/10.

Beautiful open world game where you explore, go on quests, build your character and fight monsters. It's nonlinear in that you may forget about the main quest and wander off to do anything else like raiding ancient tombs, joining a guild, fight in the arena, be an assassin or explore cities. The atmosphere is immersive and the NPC conversations are memeworthy.

There is a leveling system where the enemies and discovered items all gain a level when you gain a level, which is good and bad. This has the same problem with Skyrim where you feel like you have less options for your character the longer you play, since leveling up just specializes you more. So you may want to play on a lower difficulty just to avoid having to make a boring, optimized character that is only good at one thing.

Overall, it's a top notch game that is more than worth the money.

This game is my personal favorite from the elder scrolls series. It brings together a very cohesive world with side quests that feel like main stories, but there are just so many of them to choose from. Any interaction with any character, whether it be the emperor or a simple peasant can lead to a truly inspiring story, some coming out of nowhere, and some you have to seek out. Finding the prophet in Anvil is one of the most captivating story arcs in the game, and it is found by complete chance when visiting Anvil for the first time. It is a truly fascinating story, and yet it is a simple side quest. There are also the different guilds you can join. The fighters guild for example sends you on quests to help others using you sword, making you a sort of vigilante. Some side quests are so small they only take a few minutes, and even those are packed full of story that keeps you captivated within the world. All in all, I would recommend this game to anyone who enjoys playing video games. 10/10

To this day, TES IV: Oblivion is one of my favorite games of all time. From my childhood, it used to scare the crap out of me solely because of the Oblivion Gates. I would not go through them as a kid and therefore couldn't really finish the game. When I got older, about my teenage years, is when I was finally able to finish the game because I was brave enough to go into the gates. 

This game is vastly better than Skyrim and I will die on that hill, all the way from graphics to gameplay to story (music is pretty equivalent). Skyrim really isn't that great as a base game; the community has made it special and amazing via mods. Oblivion is just amazing on it's own. 

I absolutely love the graphics of the game; the bright and colorful painter style of the game is pleasing to some degree. It may not be everyone's cup of tea, but I absolutely love them especially compared to vanilla Skyrim's tryhard realistic graphics. The creature designs are just absolutely wonderful as well. 

The gameplay to me is FAR more interesting than Skyrim's simply because spell-crafting was one of the best things that I was able to do. I loved making my own spells in a diegtic and fun way. Joining the Mage's Guild gives you access to creating spells to begin with and sets up an incredible roleplay choice of studying magic enough to the point that you can create your own spells. And WITH those spells you can even enchant your stuff which is super cool! Being able to cast magic WHILE holding a sword allowed for a real nice battlemage playstyle which I love. Skyrim took away those aspects and kinda made me not like their gameplay that much. 

The story is just much better. I am a sucker for stories where you are not the hero, you're just some guy. Throughout the entire game, you are not the chosen one, there is not some mystical being that has just given you these ultimate powers and stuff. You fight through a prison, become a free person with one mission: bring the Amulet of Kings to Jauffre and find the last heir of the Empire. It's true you can become super powerful and you're the one shutting the Oblivion Gates, but you weren't graced with some power by the gods. That just comes from your capability. Questing in this game is a lot more fun too and honestly, I think there are more funny moments in Oblivion than there are in Skyrim. 

I really think people should play Oblivion and experience probably one of the best TES games. It's super fun and just a great game to go through.

This is one of the hardest reviews I've ever had to write, not because I'm ashamed of what I have to say, or because my personal feelings of the game are conflicted, but just because there's so fucking much to talk about. I was on my fourth draft when I realized that the reason my rant wasn't getting short enough for Steam's dainty review criteria was due to me simply listing what changes the series had undergone from Morrowind. That alone pushed me into the 10k character count.

	So, I suppose that the only way to even try to approach this is on the game's own terms, limiting both comparisons to what came before, as well as gauges against its sequels and spiritual successors in hindsight. I have to understand what the devs were going for, decide whether they accomplished it, and most importantly, decide whether the result is worthwhile.
	How do I begin, though? Everyone already knows this series.

	TES IV: Oblivion was released right on the cusp of the "HD era," before developers had truly figured out the realism that many titles strove for later in the life of the Xbox 360 and PS3; At this point, everything from that time looks dated, that wasn't at least drenched in some peculiar style to make up for its inevitable shortcomings, but the earliest to the party still manage to look the most... off.

	Oblivion is no exception to this rule, especially considering its scale. It's beautiful from a distance, but jagged and rough up close. Cyrodiil's beautiful hills and mountains are covered in forests and other foliage that seem to grow with your approach. Pristine castles and elaborate houses of clean wood and sharp stone sit abruptly on patches of waxy wilderness, with no effort to blend their points of contact, or make it look like anything other than a Lego set placed on astroturf. Even the dirt looks clean. Medieval fantasy towns of somewhat believable size are populated by a wide array of Dr. Seuss characters: potato-faced elves, beardless Nords, and Khajiit resembling fursuits made on a two-digit budget.

	Speaking of looks, the look of your character's equipment, a reflection of your level, will feel limited in the late game. High-tier heavy armor loses out to high-tier light armor when your light armor skill is maxed out, and there just aren't many of either.
	Most variety in fashion is found not in the armors, but in the clothing that takes up the same slots, which is still lacking. Single-item outfits will supplant several equippable items to make you a visually boring amorphous blob, while some items display differently depending on the sex of your character. (I, for one, liked my man-skirt in Morrowind.) Fewer equippable items means fewer options for constant effect enchantments, and just overall less depth... but then, that is the overarching theme of this game.

	Particularly with the actual RPG mechanics, that missed depth is on display. The 21 skills on offer are distributed equally among your attributes, and weighed equally when it comes time to determine what bonuses you get when you level up, which is frustrating seeing as how all skills are obviously not equally useful. You're *encouraged* to max out Endurance as soon as possible, as the exponential health gain benefit between levels is that much more exponentially punishing to delay; The other attributes, there isn't much long-term penalty for ignoring, and I ask, "Why deny myself the extra health if I'm going to max out whatever my favored attributes are and have to branch out into Endurance anyway?"

	The world and its challenges are very much scaled to the player, right down to many of the enemies and quest rewards. On one hand, this often allows you to plow right into the content most suited for your character (or just whatever you want to do first) without regard for whether you'll be underpowered for the upcoming challenge. On the other hand, it means that items obtained earlier on, that would've been permanently useful if acquired later, are instead doomed to become obsolete. So, in essence, the game encourages a more counterintuitive behavior; Avoid doing the quests for the items you know you want until you're sure you'll get the best versions of those items.

	Strangely, the quests mostly feel built to accommodate that sense of postponement. Their associated persons exist basically in their own isolated bubbles for their one quest, apart from maybe being regular merchants or guards, but nothing more. Again, calling back to Morrowind, many characters existed in what was more of a web of quests. They could become your best friends, keep you at arm's length, or die by your hand. It was still empowering to the player, but gave choice and result.
	Here, though, you're only supposed to scratch the surface, and nothing more. The scale of the game was kept similar, but there's just less to it.

	The factions share the same sense of isolation, and apart from the Thieves Guild, they don't really step on one another's toes or interact with each other. You can join every faction in one playthrough, and be the head of each simultaneously. They exist primarily as vehicles for their own questlines, atop one or two little perks each, rather than as extensions of your character's class and identity. These are very much "do or delay" scenarios, at your convenience, often in the manner of your choosing. Most of them play out in only one fashion, unless you do something stupid and get kicked out, which usually requires you to intentionally go out of your way. It's not that you can do anything; It's that you're supposed to do EVERYTHING, often without consequence, and there's a serious lack of immersion as a result, NPCs daily routines notwithstanding. There's rarely any sense of risk or urgency in the vast majority of this experience.

	You have to realize, though, that most of these design decisions were clearly intentional. This was either never meant to be immersive, or, if it was, then the overly generous world that seems built to revolve around the player undermines it at every turn. It's a series of short bursts of fun, at the cost of a believable world and any long-term satisfaction that comes from building up the type of character you wanted to play, a class-based RPG that seems to resent its class system at every turn.

	TES IV: Oblivion is an entertaining title, one that every ARPG fan should play once, and even that one playthrough is worth the price. Beyond that, though, it's also the most poignant shift in its series into a bland, utterly player-subservient direction. Its influence is more due to its quirkiness left over from its predecessors than the depth of its gameplay. Subsequent playthroughs feel less like I'm spending time in a fantasy world, and more like I'm dissecting a fantasy stage production where I'm the main character. Part of me knows that no matter what sort of character I create, it's usually going to end up in the exact same place, not because I want it, but because that's how the game was designed. Yet, even their journeys are only as different as a five-lane highway. Even in one lane, you can basically see what the others see.
Its a classic, the gaming equivalent of slipping into a pair of old shoes.

I skipped Oblivion because I heard bad stuff about it.  But...  that was a mistake.  This is another great game from Bethesda!

Compared to Skyrim, the NPC dialogue and quests are much better (and even in 2024 I think the graphics are fine). After 202 hours I'm just starting the main quest.  I do get distracted by alchemy though so most of my time is spent excitedly jumping form flower cluster to flower cluster... and like all Bethesda games prior to Skyrim the levelling is totally broken, so I'm using an "all stats +5" mod...  and a x2 carry weight mod...  and a reduced weapon weight mod (because how can a dagger possibly weigh 10 pounds).

But!  It's loads of fun.  If you skipped it and only played Morrowind and Skyrim (like me) I recommend you try Oblivion too.  The NPC dialogue and quests are absolutely better than Skyrim.  I mean, I read that, and thought, "That's so subjective, and Skyrim was fine anyway" but no, it's true.

I played Oblivion because of the environment. I am a sucker for ambience and nature, and when I found myself immersed in such greenery which is also open world, I found it really relaxing. I never really did any quests or so, I just kept getting lost in the roaming aspect of the game.

RECOMMEND -With some caveats

PROS:
-A beautifully crafted world
-Cities actually feel like cities with dozens of people living in them, each one with their own schedules, families, friends, jobs, talk to each other (way better than in Skyrim)
-A very good main storyline
-Likeable NPCs
-Some good side quests
-Some armors and weapons looks are just *kiss* perfect
-Lockpicking is a not awesome but solid system

CONS:
-It wouldn't be a Bethesda game if it didn't had the lamest, stalest, dullest, boring and broken combat system you can imagine.
-The looks... Why did they do that..? Horrible. Characters, the vast majority of armors, clothing and weapons are just ugly. Ugly, ugly, ugly, ugly...
-Sadly, again the writing is not thyere yet. Many quests make no sense in-universe, like how a Daedric Prince would grant an extremely powerful artifact created with their own essence to an unknown non worshiper for a random task that isn't even  dificcult? Answer: poor writing.

CONCLUSSION:
If you can stomack the ugliest character creator, the lamest most boring combat system, poor writing and ugly ugly ugly armors and weapons, this game is a gem.
in many ways it is a horrible mess of a game but despite that it offers a fascinating, living world full of personality where modern bethesda games from skyrim onwards are largely devoid of it.

One of the most unintentionally funny games ever made; has aged visually like milk, and I love it.

Oblivion was a game that exploded child me's brain as a kid, and I've put an unspeakable amount of time into it (mostly back on 360)

Going back to it as an actual human being though makes you realized just how incredibly messed up this game is in many aspects. I WOULD NOT PLAY THIS GAME UNMODDED. The combat is a pool noodle fighting simulator with some basic rps sometimes, the world scales like a shonen manga that's way past its prime and sucks at power scaling, and the worst yet, the leveling system that promotes playing like you have paranoid schizophrenia or just accepting you can never sleep again or risk waking up in a world where everything is the same but the local cancer ridden mutts down the street can now mating press your mom and steal your lunch money in front of you and you can't do a thing to stop them. 

What I'm saying is, not even counting bugs, the game's basic systems are broken in game ruining ways. 
However, it you're not a coward and just mod the game, stuff can get wacky and extremely fun. Curing Oblivion of its many plagues unlocks a silly little dungeon crawler that has a lot of charm and great character expression. The main story and factions are generally quite good, and when dungeons aren't just walk in straight line and turn around, feel quite good.

For the DLC, Shivering Isles is basically Oblivion Pokemon Platinum where you get to go the the based realm to crazyland where the Little Caesars only sell 'Normal' Bread. It's fantastic, 
Knights of the Nine is just a really cool faction quest added in, also very very good.
Everything else can familiarize themselves with the wrinkles of my nether region. 

I remember only having SI and KotN on X Box 306, so I never had any of these honkey DLCs like horse armor or the DLC houses that make it where you can instantly become a gorillionaire demigod. 
I hate in mods where you spawn in and instantly you're the heir of Versailles and Epstein Island, but I never realized the origin of this annoying trope would be Bethesda themselves. 

Tl:dr:tl:dr Oblivion is the weird middle child between Morrowind and Skyrim, but I think it's quite fun and interesting as long as you mod it to not be CBT.

Esse jogo é o primeiro jogo da saga Elder Scrolls e acredito que fiz uma ótima escolha.

Pra um jogo de 2007 é bem complexo, o sistema de "level up" e "Efficient leveling up" é capaz de confundir os novos jogadores, entretanto é possível baixar um mod onde o sistema de upar de level volta ao normal.

É incrível que, toda cidade tenha suas características, cada uma é única, completamente diferente das outras, acredito que isso seja um zelo que poucos jogos possuem hj em dia. Cada interior tem a sua decoração, com seus items, decoração e por ai vai.

Você também tem uma liberdade absurda pra fazer qualquer tipo de build, Guerreiro, Mago, Stealth e várias outras, nesse quesito a criatividade de quem joga é o limite.

As músicas são um tanto repetitivas e chega num ponto que fica chato de ouvir, embora, seja bem feita e bem "imersiva".  

O jogo entretanto é repetitivo, as dungeons, cavernas e acampamentos fazem o jogo ficar um tanto massante. No começo pode até ser divertido e suscitar essa vontade de explorar o mapa mas a longo prazo fica chato.

A customização de personagem é ok pra um jogo da época, não acredito que seja complexa mas também não é tão simples assim.

A interação com personagens é divertida e imprevisível o que adiciona um tom de humor

Em relação a DLC: Não recomendo comprar nenhuma além da Frostcrag Spire e a que habilita Sundercliff watch.

Eu daria 8.9/10 pra Oblivion, não é um jogo que eu jogaria denovo, mas guardo com bastante carinho

Oblivion has its problems (mainly its main storyline and the oblivion gates), but other than that I truly believe this is the greatest Elder Scrolls game ever made. Many folks will not agree with me, choosing Skyrim or Morrowind instead. I grew up playing Daggerfall, and Oblivion is the closest Bethesda ever came to capturing a sense of scale and freedom close enough to Daggerfall but in a modern way. Oblivion is full of great ideas, charm, discovery. I love its weird clunky UI, its side quests, DLC, progression systems. Skyrim is far too cleaned up in its systems to me, and I found myself incredibly bored with it. I sunk countless hours into this game on Xbox 360 and still feel pulled to explore it further and visit my favorite towns and NPCs.

This game is objectively bad in a lot of ways:
-forgettable main quest
-braindead AI
-massive retcon of the setting (LotR had come out recently around its release and suddenly Cyrodil is no longer a jungle as previous games had mentioned)
-clunky combat, especially spellcasting (fuck you if you wanna have more than 1 spell at the ready, right? Just kidding, you're gonna be a stealth archer anyway)
-character models have aged terribly and look like wood carvings of people
-byzantine menus

So why the recommendation?
-Oblivion is the all time champ for most unintentionally entertaining games. Just watching the aforementioned AI spiral into absolute chaos from something unremarkable or get locked into surreal conversations with each other still makes me laugh. 
-I'm a sucker for a good OST
-I love the look of the menus and UI, even if they're arranged poorly. 

If you catch it on sale, you will absolutely get $5-10 worth of entertainment.

This isn't a review; it's more of a recollection of my memory.

This game holds a very fond place in my memory. It was the first open-world RPG I ever played. Back in 2007 when I was 15, I didn't understand English very well. I bought a guidebook translated into Thai a month before I even got the game. I read the guidebook cover to cover, but even in Thai, I didn't understand much of what was going on. Eventually, I got the game two weeks later and started playing. I was totally hooked on the game world. There were many enjoyable moments in the game, and it's also where I started to understand English a bit more.

I played as a Khajit Warrior proficient in both melee and ranged combat. I still remember looting everything I could find, getting the 33 all-element damage staff, then going to kill Umbra to obtain the best sword. I rushed through the Brotherhood questline to get Shadowmere, then found a forest camp to farm melee and ranged skills on Shadowmere. After that, I focused on restoration until I maxed out the three main stats at 10 before I slept to level up. I remember doing that in a bandit camp somewhere across from Leyawiin. Then I completed tons of quests, and when I almost reached the max level, I continued the Mage Guild questline to create custom spells. That's when I started using cheat codes because the spells I wanted to try used way too much magicka. I ended up with a character with 200 in all stats and a spell that let me run on water, making the game feel ridiculously fun. By the time I started playing the main quest, my character was already way too overpowered. All of this remains a very fond memory.

This game was also a stepping stone for me to start working in an international company and led me to pursue my graduate degree here in the US. It's where I began to grasp the English language, along with Fallout 3. The latter game also got me into a bit of modding and programming.

I'm 31 now and still can't believe how much this game has affected my life. My life wouldn't be like this if I hadn't played this game and if my parents hadn't allowed me to.

I love this game. I first played it on Xbox 360, and then on Xbox One where I got 100%. This game will never gets old, and I am on the path to 100% once again. The game is alright but feels like it could have a little more to it to give it a better experience. Compared to the previous and next elder scrolls games, this one is underwhelming but not horrible. It does have a unique culture in the world, and is a unique story and experience, and helps explain some of the lore and does some worldbuilding, however, it feels very forgettable as compared to Skyrim and Morrowind, and you could skip over Oblivion in favor of either of the other two. Oblivion has plenty of meme potential and some good moments, with a final mainline quest moment that is more epic than possibly any moment in Skyrim. I do wish it was more dynamic like Morrowind or had more features such as Skyrims smithing/mining systems, but its definitely a complete game and theres a lot of hours of content to enjoy here. As I wade through the ocean of mediocrity that is this so-called "classic" of the gaming world, I can't help but marvel at the audacity of those who dare to call it a masterpiece. Let us embark on this epic journey into the realm of disappointment, where even the most fervent defenders of this overrated title might find it hard to ignore its glaring flaws.

First and foremost, let's talk about the groundbreaking graphics that Oblivion flaunted upon its release. Oh, how marvelous it was to witness the characters' faces that looked like they had been sculpted by a blindfolded toddler with Play-Doh! Truly, the creators of this game must have decided that realism was overrated and opted for a more avant-garde approach to character design. Who needs facial expressions when you can have a cast of characters resembling a bizarre masquerade ball gone horribly wrong?

And let's not forget the awe-inspiring landscapes that were ahead of their time – if you happen to consider flat, textureless fields and awkwardly placed trees to be the epitome of artistic achievement. The sheer audacity to present such lackluster visuals as a triumph in open-world design is a testament to the game's commitment to underwhelming its audience.

Now, let's delve into the riveting narrative, a tale so captivating that it might as well be a textbook on insomnia. The main questline, featuring the illustrious protagonist known as the Hero of Kvatch, is a rollercoaster of excitement that somehow manages to be as predictable as the changing of the seasons. Save the world from impending doom? Groundbreaking. It's almost as if the writers pulled a generic fantasy plotline from a hat and decided to roll with it.

And let's not overlook the enthralling characters that populate this vibrant world – from the stoic and forgettable knights to the wooden and lifeless elves, each one a masterpiece in uninspired dialogue and lackluster voice acting. It's as if the developers went out of their way to ensure that players would form no emotional connection whatsoever with the denizens of Cyrodiil.

Combat, oh what a joy! The fluidity of movement, the precision of strikes – it's like watching a ballet where everyone involved is stumbling over their own feet. The sublime joy of engaging in combat is only heightened by the erratic AI, which seems to alternate between bouts of genius and downright idiocy. Who wouldn't want to face off against enemies with the strategic acumen of a confused chicken?

But let's not forget the pièce de résistance – the leveling system. A stroke of sheer brilliance, or perhaps madness, that rewards players with the profound experience of facing increasingly powerful enemies as their own skills stagnate. It's a design choice that can only be described as avant-garde – a term we'll use liberally throughout this review to mask the glaring issues.

In conclusion, The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion is a shining example of a game that managed to capture the hearts of players through the sheer force of nostalgia goggles. If you have a penchant for masochism and an insatiable desire to experience a fantasy world that's less immersive than a puddle, then by all means, indulge in the delight that is Oblivion. But for those who prefer their gaming experiences to be something more than a trip down memory lane, perhaps it's best to leave this relic of a bygone era in the dusty annals of gaming history.

Game Summary:

* You are a loser in a prison
* Broke and can't even spare a coin for the needy
* That one dark elf insults you no matter what
* Console commands can break/fix the game depending on your outlook
* The faces of everyone look like swollen pears
* Dialogue is anything but natural
* Graphics are dated to put it nicely

Overall Outlook:

* 10/10 Would suggest picking up this game to play. I first played this game on my Xbox 360 about a year or two after it's original release. Fell in love with all of it's quirky characters, missions, enemies, environments, and bugs. Sure it's goofy but it makes for great fun and a relaxing play through. I love the game because I can screw around and just decompress. And if I really want to, I can just walk around and appreciate the landscapes in the game. It is an old game but there is a lot to admire about it. The dungeons and traps are way more unique and actually scary at times compared to that one game (Skyrim). Don't get me wrong, Skyrim is visually appealing in numerous ways. But in terms of game-play, I have always preferred Oblivion. Maybe it's the bugs and the finicky fighting. Or the terrible conversations that make no sense. At any rate, it's just got a lot of character.

Back when Champions of the gaming industry reigned unblemished and adored. Before greed and corruption took hold of their hearts. Step back in time, to when your elder Uncles or Dads explored Cyrodiil with an excited gleam in their eyes, with still a few solid years left of the Golden Years of gaming before them. Oblivion is in a tricky position, being the awkward step child between Skyrim and Morrowind. I started with Skyrim and have played that plenty since it's release but I've only recently gone back and played Morrowind, which I immediately fell in love with once I understood the game and met it on it's level. Oblivion doesn't require as much to get comfortable with the systems, but maybe that's because I came to it from Morrowind. 

I do recommend Oblivion, but I can't help but see the potential if Bethesda had improved on some of the systems from Morrowind instead of deleting them outright. Instead of being able to break the game over your knee with enchantments and artifacts, now even the most powerful of swords with the most powerful of enchantments is not that much better than the loot you find in the world. Trying to balance a single player game will never make sense to me.

What is TES: Oblivion ?

My first contact with TES was with Morrowind like in 2006 or something and I would only return to the franchise again after Skyrim was released which made me replay Morrowind and then finally beat skyrim for the first time when I got a better pc back in 2012, which meant I had this gap in the middle, that I never played oblivion, so I played it like almost a decade ago and I never got it on steam because I never cared about getting it here, even tho I already had skyrin and morrowind, recently on a sale I got it for cheap.

To start with the review, Oblivion is a complicated case, compared to other TES games, I feel like its the one that has the biggest personality, maybe it wasnt made on purpose but whenever I see the characters talking in the middle of a town, the zoom in their ugly faces, this followed with the more colorful nature of the game which is a lot brighter than skyrim or morrowind, it just makes this game feel funny and despite playing this one after Morrowind and Skyrim pretty much years ago, I still found it fun to play and enjoyed its more fast paced combat system, it felt sometimes even more fluid than skyrim, however the more I played the more I lost interest...

Despite the more colorful visuals that I prefer over than morrowind and skyrim, cyrodiil is the most boring location out of all 3 I mentioned before, despite having a great capital city, the map of Oblivion doesnt give me the same desire to explore it especially with its very weird difficult mode with scaling enemies, the story here about gates of hell opening everywhere isn’t that interesting either, I felt like the game was lacking a central villain like Dagoth Ur or Alduin, Mehrunes isn’t as interesting as them and the way the conflict against him is resolved is lame, the overall closure of the game is very disappointing, I do like the soundtrack of this one the best, however since Cyrodiil didn’t give me that awe that morrowind or skyrim did as locations, a disappointing main story mode and weird difficult aspects the game had, turns out I only did a few stuff outside the main quest which was like a dozen sidequests, all oblivion gates closed and no participation in any guild, when the main story left me with an off feeling I just wanted to get over the game.

However besides all this personal experience, I think Cyrodiil didn’t hook me because maybe I already had experience Morrowind and Skyrim before so Oblivion didn’t had much to offer that felt more unique compared to those two games, Im sure with some mods certain issues can be fixed as any Bethesda game, but I for me its the weakest of the 3 mainline 3d elder scrolls game but still definitely one of the best rpgs of its decade and how cheap it is now, definitely worth getting.

This game isn't just fun to play; it's a masterpiece that deserves a permanent spot in any gaming library, be it on Steam or otherwise.

A hamburger, or simply burger, is a food consisting of fillings—usually a patty of ground meat, typically beef—placed inside a sliced bun or bread roll. Hamburgers are often served with cheese, lettuce, tomato, onion, pickles, bacon, or chilis; condiments such as ketchup, mustard, mayonnaise, relish, or a "special sauce", often a variation of Thousand Island dressing; and are frequently placed on sesame seed buns. A hamburger patty topped with cheese is called a cheeseburger. Now, hamburgers are good, The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion is also good. Yet, it is not a hamburger ... strange isn't it?

This was the first ES game I played.  I loved the open world with no pressure to complete the main quest line.  There is far more variation in the biomes and color palette compared to Skyrim.  
The mob level scaling starts to get rough at higher levels, but can be countered with delightful game-breaking potions and enchanting.  The harder modes almost make it impossible to play without a little exploitation.  
The magic and alchemy are far better than Skyrim, but the smithing is WAY worse.  If you own both ES IV and ES V, you will be able to play Skyblivion.  It is a fan-made mod that recreates Oblivion with the Skyrim engine.  Due to licensing restrictions, every physical item and landscape in game had to be reproduced by volunteers.  The estimated release date is 2025.
You must own both ES4: Oblivion, and ES5: Skyrim to play.  If you already own Skyrim, you should also buy Oblivion to further your ES knowledge and prepare for the release of Skyblivion.

Hands down one of my all time favorites, a must have for any elder scrolls fan.

No wonder this game won the GOTY back in 2006, because it's really fun to play. It might be old, but not too outdated as many might think.

The game starts just as every other Elder Scrolls' title: creating a character being held as prisoner. This time we are prisoners in the Imperial City, in Cyrodiil. During the escape of the emperor Uriel Septim VII, he gets murdered, but before his death he gives us a task of finding the heir to the throne. And so, our adventure begins. 

Just like I said time ago with Morrowind, it can look kind of outdated technically playing, and no wonder: it's a game released in 2006, as one of the first Xbox 360/PS3 titles. Still, it's playable and enjoyable, with many missions to play, characters to meet and many places to explore.

The aspect that might have aged badly is the graphic style, since the characters lack of good facial expressions with some goofy faces. Still, the enviroments aged well, with a good looking landscape, cities, etc... 

And the soundtrack? Incredible. Personally it's not my favourite in the saga, but I still like it. The voice acting might be kinda weak tho.

I would wait for sales to buy the games. The full price of the game is 15€, which considering the hours of gameplay it's not that expensive, but buying it for 3,74€ (or 5€ the deluxe edition) can hurt less to your wallet.

Oblivion, the epic fantasy adventure, falls short in an unexpected area—diversity and inclusion. In a game where players traverse a vast and enchanting world, the lack of representation from various backgrounds leaves the experience feeling somewhat one-dimensional.

The realms of Cyrodiil are teeming with magical creatures and diverse landscapes, yet the inhabitants often share a homogenous quality that detracts from the game's potential richness. The missed opportunity to incorporate a broader spectrum of characters and stories is particularly noticeable in a fantasy setting that could have embraced a multitude of cultural influences.

Funny and very memorable rpg. It has this whimsical early 2000s medieval fantasy style which I really dig. I think where this game really shines among the other Elder Scrolls titles is in its faction quests and cheeky voice acting.
Although I've heard some people trashing on its graphics, I have personally found the game's scenery to be absolutely stunning.

Has a few cons though. Mainly its leveling system, which sucks ass because as you level up your enemies see their stats boosted until they become big annoying HP sponges.
It also doesn't help that the melee combat system quickly gets really boring after a while.

But in overall, it's a fun enjoyable classic.

I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right hand—the hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bed—the hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happiness of other people. I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

I purchased Oblivion after the Skyrim version on Switch glitched so badly that it became unplayable (this year, 2023)

Oblivion might be old, but is by far superior to Skyrim in the aspect of the love that has been given to the story lines and some details like being able to decorate your house(s). Yes, there are a lot of things that lack the convenience of Skyrim, and you practically don't have followers, but Oblivion was immense fun to play.

Whilst I played Skyrim now for 1000+ hours altogether (switched to the PC version, as Nintendo version is horrible, even more so after playing Skyrim on PC and seeing even more differences!!! It's as if Bethesda released a test version for the Switch and can't be bothered, but happily takes the money), I enjoyed Oblivion on a deeper level because of the depths of lore, that is just missing in Skyrim.

Also, if you are a Skyrim player you might find yourself in the position with Oblivion of having loads of Aha! and Ohhhhh! moments, as you make certain connections (again, no spoilers).

I don't want to spoil anything by giving details, but if you don't mind 20+ year old graphics, go an play Oblivion. It's well worth it.

Having embarked on my journey through The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion 16 years ago, it remains a timeless classic that holds a special place in my gaming soul. While some may scoff at its aging graphics and UI, I find solace and charm in their simplicity, evoking a sense of nostalgia. The diverse landscapes, from majestic mountains to mysterious marshes, create a fantasy canvas that continues to surprise and awe. The guild quests, especially the Dark Brotherhood, steal the show with their narrative brilliance, making them a shining example of gaming storytelling. Oblivion's open world is a living, breathing entity, where every decision resonates in a vibrant tapestry of consequences, creating an immersive odyssey that transcends mere gaming. In an age of hyper-realistic visuals, Oblivion's unique beauty lies in its simplicity, allowing the imagination to fill in the gaps. It's not just a game; it's a pinnacle of the series that has captivated this avid gamer's heart for over a decade.

First of all, shitty engine, I hate this engine so much. It's one of my primary gripes with FO3 and I can just barely tolerate it to enjoy FNV. No amount of mods can deal with the fact that playing the games on this engine just doesn't feel good. Morrowind at least has the benefit of being jank in a fun way, like Daggerfall.

Anyways, when I first played the game I liked what the game tried to do, and there's plenty of quests that are interesting and dialogue that is fun, but now that I've experienced (almost) the whole series (fuck Arena), this game is honestly really disappointing. It's more of a generic fantasy game more than an Elder Scrolls game, and in terms of gameplay it's straight up just poorly designed. The way the scaling works makes me think no QA tester actually played through the whole game with one character, and it got rid of all of the interesting RPG mechanics that help make Daggerfall and Morrowind fun while not being a satisfying FPS/TPS experience like Skyrim can be.

Overall, I think it's the worst offering in the series (except Arena). I'd straight up recommend not playing this game unless you have already become an elder scrolls fan, and in which case, you're probably going to play this game regardless, and to which I say have as much fun as you can.

The leveling system is a mess, it was one of the first games to introduce modern day DLC, there's only a handful of voices used for dialogue, it's more streamlined than Morrowind, and there's enemy level scaling. Despite all of these flaws, this game is absolutely worth playing in 2023/2024. There's an indescribable serene nature within Oblivion. The music, environments, and questlines are still some of the best in the industry. 

While the NPC behavior leads to many meme-worthy moments, it is still impressive seeing villagers with 24/7 work/social/sleep cycles. Seeing someone at work during the day then at a tavern or guild's quarters at night really adds to the immersion.
