Starting up Elder Scrolls Oblivion for the first time, I was apprehensive. My first taste of Bethesda magic came through with Skyrim when i was 12. Spending well over a hundred hours running around from dungeon to dungeon. City to city. Conquering dragon after dragon. Surely, going back to their previous title was going to do nothing but disappoint me. Skyrim's graphics were borderline dated for their time already. And the floaty melee combat would simply be more exaggerated. So surely, I wouldn't be able to spend more than an hour in Cyrodiil before calling it a day... right? 

Bethesda worked its magic again. I found myself falling in love and immersed in yet another world. Hell, who better than to welcome me into it all than [i]Patrick Stewart[/i] himself as [i]Emperor Uriel Septim VII[/i]. Thrust into another grand adventure upon escaping prison - the world became my oyster and I was sucked in for 100+ hours. 

Combat is as you expect of a Bethesda title, even as I write this at the end of 2023. Weightless and rather janky at times - especially if you're more focused on melee based builds. I've always enjoyed being somewhat of a battle mage myself; Trusty sword in one hand and some combat based spells in the other. Always a great combo to go for with the amount of effects you can conjure forth and rain down on your enemies. Dare I say, I found myself enjoying questing more so here than I did with Skyrim at the time. The Shivering Isles DLC certainly left a good mark on me. Although I certainly do miss the organic and seamless Dragon battles that occurred in Skyrim - the feeling of badassery is felt more there for sure. 

Presentation leaves lots to desire too I'm afraid. This is a badly dated title. Running on the Gamebryo engine - if you thought Bethesda's current Creation Engine iterations are dated and bothersome. This isn't going to be changing your mind anytime soon. The facial animations and apparent use of 4 or 5 voice actors across Cyrodiil is rather incredible. Not in the best of ways - but at least in a funny way.

Perhaps it's the music and soundtrack then that all came together to provide me with such a chill and pleasant time in Cyrodiil. The world and vibe is reflected incredibly well through its sounds. There's a reason there are memes to this day referring to real life, "Oblivion Dialogue" , set to the sounds of this game. It just works so well with awkward social encounters apparently. But it just endears me to the title further. I might even prefer the main theme over Skyrim's. There's something about the [b]GRAND[/b] nature of it all - being here at the Emporer's calling and request to defend a nation against impending doom. Rising up as a Champion. 

I adored the time I had spent addicted to saving Cyrodiil from Oblivion. While Bethesda may have lost some luster with fans nowadays - the rumoured remaster of Oblivion will certainly quell some negativity...

Disregarding nostalgia, this is what I think peak Elder Scrolls game should be. It has the love and care of Morrowind, and it is only slightly harder to understand than Skyrim. You could easily make it a simple game if you don't want to go into the more complex mechanics, but it feels so rewarding to play tactically as a mage or rouge.

Edit: Recalling the detail of lore in Morrowind, it is certainly lacking, but Oblivion doesn't gut the core philosophy of ES. In my opinion, Skyrim feels more like a quicker rpg than it's predecessors. The class choices you make are far more important than Skyrim, but not as fleshed out as Morrowind. I remember how in love I was with Skyrim because it did feel like a freshened up world of ES. As time goes on and I watched more videos on these games though, I feel like starting in Oblivion you can feel the old philosophy drifting away if you'll forgive the metaphor. Skyrim wants you to be a hero, Oblivion wants you to be a person who becomes a hero, and Morrowing casts you in a wholly different light while still using the motif of "Chosen Hero".

[h1]The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion - A Pinnacle of Open-World Gaming[/h1]

The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion, released in 2006, remains a cornerstone in the world of open-world RPGs. Developed by Bethesda Game Studios, this installment in the iconic Elder Scrolls series has left an indelible mark on the gaming landscape. Over a decade since its release, Oblivion stands as a testament to the timeless appeal of its expansive world, immersive storytelling, and groundbreaking gameplay mechanics.

[h2]Visual and Artistic Brilliance:[/h2]
Oblivion's visual presentation is a triumph that has stood the test of time. The game's rendition of the diverse landscapes of Cyrodiil, from bustling cities to dense forests, is a testament to the meticulous attention to detail by the developers. While the graphics may not match contemporary standards, the artistry embedded in each location remains captivating. The architectural diversity of cities, the atmospheric effects, and the intricate design of characters and creatures contribute to a visually rich and compelling game world.

[h2]Immersive Storytelling:[/h2]
At the heart of Oblivion lies a narrative of epic proportions. The looming threat of Oblivion Gates and the resurgence of the Daedric Prince Mehrunes Dagon serve as a compelling backdrop to the player's journey. However, what truly elevates Oblivion's storytelling is the depth and complexity of its side quests. Players find themselves entangled in a web of intrigue, moral dilemmas, and unexpected twists, fostering a sense of agency that few games achieve. The world feels alive not just through grand events but also through the intricacies of individual stories woven into its fabric.

[h2]Dynamic Gameplay and Customization:[/h2]
Oblivion's gameplay mechanics set a high standard for open-world RPGs. The flexibility of character customization through an intricate skill and leveling system allows players to tailor their experience to their preferred playstyle. The Radiant AI system, though imperfect, introduced a dynamic element to NPC behavior, making interactions within the game world unpredictable and immersive. The vast array of spells, weapons, and skills further adds to the richness of player choice, creating a truly open-ended experience.

[h2]Unforgettable Audio Design:[/h2]
Jeremy Soule's evocative musical score is a standout feature, enhancing every moment of the player's journey. The haunting melodies and ambient sounds seamlessly blend with the game's atmosphere, creating an emotional resonance that lingers long after the game is turned off. The attention to detail in sound design, from the rustle of leaves in the wind to the distant roar of creatures, contributes significantly to the immersive quality of the gaming experience.

[h2]Enduring Legacy and Modding Community:[/h2]
Beyond its initial release, Oblivion's enduring legacy is sustained by its vibrant modding community. The game's open framework and modding tools have empowered a dedicated community of creators to expand and enhance the experience continuously. From graphical enhancements to entirely new questlines, the modding scene ensures that Oblivion remains a living, breathing world that evolves with the creativity of its player base.

[h2]Conclusion:[/h2]
In conclusion, The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion is more than a game; it is a milestone in the evolution of open-world gaming. Its enduring visual appeal, immersive storytelling, dynamic gameplay, and unforgettable audio design combine to create an experience that resonates with players across generations. Oblivion's influence on the gaming industry is undeniable, and its continued relevance is a testament to its status as a timeless classic in the RPG genre. Whether revisiting the world of Cyrodiil or stepping into it for the first time, players are bound to discover an adventure that transcends the boundaries of conventional gaming.

Movement is slow and sluggish. Controls and keybindings are infuriating. Combat is laughably bad if not equally infuriating to the movement. Enemies don't telegraph attacks, making it extremely annoying to fight literally anything. Character models, especially the faces are nightmare fuel and belong in a horror game.

The only thing the game has going for it is quantity and an interesting setting.

The first thing that always strikes me about Oblivion is the comfortable and safe familiarity of its world, regardless of the controversy surrounding its depiction as a generic fantasy world in place of the lush rainforest it was in lore prior. There's still something magical however about stepping out into the rolling hills and dense forests of Cyrodiil. 

Oblivion also marks the beginning of a shift to a more console-friendly form of RPG, but that doesn't mean it's without depth; instead it offers an engaging blend between action-based combat and stat management. Levelling up remains a contentious problem in Oblivion as enemies scale with you, and yet it's also still a lot of fun to dawdle and take your time regardless. It remains a world filled with wonder and adventure regardless of the quirks, and one I still love to return to.

Fun Elder Scrolls game. Skyrim is better overall, but Oblivion has a unique charm that Skyrim doesn't. It doesn't take itself too seriously, and many of the dialogue sequences and NPC interactions will have you laughing. It's also a beautiful environment where everything feels Medieval and fantastical. It's much more relaxed as opposed to Skyrim's hyper-serious tone. Worth playing. You'll need to get quite a few mods to fix some basic issues, but that's expected with Bethesda games anyway. I also highly recommend playing the Knights of the nine DLC questline and the Shivering Isles DLC. Very well made DLC.

I played this game for the first time in 2021 and I have to say it didn't age well at all for someone with no nostalgic connection to it. The world is empty and depressing, the side quests really aren't as great as long time fans make them out to be and the combat is even worse than in Skyrim. The character models look like something straight out of a playdough fever dream. They look terrible to a point where it's hard to take the characters and what they say seriously. Graphics are usually not that important to me, but in this case it actively worsens my playing experience. There's a reason why only die hard fans who played this game back in 2007-2010 still talk so highly of it. If you're planning to play this game for the first time today, you should probably mod it to a more playable state. This is my least favorite TES game. This is of course just my subjective opinion and shouldn't keep you from giving this game a chance.

[h1] A Masterpiece of Fantasy Gaming [/h1]
[h2] Rating: ★★★★★ (5/5) [/h2]



I have been a fan of the Elder Scrolls series for years, and Oblivion truly lives up to its reputation as one of the greatest fantasy RPGs of all time. With its captivating lore, immersive world, and incredible gameplay, this game has kept me hooked for countless hours.

Firstly, the world of Cyrodiil is breathtakingly beautiful and diverse. From dense forests to vast plains and grand cities, each location is meticulously crafted with stunning visual details. Exploring the land feels like a genuine adventure, and uncovering hidden dungeons and quests adds an extra layer of excitement.

Character customization in Oblivion is another highlight. The game provides an extensive range of race, class, and skill options, allowing players to tailor their character to their desired playstyle. The leveling system is well-balanced, enabling a genuine sense of progression as you develop your abilities and gain new spells or abilities.

Furthermore, the main questline is captivating and engaging. The story of the protagonist's journey to close the gates of Oblivion and overcome the Daedric invasion is richly woven with unexpected twists and turns. The supporting characters are memorable, each with their own unique personalities and quirks. Side quests are equally captivating, making every corner of the game world worth exploring.

In terms of gameplay mechanics, Oblivion strikes the perfect balance between accessibility and depth. Combat feels satisfying and responsive, while the spellcasting system allows for endless possibilities. The AI is noticeably improved compared to its predecessors, making encounters with enemies or NPCs feel more realistic and challenging.

Lastly, the modding community for Oblivion is incredible. With thousands of user-created mods available, you can extend your gaming experience even further. From enhanced graphics and new quests to gameplay tweaks and additional content, the modding scene keeps the game fresh and exciting, even after years of its release.

Overall, The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion is a true masterpiece that has stood the test of time.

Right off the bat the game is unplayable. I cant use my keyboard. I shouldn't have to hunt down a fix online and mess with the game files just so I can type my fucking name in the character creation screen.

I recommend to play this game with the Bevilex's mod list to bring it to 2010s standards.

You could skip the graphic mods if you want but the stability ones are crucial.  

Otherwise it shows its age both in technical and some gameplay aspects due to how unstable it runs and the incredible amount of bugs it has when you don't use at least 3 or 4 different patches.

Don't get me wrong, it was a great game back then.  And it still is perhaps one of the best RPGs ever done, 

I just think it hasn't aged very well in some aspects, despite how much I liked it. 

Thanks to the community though, as with every game from Bethesda, that can easily be changed.

Personally, my favorite Elder Scrolls game. An amazing cast of voice actors, including Sean Bean, Terence Stamp, Wes Johnson, and my favorite Patrick Stewart as Uriel Septim. I remember seeing the trailer come out and it revealed the beautiful landscape along with Patrick Stewart narrating in the background to the tune of this amazing sound track. I was blown away. I've been playing this game for years and I keep coming back because it's so enjoyable. 

Pros - Amazing soundtrack

- Voice acting

- A multitude of different class set-ups that are all viable

- Some of the best guild quests in any ES game (most notably the darkbrotherhood, which is my favorite part of this game hands down.)

- Huge sprawling world that I've yet to completely explore in my 10 plus years of playing this

- I believe it was the first game where you can retrieve your arrows from the environment.

- Huge cities where you can buy property 

- The lower fantasy setting, which I find to be more immersive 

- Being able to cast and have any weapon equipped, most notably a bow for those types of builds

- Many interesting characters 

- Amazing side quests 



Cons

- Actual combat leaves a lot to be desired, yet it has some redeemable factors considering how many different build style you can use.

- Bugs and glitches 

- Oblivion gates are dull and repetitive

- Small voice acting cast for npcs, so you end up hearing the same voice over and over again

- Level scaling could have been handled better

- Faces can be hard to look at lol

- Crime system feels arbitrary

- Enemies tend to be bullet spongy (depends on difficulty setting)

- Could have used more dense forest but that's probably due to the engine limitations. 

Overall, an amazing game and experience. I recommend anyone to try this game if they have not yet.

Oh, the best quote in the game is "I'm Mirabelle Monet. I run the Fo'c's'le, a boarding house for sailors. Sorry, I reserve my beds for seamen."

Pros: Nice forest. Some interesting quests.
Cons: the rest of the game is generic and unimmersive.

I have a few 1000 hour games and this is one of them, between time spent here and on the PS3 version.

Most playthroughs I start by either heading off to find a dead emperor's son, or I climb up from the sewer to the imperial city arena, to get some armor and gold. There I find "The Gray Prince" Agronak who tasks me to travel to an abandoned fort in the remote western hills of the Gold Coast, to uncover the truth of his parentage.

The road becomes muddled. Am I attacked by bandits protecting their claim over an Ayleid ruin? Will I find a powerful bow or enchanted piece of armor which changes my play style? In my travels west, do I meet an insane little man called Glarthir who says he'll pay me 1000 gold pieces to murder his neighbours? Do I ever learn the secret of Agronak's birth?

Dive into Oblivion, accept the complete non-structure of its world and you'll be be endlessly rewarded. At least until the game starts crashing for no reason 50 hours in and you rage quit.

once you've played one elder scroll game, youve played them all
it's the same hundred hour fetch quest slog with zero decision making on your part that is very fun until you finish one quest line, then you realize nothing you do mattered, and everything was designed to consume your time mindlessly
example:
The main quest (gameplay spoilers for the middle), you are tasked to return fetch item #1 the most important fetch in all of Tamriel. The big bad man has the fetch item, and you must infiltrate his compound. Oh boy this sounds exciting I can't wait for all the ways I can fool these guys into getting the item! Wait what? Why is there only one entrance? Weird. Wait, I can't sneak past this guy? He auto detects me? Oh so there is one linear infiltration path that automatically happens. Oh. Ok I'm at the fetch item, let me kill this guy before he teleports away, so I may get the item. Oh, he's invincible.

It's like the writers realized how short and linear the main story is, realized they needed to make it longer so they removed the option to not fail this quest despite it clearly being designed for you to actually kill the guy. Now they did this so they can interject like 4 insanely massive dungeons filled with copy and paste enemies that are also highly linear and plot-wise empty to pad the game.

Another example:
In the Dark Brotherhood quest line (major spoilers) Lucien tasks you with killing literally every single dark brotherhood member in your sanctum. This is because there's a spy amongus. Naturally you assume you can find the spy, so you open several masterlock chests looking for any clues to find, and theres literally none. No that random barrel that has a masterlock on it in Lucien's room is literally filled with apples. So there is no traitor, atleast any you can find and this guy is telling you to literally kill everyone. So I deduct by that, he's lying, and that he is the traitor. Naw he's essential, can't kill him. Literally zero decisions made on the mission where you betray everyone.
idk especially sucks when you realize theres zero motivation for your character to be doing these massacres other than money, but the story still tries to pretend youre loyal to the DB

It's oblivion, Hail Sithis

Oblivion does a lot of things right, but also does a lot of things very poorly. Easily Oblivion's greatest strength are the side-quests, which are very creative and intriguing. Notable examples include quests that have you save a painter stuck inside his own creation, or the quest that has you attend a party with the intention of killing everyone inside. Another strength Oblivion has is how alive the world feels, despite how weak the world-building is and NPC conversations are. The soundtrack is also phenomenal and accompanies the 'medieval' feel of the world very well, which makes it a far more immersive experience. However, where Oblivion's biggest issues are lie in the unbalanced level-scaling, the repetitive dungeons and landscapes, floaty movement and combat that while responsive unlike Morrowind, isn't very fluid. Despite all of its flaws, Oblivion is one of my favorite video-games of all time and think that its worth playing, although I would install at least the Unofficial Oblivion Patch mod to make the game less buggy.

The last Elder Scrolls game to wow me. I still remember emerging from the sewers for the first time and seeing this vast open world around me waiting to be explored. There are complaints that it's a very generic fantasy world and those complaints are valid. It is the most vanilla, basic, boring fantasy world around and yet it still has this strange charm that the series never really had again. It's just strange enough on the periphery to keep it compelling with some of the best side quests ever made. I still recommend it today as the standard for the series, but you'll definitely want to mod this thing up. It's age is showing, but with a few mods, it can still be a good time visually and gameplay wise. More than Skyrim, this is still the Elder Scrolls game I find myself most likely to load up for another run. In fact, it might just be time to do that again.

This is where my journey with the Elder Scrolls games began, and I was totally blown away by Oblivion at the time.  The graphics were ground-breaking, and the land of Cyrodiil was wide-open to explore.  With its contrasting environments from the Imperial City to the snowy town of Bruma, this game pulled me in and wouldn't let go!

There is a main quest, but you are totally free to ignore it and do the many side quests, or even no quests at all and just go exploring.  I completed the main quest. many side quests and nearly all of the Guild quests, many of which I found more interesting than the main quest.  The Assassin's Guild quest line is probably the best of the bunch.

Combat is a little clunky, there's a cookie-cutter approach to some of the dungeons, and clearing out the Oblivion gates gets tiresome, but this game is definitely one to play if you're into RPGs and haven't experienced it yet.

There are a host of mods to fix bugs and improve graphics and game play for modern hardware.  There's even a project called Skyblivion that will run the game in the Skyrim engine, which will be epic.  I shall probably go back to Oblivion once again when that is completed.

The most humorous and whimsical of the TES games. Amusing voice lines in content and delivery with a surprising amount of genuinely moving and emotionally charged moments throughout. The art direction is fantastic and I prefer the softness of it over the harsher look used in Skyrim.

Dungeons are very samey and bland and maddening to get lost in since there was nothing of interest to look at most of the time. NPCs running into your attacks is incredibly annoying. Enemy scaling is absurd. Frequently crashes even with curated modpacks optimized for stability, but I beat most of the game in spite of that and found it to be very enjoyable.

The Knights of the Nine DLC was really cool and has some of the best armor in the game both in aesthetics and power. Unfortunately it only comes in the form of heavy armor. Shivering Isles seems like a neat DLC but I have yet to complete it, right now it hasn't gripped me though. Some funny bits but has been harder to get invested into early on. Even if I dislike I will recommend this game in general though.

My favorite game from the TES series. Similar to to other Bethesda games and RPGs, with a nice balance of serious gameplay and goofy fun. The base game runs smoothly even on older PCs and laptops, although you will run into an occasional gameplay bug no matter your specs. On PC most bugs are easily fixed with console commands or anti-crash mods. Modding is always enjoyable, creating your own custom worldspaces and NPCs is easier than the newer titles; many custom quests, NPCs, armors and weapons are available on modding sites if you want to make the game unique to you.  However the quirkiness of the game is what gives it it's charm; ugly potato-folk, silly AI encounters, and unique quests make Oblivion shine. Obviously the graphics or AI won't be on par with newer games, but for it's time, it was revolutionary in both picture and in NPC intelligence. It also has the largest map out of the 3 main games: Oblivion, then Skyrim, then Morrowind.
And a bit of advice: If you are looking to get started playing The Elder Scrolls but you're conflicted with what game you should start with- it doesn't matter. Each game is so unique and different from each other, but each one has books of lore you can delve into. Pick the game you think you would enjoy playing the most, and don't worry about the timeline.

I hope that The Elder Scrolls 6 will neither figuratively nor literally become an expansion for Skyrim, and that it will be released pretty soon. 

The time that has passed since the release of Skyrim is already twice the length of time between the releases of Oblivion and Skyrim!

The worlds in Fallout and its lackluster, Spore-themed spinoff no longer interest me.

Bethesda should have developed Starfield only after releasing The Elder Scrolls 6. Even if The Elder Scrolls 6 ends up being a rehash of Fallout 4 set in Tamriel, it would still be entertaining, and worth the wait.

However, it's frustrating that Bethesda Game Studios and Bethesda Softworks have long realized they can still make a fortune by creating 'blank slate' games, rather than delivering more intricate experiences like Daggerfall or even Morrowind. They also rely way too much on their fanbase to fix issues with their games, especially when they create them.

On a side note, I have the feeling they are now going to make games that require DLC to feel complete.

If TES6's release goes past the year 2030, then it took a really long time to develop.

If the base game turns out to be a HD version of Skyrim but has an even smaller scope than Starfield—including another uninspired storyline—it will be kinda disappointing, at least for someone like me.

Bethesda should REALLY... Like seriously... Upgrade their infamous Creation Engine...

It is way past the point where there should be no excuse!

Even if Bethesda does not do a good job, there will be some modders that adapt to Bethesda, but it's lame that Bethesda chooses to adapt to modders by never doing more than "enough."

Even to this day, I believe that Oblivion is still a genuinely amazing game and 100% worth playing for any fan of the RPG genre. The environments hold up wonderfully, the quest lines are engaging, and the soundtrack is undeniably glorious. The only thing really holding the game back is the janky levelling system, but that can easily be circumvented either through mods or simply turning down the difficulty slider when needed. Oblivion holds a place in my heart just as much as both Skyrim and Morrowind in its own special way, and if you've played and enjoyed either of those games in the past, it'd be a crime to give Oblivion a miss.

Look! Up in the sky! It's a bird! It's a plane! It's--the Hero of Kvatch with level 90 acrobatics! 

Speaking as someone who played Skyrim before taking a stab at TES IV: Oblivion, I cannot recommend this game enough. It's an experience everyone should have at least once. Where else will you hear the voice of Lord Stark talking about his "friend Joffre"? Nowhere. And did you particularly enjoy the Sheogorath quest in Skyrim (Mind of Madness)? Then this is your game, my friend. Just be sure to get the package with all the expansions, they are more than worth it.

Yes, gameplay/combat can be a little clunky at first, and there is definitely a confusing leveling system, but darn if it isn't magical (literally, invest in your magic skills). You WILL be able to leap tall buildings in a single bound.

The writing is incredible. You get invested in the NPC's lives and totally immersed in the world, just ask Sir Patrick Stewart (who IS in this game, and had some interesting things to say about the experience). I would even say, given the extent of the lore involved, it feels more immersive than Skyrim. Overall, it's a happy medium between the playability of Skyrim and the world building of Morrowind.

Questlines in this game are TOP. TIER. Oblivion Dark Brotherhood > Skyrim Dark Brotherhood, any day. Seriously ominous and actually bad-A. The Thieves Guild questline is epic, too. Expect the unexpected with this game, and remember, you do face in-world consequences for your actions.

Did you feel like a bad person for doing certain daedric quests in Skyrim? No? WELL YOU WILL IN CYRODIIL. Decisions you have to make will always feel high stakes, and sometimes there is no happy ending for a quest. Of course, sometimes being a terrible person is worth the rewards. To the Deadlands with St. Alessia!

And did I mention how acutely disturbing some of the stories are? And it's not down to graphics (believe me); it's really the storytelling and presentation. You're walking through a place called Paradise thinking "Isn't this pretty, except for the voice of the raving extremist" and then the next thing BY THE NINE WHAT IS HAPPENING. And don't get me started on what happens when go to meet [redacted] at [redacted].

As for the environment, it's actually quite stunning; it's like playing in a watercolor painting. Just watch out for painted trolls. The dungeons are diverse and difficult to navigate, but in a way that keeps you on the edge of your seat. Dealing with run-of-the-mill encounters can actually be quite challenging, which I often find rewarding. Other times I just start running in the other direction (which DOES work).

And of course, the bugs. Is it a feature or a bug? Yes. The answer is yes.

While I would keep Unofficial Elder Scrolls Page handy until you get the hang of things, any difficulty or frustration with this game is well balanced with fabulous exploits and an endless supply of surprising quests, and some things you just have to see to believe.

Oh. Goodbye.

Oblivion, at its heart, is a good game. It does some things better than Morrowind/Skyrim, and some things worse (namely, non stealth-archer combat). Overall, it is a [i]pretty fun[/i] Elder Scrolls game.

The problem, is that the engine for Oblivion is absolute trash, to put it mildly. Even if you are wanting a pure "vanilla" experience with no mods, you are not going to have a good time. You need many mods, 3rd party tools, and unofficial patches just to get a [b]SEMI[/b] stable experience. No matter what you do though, you will be besieged by crashes that increase over time.

The pros tell you not to use autosaves or quicksaves. They'll tell you to never overwrite a previous save. They'll say to restart the game after every death. They'll tell you a hundred other tips and tricks that ultimately decrease the enjoyment of your gaming experience.

I cannot count how many times I had to re-do a quest because I kept forgetting to "save manually", and then had a crash right before I thought about saving, or times where I died and just decided not to re-open the game. It's exhausting just how much you have to go through just to play the game.

And even if you follow every instruction and every best practice, you will still, inevitably, lose your savefile to corruption. I've tried on multiple occasions to get a solid "stable" experience going. I've dumped hundreds of hours into Morrowind, Skyrim, and even Oblivion back in the old days. I had hoped that with all my newfound knowledge and experience of these engines, combined with over a decade of community support, that it would be easy to "not screw it up" and get another hundred hours out of from Oblivion.

Attempt #1: Complete and total Savefile corruption after 35 hours.
Attempt #2: Complete and total Savefile corruption after 50 hours.

At the moment of this review, I have 85 hours in Oblivion. I have easily spent more than that trying to research and stabilize a mod list that would maximize the performance, stability, and gameplay aspects of Oblivion. I am feeling very burnt out and disappointed with the end result. I may try and go back to an older save to recover it, but I've done this several times already and I don't have high hopes.

But overall, Oblivion is an interesting fantasy first-person role-playing experience, different from Skyrim, with its own unique quirks and features.

As someone who experienced Oblivion for the first time in 2023 I feel the need to make a review here specifically to address any concerns of people who haven't played the game before. This game was released in 2006 and it can show its age at times which may have newer players hesitant to buy it. My goal is to fairly judge the game by the standards of 2023. Now for the record I came to the Elder Scrolls series relatively late in 2011 with the release of Skyrim and while I have played Oblivion before it was often in short bursts before being distracted by other things. I never got past the second Oblivion gate in the past and since it had been nearly a decade since my last attempt at playing it I went in with little foreknowledge of the game's mechanics or story. At the time of this review I'm 24.6 hours in, have completed several major questlines (thieves guild/ dark brotherhood) and are progressing steadily down the main story as a vampire sneak archer with some magic and a second playthrough underway as a magic user.

     Let's start with the biggest concern of a game from 2006 running on modern PCs: Compatibility. I'm playing this game on an above average gaming rig running windows 10 with an AMD card and so far I have had only a few minor issues that were solved by simply running the game in compatibility mode. These issues were a loading screen visual glitch that was harmless and a brief visual glitch where a ground texture failed to load properly giving a strange color pattern to a piece of the ground at one point. Most modern games launch with far more bugs than what I experienced running this game from 2006 on a modern PC which is saying something. Though many players recommend downloading a mod to improve the game's functioning I found that this isn't necessary and the game works perfectly fine without it.

     Now for the most important topic in my own opinion for a game: Gameplay. The greatest story in the world can't be enjoyed if the game's mechanics are boring. In this case the game holds up surprisingly well but this is the area where its age shows the most. If you're coming to this game from Skyrim or other modern titles you'll have a bit of a learning curve regarding the magic system and the leveling system can be difficult for even veteran Elder Scrolls players to wrap their heads around. While melee weapons and bows use the same first/third person shooter style that the more modern Skyrim/Fallout games use the magic is tied to the "c" key by default meaning what ever spell you have equipped can be triggered with this button. You don't equip them in your hands like in skyrim and it takes some practice to learn how to aim. That being said this system, while different, is perfectly functional and even has a few perks over Skyrim's magic such as holding melee weapons.
     The level up system: Oh boy, this is the system that can break the game for new players. I STRONGLY recommend looking up a guide to it before you start playing as it is easy to mess up your stats and you won't realize it until a good ways into the game and find yourself needing to drop the difficulty slider to compensate. Basically your character has base stats like in more traditional RPGs/DnD that affect your core abilities such as strength, endurance, etc. Carry weight, health, sneak, etc are all strongly affected by these. The stats are in turn increased by leveling the side skills that are tied to the particular stat (IE: raising sneak allows you to put points into agility, etc.). Most of this is easy enough to grasp but unfortunately because your health is tied to a particularly cumbersome trio of skills (block, armorer, and heavy armor) it is easy to find yourself seriously squishy if you don't go out of your way to build it up, IE: grinding block skill and heavy armor even though you're a mage. Failing to understand this and keep your endurance stat relevant can, and will, get you killed later in the game. This is my only real negative towards the game as it feels like a game design oversight that forces non melee players to level these skills. That being said, this is a Bethesda game so you know that this issue was fixed in a mod. Though I continue to play without this mod, no one will blame you for going for the easier level up system.

     Story: The bread and butter of an RPG is its story and Oblivion does NOT disappoint. Out of all of the Elder Scrolls titles Oblivion has my favorite storylines. As is typical in an Elder Scrolls game the main story is only a small part of the world's overall story and there is a great deal of side content that will keep you happy. As I said in the beginning I favored a sneak archer and went through the Dark Brotherhood and Thieves guild storylines, both of which were amazing. The robinhood style story of the thieves guild and their feud with a local lawman was both interesting and clever with the missions taking on a cat and mouse style feel. The dark brotherhood line is easily the best in the series with a long and convoluted story I can't really talk about without spoiling major plot points. Do it.
     As for the main story: I found Oblivion to be much more satisfying in its story than Skyrim although not quite as much so as Morrowwind. The gist of it is that portals to Oblivion (the game's equivalent of hell) are popping up and unleashing terrible creatures upon the world and you need to go in and shut them down. All the while the kingdom is trying to solve the issue of a king's succession rights and figure out why this is all happening. As is typical in an Elder Scrolls title you are a nameless, faceless stranger who wakes up on the wrong side of the law to find yourself thrust into destiny. Something I definitely liked about Oblivion's story versus others in the series is that while you are obviously the token "chosen one" of the story you aren't the only person actually doing things. Without going into detail there are a few moments in the story where the rest of the world actually takes part in saving itself. Unlike in Skyrim and Morrowwind where the people basically just sort of throw all of the responsibility on the player. It feels like you're HELPING these people overcome their problems rather than just single handedly saving the world while they hide in terror.

     Would I recommend this game to someone who has never played it before in 2023? Yes. I strongly recommend getting this game if you haven't already done so. That being said it, is frequently on sale and you should probably not pay full price (I paid 8$ for the GoTY version and regret nothing). I also strongly urge you to get the GoTY or another version that comes with the DLC. The DLC in Oblivion is legendary as being a prime example of how DLC should be done and it over doubles the amount of content and even makes the game's world bigger than that of Skyrim. The shivering isles DLC is in my opinion worth the price of a full game alone. 
     Graphics: People really judge games by the graphics? I don't generally hold graphics against a game unless they fail on a level that is insulting to the consumer (IE: a AAA title that looks like it was made 5 years earlier). When Oblivion first launched the game was visually stunning and had one of, if not THE, most beautiful worlds in any video game to date. That being said it was released in 2006 and so the visuals are somewhat dated. if you've played Fallout 3 or NV you have a pretty good idea of what you're going to be looking at. I did not find the graphics to be detrimental to my experience at all.
     Summary: The game holds up amazingly well with only a few minor setbacks mostly tied to its leveling system which can be addressed with a quick google search. The story is great, the gameplay excellent, and there really is no real reason not to say that this game is amazing even by 2023 standards.

Oblivion remains one of the most immersive and groundbreaking fantasy RPGs out there. The sheer size and scope of the open world is incredible - the forests, valleys, cities and dungeons feel richly detailed and full of surprises. Whether you follow the epic main questline or get lost in hundreds of side quests, Oblivion offers an endless adventure.

Creating and developing your character is extremely addicting. The character creator is robust for the time, letting you pick from a variety of races and customize your appearance and skills. Leveling up and picking new abilities feels very rewarding. There's real freedom to play how you want - as a powerful sorcerer, stealthy archer, hulking warrior or any hybrid of those.

Questing in Oblivion is brilliantly done. Even minor side quests are unique and take you to handcrafted caves, castles and ruins. The writing and voice acting brings the world to life. Some questlines like the Dark Brotherhood assassination guild are unforgettable. Just walking the world you'll discover new dungeons and encounters.

While the graphics are understandably dated by today's standards, the art direction of Cyrodiil and its architecture still shines. The orchestral score adds to the grandeur. Combat and gameplay can feel clunky at times, but there's so much to see and do that it's easy to look past.

Oblivion set a new bar for open world fantasy and still holds up as one of the greatest RPGs ever thanks to the incredible attention to detail and worldbuilding. Over a decade later, it remains a must-play for any RPG fan.

This is not the game for players like me.
If you like to explore the world, do all the side quests, join every faction and develop your character to become more and more powerful, then Oblivion is not the game for you.
My advice is, If you wish to enjoy this title do not exceed your gametime past 100 hours, try to keep your exploring intact, do the main story along with a several side activities and try to finish the game without visiting every place you come across while traveling the map.
I wish I knew that earlier, but there is a point in this game where leveling your character has no more sense, attributes are maxed out, your equipment is top tier and there is no space for further improvements. Leveling up after a certain point just makes your enemies have more health and hit you harder without giving you anything in return, so you suddenly find yourself in a position where you even avoid sleeping in beds to not level any further.
Leveling system and level scaling in this game is the worst thing I experienced in any RPG game (and I played a lot of these). This is literally the first game I abandoned. I feel terrible, because I was always pushing myself to beat every title I've played, but this time I've failed.

I HATE when an RPG game hits the point when you stop feeling yourself becoming more powerful, when there is nothing more to surprise you, no more items, no more foes. Oblivion gives you such a big world, but fails to deliver a character development system and diversity to keep you going.

And the last aspect which was a nail to the coffin is a fighting system. I could carry on through the game If the combat was satisfying enough. In AC Odyssey, Sekiro or Cyberpunk I also made myself powerful to the limits and there were no more rewards and no more foes for me, but a good combat system gives pleasure and brings enough satisfaction to play the game just for the sake of utilizing it.
This is not the case in Oblivion. There is no weapon feeling, hitting someone doesn't carry any weight to it and there is no freedom of approach.

I feel honestly sad leaving such an iconic game behind. I fell in love with Morrowind. This time tho, mistakes were made. This was my second Bethesda game. I do hope they didn't f*ck up any other titles in a similar way. Time will show If I become a fan of Todd Howard or one of his haters.

There are years worth of them now and they are worth engaging with to fix up some of the common problems people have with the game.

TES4: Oblivion remains one of the best games I've ever played and certainly the best RPG. The environment is, for a pin from that time, very nice, there is an incredible amount to do and adapt.
The variety in enemies, quests, items, spells etc is incredible and there is always room for discovery and entertainment.
An epic story, a lot of freedom, choices in gameplay, skills to expand, boards full of sidequests, and many hours of gameplay, which also remains fun. Oblivion is still a great game to play for non-RPG gamers as well. Areas, especially the dungeons and the "Gates of Oblivion" usually look very similar, but that is also the only real flaw.

Oblivion is already quite old and in the meantime we are waiting for TES6, but in terms of appearance there is a lot of good to say about Oblivion.
The surroundings are generally beautiful; ranging from snowy landscapes to fertile forest and farmland, all of which looked great on my old tube TV.
Players will stop often enough to enjoy the view, just like with Skyrim.
This is something I haven't had in any game I've ever played, well Skyrim and The Witcher 3 or some GTA games also made me stare at the environments a lot, but with Oblivion it was really the first time.
There is a lot to see in terms of ruins, flowers, mountains, rivers and playing deer and the DLCs also bring some extra variations with new fauna and flora. The design and animation of these elements are still quite good and provide a complete picture.

Anyway, it's not always roses and moonshine, The gates of Oblivion have opened. Cyrodiil is flooded with demons from the infernal underworld of Oblivion, where Mehrunes Dagon is lord and master. By chance, or perhaps by fate, you have become the person who has to help solve this. This is the setting of The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion.

After all, nostalgia is a great drug. And some of the games that got you excited over the years may be downright bad now, but luckily Oblivion isn't one of those games.
Even though the trees don't look so refined today, and the NPCs were a little behind mentally, it's still worth thinking about this game every now and then and starting it up again.
based

Welcome to Cyrodiil! Here the Planes are grassy, the mountains breezy, and the forests are uh... tree'y. Since the time of Morrowind there have been major enhancements in humanoid ergonomics and physical appearance. Limbs have evolved to swing weapons at lightning fast speeds, spells can be cast with one hand, and faces can give you every expression you would expect from an oddly shaped potato.

Jokes aside, The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion is a fantastic RPG, but it simplifies some of the concepts of Morrowind to its detriment. Oblivion has a far more graphically and physically populated world than its predecessor, but the locations and dungeons are generally less interesting. Equipable items have been decreased significantly, cutting down on the wackiness of character builds. Levitation was removed from the game, probably because Imperials don't know how to magic. And Oblivion gates... they start out as this fun trudge through an apocalyptic hell-scape, only to become repetitive and boring after a few visits. Oh and Horse armor.

Oblivion does have several wins going for it. The story is fun, engaging, and fairly well written with Patrick Stewart and Sean Bean lending their voices to some main characters. Combat is a 100% improvement over Morrowind with one flaw, there really is no reason to use a 2 handed weapon. Voice acting is a welcome addition, though characters can't provide nearly as much detail in the information presented. The almighty compass makes its debut. The faction quests, while not as long as Morrowind's are memorable and a true joy to complete. 

It is worth dedicating a paragraph to the phenomenal DLC for Oblivion, The Shivering Isles, and the highly underrated Knights of the Nine expansions. 

Shivering Isles brings back much of the foreign terrain that made Morrowind so special, areas are familiar to the player, in that they are perverted and warped versions of structures and nature that we are used to. Sheogorath makes for a strangely compelling character to work with and for, and the entourage and cast of characters are quirky and likeable in their own peculiar ways. The shear insanity of the Isle's will keep you entertained for hours on end. 

Knights of the Nine is not necessarily a fully fledged "addition" to Oblivion in the sense of the word. Knights adds some new locations and a swathe of new characters that have an underrated charm to them. Searching the landscape for a Paladin/Crusader armor set isn't something that initially sounds enjoyable, but Knights keeps you on your toes, and makes the experience exciting. Sadly, some of the knights you recruit along the way are named NPC's that can and will die during the final showdown if you are not careful. It is a strangely emotional experience to hear the surviving Knights of the Nine talk about their fallen comrades. 

In summary, Oblivion is the intermittent Bethesda RPG, its light, flaky, and fun while still hitting the hardcore RPG high notes. Oblivion is a staple for western RPG's for many reasons and stands out as one of the finest games of the XBOX 360/PS3 era.

This game is stupid and I love it.

Ok, well, that's sort of a lie. Because this game is genuinely amazing, and all of the jank, glitches, and awkward interactions somehow add to the experience, instead of detracting from it.

The combat is fun, the music is phenominal, the story is amazing, and the characters are actually memorable.

Genuinely think that this is better than Skyrim by a fairly large margin. Skyrim has more replayability, a bigger modding community, and a much bigger fanbase, but damn it, Oblivion is just awesome, man. Every questline in Oblivion I believe is superior to their counterpart in Skyrim.

The Ultimate Heist V.S Returning a rusty key (Theives Guild) 
Infiltrating an opposing faction, taking a drug, then realizing that you killed multiple innocent lives V.S Some pack of Furries (Fighter's Guild V.S Companions)
A finished story V.S An unfinished story (Mage factions)
Actual Dark Brotherhood V.S An impersonation group
Being the hero's best friend V.S Being a chosen one (Main Quest)

Oblivion is just much more interesting and creative with what it has. I do not hate Skyrim in the least, it's still one of my favourites, but Oblivion is just something else, man. The world is so much more vibrant and beautiful than Skyrim could ever dream of being.

10/10, We love you Wes Johnson <3
The thing I think of when I look back on a childhood of gaming. Plot holes? absolutely! Fantastic quest writing and exploration? You bet! Wacked out NPCs? Oh yeah! A truly breathtaking experience.

The quests are all go here and find this item or go there and kill some people -
not interesting and repetitive. The voice acting is top notch and the graphics,
even though very dated, stand up to the test of time (as of 2023 IMHO). The
world is very large, but also very empty; you can walk for 5 minutes and
literally see nothing interesting beyond a wolf or maybe a bear. There is no
real direction outside the main quest and I can see how people get pulled into
the 'open world' aspect for tens if not hundreds of hours, but that isn't me.
Lastly, and my biggest complaint, is that the combat is horrible.

I can't overstate how bad the combat is. I am playing as a mage and I can dump my entire mana bar and not kill one enemy sometimes. Maybe I am not using the right spell, but I wouldn't know because there is little to no information on anything in the game. Is 10 damage a lot? 50?

Again, if you are looking for a world to live in, this game is it. Probably has depth for days, but I want to relax for an hour here and there and this is not the game for that.

Lastly, the game freezes and crashes somewhat frequently. I am playing on linux via proton, so this might not be the case for windows.

I was born 87 years ago. For 65 years I've ruled as Tamriel's Emperor. But for all these years I have never been the ruler of my own dreams. I have seen the Gates of Oblivion, beyond which no waking eye may see. Behold, in Darkness a Doom sweeps the land. This is the 27th of Last Seed; the Year of Akatosh 433. These are the closing days of the 3rd Era, and the final hours of my life.

Hundreds of hours of gameplay, a rich world to explore, I played this after playing skyrim for the first time. All the things I found tedious about skyrim were so much better in oblivion. The world is so much richer, more beautiful, there are more things to do and consequences feel so much more real. 
I accidentally became a vampire at one point, the condition progressed and got worse over time as I refused to drink blood, to the point where I could only spend about a minute outside before dying and the challenge of dealing with this with travelling was gruelling and rewarding. I travelled at night hoping to find a tomb or inn to sleep at during the day as I crossed the country and I faced stigma from townspeople who could tell that something was wrong with me. Many times I lost track of the hours and found myself spamming healing spells and eating my whole inventory as i tried desperately to make it to the next land mark only to find it was filled with bandits meaning I had to battle in my weakened state before I could finally rest. 

This is just one example of how this game is challenging in a way that few rpgs are now days. 
It is far superior to skyrim. 
I wasn't expecting to enjoy a game that was over 12 years old so much but oblivion remains in my top 5 games even 2 years later.

Epic and nostalgic. 
Replaying it in 2023 is obviously not the same experience as it was when I was 14 in 2008, but it still holds up in a lot of ways. The game was praised so highly for its graphics when it came out, and while they don't hold up to today's standards you can still appreciate the warmth and creativity. In the modern landscape of graphics everything is hyper realistic and honestly that just makes it all feel the same. There was a certain dawning age charm and mystique that these older games had which current developers cannot reproduce.

"BuT sKyRiM hAs BeTtEr GrApHiCs" Oblivion is, in my opinion, the best Elder Scrolls game to just sit and play. The leveling system is my absolute favorite, and you're not forced into using the same 3 archetypes. The mixing and matching is incredible. Also, the botched voice lines? Impeccable. The world is so detailed (granted it is an older engine) but still is functional and there are so many little things to find. I also love the Daedric Prince quests compared to Oblivion, but that's personal taste. Also, it seems the quest lines are longer and there are little additional things you can do during the quests (such as in the dark brotherhood story line to increase gold received) that honestly make it super enjoyable.

thanks to the wonderful modding community behind this game, it still holds up even in 2023. i did a rough version of the bevilex mod suggestions, totaling with somewhere around 150 mods. Due to the mods, i do have some instability, about every 40 minutes or so when i go through a loading screen, my game crashes. while obviously annoying, it hasnt been too big of deal because ive been saving before i go through loading screens now (100% because of the crashing, not a gameplay thing) Modding it was my own choice and stability is something your always risking with modding, so i cant fault the game itself.
Story Wise so far its been amazing. Im about half way through, done tons of side quests, finished some factions, started the other faction quests, explored probably 60ish% of the map in depth, and my impression so far is that its much more in depth than say fallout 4 or skyrim. 
Quest wise, the Faction storylines feel significantly longer, with better writing. they made me actually feel like i earn my way through the guilds, compared to skyrim where you dont really get ranks or anything, just eventually your always the leader. 
You actually pick a class like a traditional RPG. you can build your character in ways that you really regret in late game, or make the game a breeze based on character creation.
i really enjoy having magic as a separate slot than using one of my hands like skyrim. it makes battlemage builds way more fun, and its just another tool that you can access any time. i feel skyrim took this away because of dragon shouts, but i really hope it comes back for ES6.
Even though im really loving the game and would recommend it to anybody, id be lying if if it said it was perfect. 
Its an old game, while the world is still beautiful, especially with mods, and the gameplay is great and great story telling, holy cow do they have some ugly looking NPCS. like, all of them are absolutely terrible. Guards are way too aggresive, somehow every single guard in all of cyrodill knows when i accidentally go in somebodies inventory because i tried to talk while in sneak mode. 
Overall its awesome, and made me excited to go back to play morrowind

For such a low price as well, it's an amazing pick for something to play.

Though it has its problems mechanically Its still a fun game despite its age, it holds up very well for its age, with a slight bit of modding you can make your experience with this game truly special and relatively modernized, though most mods arent really necessary, mods to fix the leveling system bonuses *are* essentially necessary unless you want to micromanage your character (I would also recommend a mod to up the total damage given/taken because by default everyone in the game including you is a damage sponge). Oblivion by default gets more difficult when you level up, enemies become more spongy and if you do not micromanage or mod the attribute bonuses you will quickly become outclassed. If youre coming from Skyrim or even any of the 3d fallout games, switching to oblivion can absolutely be jarring, however if youre able to stick around for one reason or another oblivion really is an amazing game worth putting some time into. 

(Personally while I still do prefer the general gameplay of skyrim, there are absolutely aspects of oblivion that are far better than skyrims counterparts, the biggest being that many of the storylines within oblivion are deeper and more well thought out.)

More accessible than Morrowind and with better writing than Skyrim, this game is an absolute masterpiece. Saving the world from one daedroth in the base game and serving a daedroth in the DLC, you experience everything the province of Cyrodiil has to offer. The spellmaking and enchanting systems are heavily customizable but not too complex, and things like 100% Chameleon put the game on easy mode. The occasional glitches can be easily resolved with console solutions found on UESP, and the occasional crashes can have their damage mitigated by frequent saving. The province of Cyrodiil is filled to the brim with absolutely monstrous threats, but careful planning and thorough preparation will save your life every time. Make suitable potions, craft spells appropriate to the situation, have a few different sets of enchanted armor for various situations, use detection spells to see threats before they notice you, and you'll be absolutely invincible. Oh, and the Dark Brotherhood questline is absolutely metal - you should set some time aside just to play that through in one sitting.

Behold, after dwelling within the archaic Imperial prison, I have located a manuscript from the previous captive of this insidious dungeon. A philosophical piece that traverses through the rather deranged mind of a Redguard. A tome of utmost significance that depicts this Redguards tales of woe under the captivity of the SAESNEG ELDERS. Undoubtedly, the torment he endured in a Redguard household was unparalleled and as a result he fell into a bout of perpetual insanity, concocting dance routines that only the unhinged and naively aloof would willingly enact. 

Diary Excerpts of Goblin Amir – Inexplicably the dates of this Redguards scrawling’s are blurred with a peculiar black smudge, perhaps charcoal or an Redguards tainted darkspawn blood, leaving the timeline ambiguous and faded beyond all recognition. 

“I used to perform the little lads dance back in my youth you know. Berries and cream. Berries and cream. I fondly remember the dish best served upon a marble platter.”

“Berries and cream. Berries and cream. I was innocent once you know, a free range sunflower, whose fire had yet to be stoked and then I was trod upon by two Imperial children who were running amok in their corpulent fathers vineyards. It was then that I was reincarnated as a child in a depraved, conventional Redguard household. Berries and cream, oh how I yearn for berries and cream. Since entering into this world as a vessel anew, I have been tormented incessantly, ruthlessly coerced into participating in Redguard rituals to polymorph into caricatures of Eldritch Daemonspawn. Gradually, my boyish charms and golden locks faded, replaced with what would be gnarled limbs, furtive eyes, and a traditional cokney smile, alongside other more disdainful Redguardian features. Initially I was vehemently opposed to performing that berry dance for my captives amusement, albeit I soon changed my mind after being beaten with a hot poker and coerced into performing sexual acts with my female siblings, under the scrutiny of a camera lens, in exchange for the promise of newfound literature to sate my thirst for knowledge. Inevitably as a result of my endless oppression I relented, capitulating to the whims of my non pious, hedonistic Redguard parents. Gradually feelings of Stockholm syndrome began to set in, distorting my perception of the world and placing the acts of debauchery I committed in a more auspicious light. It was thus that my transformation was complete, I had finally polymorphed into a full blooded Redguard. I would now willingly dance as a puppet on a string for my sustenance, just as my enslaved forebearers had done. Go on onlookers, GO ON crimson cloaked fowls, whip me, make me dance, make me serenade the ballad of my ancestors! BERRIES AND CREAM. BERRIES AND CREAM, I DEMAND MY VITTLES.”

“I tried to kill them you know, I ATTEMPTED TIME AND TIME AGAIN TO SKEWER THEM WITH A PRONGED FORK, ATTEMPTING TO FIGHT BACK AND RECLAIM MY SENTIENCE, IT WASN’T MY FAULT. I DIDN’T ASK FOR THIS! On many occasions did I attempt to utilize cyanide as an alternative for pancake mix. On every second day I attempted to spoon feed my relatives crystalized arsenic, assuring them that what they were gorging their piggy little mouths upon was in fact sugar cubes. I even attempted to brain my sister with a mallet on one misty morn. But nay, despite my valiant efforts they remained alive, robust and formidable in an otherwise demented vessel. They were the embodiment of Achilles, an immortal behemoth ready to cut a swath of temptation and decadence along the cracks of our society, carving their ominous incantations along the walls and hurling excrement at any who appear relatively hinged and exuding a carefree air, insinuating that they were free from the Redguard menace. I WILL SOAR THROUGH THE SKIES AS POLLEN, I WILL RESIST ONCE MORE AND ELUDE THE MADNESS THAT PRIOR ENVELOPED AND ENGULFED MY INNER BEING. IT IS TIME TO RIDE FORTH, NO MORE WILL THE SAESNEG TORMENT THEIR YOUTH, THEY WILL RUE THIS DAY WHEN FIRE AND BRIMSTONE RAIN DOWN UPON THEM.” 

“I’m at my wits end; I’m going to hasten the speed of reincarnation and polymorph into a sunflower again. That’s why I have this here hole and am currently in the process of planting myself. I shall become a sapling anew, reborn as a noble herb that will genuinely contribute to society, more than any REDGUARD could have. Oh Norns, Duna, Vraccas, SHOR, THE NINE above, grant me my earnest wish, send forth a radiant light from the heavens and transmute my body and soul into that of an altruistic and carefree sunflower. I wish for my petals to become sandstone, an alluring smile and countenance fair and to be deeply nestled into nature’s most serene of soils. Give me the power O’lord, ensure that these tears I have grieved over the years have not been for naught. AH YES, I CAN FEEL IT, THE POWER COURSING THROUGH MY PAIN WRACKED BODY. The lord wishes for me to gorge myself on soil, only then can I enter the state of entrancement necessary to morph my appendages into roots and my cranium into a bedazzling flower. IT IS TIME TO DINE ON THE LAND, THE SOIL IS THE FOUNDATION OF OUR SOCIETY AND AS SUCH WE MUST PAY IT PROPER HEED. Tonight, I dine on victuals and emerge reborn as a radiant, scarlet winged phoenix.

I wouldn't dream of having this game any less broken and stupid than it is. yes, at 250 hours there's a bug that makes the game unplayable but I still got 250 hours of enjoyment out of it. I probably would've finished everything had I run everywhere instead of walking everywhere, getting into my character, feeding them when I think they should be hungry and getting the recommended amount of sleep. 

Being in this world is just a pleasure to me. Admiring the 2006 high fantasy landscapes and cities that don't look a year under 20. And chatting up every ugly mug I see because I know they'll have something entertaining to say. I just can't help but take my time with it and complete everything I can in one city to let my excitement build up for the next one. I love them all but Bravil doesn't really compare to the others. That place is a colorless ****hole but it still has great quests.

The only part of this game that I probably should've felt less compelled to fixate on is dungeons. The caves were my favorite part of this game growing up and I really don't get it. I think it was just some childhood fascination with real caves but they're pretty boring most of the time and when I got the means, I usually just used turbostealth to literally push past every enemy. Not even doing these dungeons would've been the right call and it's especially true for Oblivion gates. I remembered loving them as a kid and on return, I did for a while but there's like, 100 gates in the world and around 6 Oblivion dungeon layouts that any of these 100 gates can lead to, making them all mind numbingly repetitive.

Whatever though, just don't shoot yourself in the foot like me and focus only on doing quests for people. Forget about the caves and I think this becomes one of the funniest and most enjoyable gaming experiences I've ever had, despite the indisputable lack of quality or consideration in just about every one of the game's core elements. Seriously, look up a video of how redonculous the leveling in this game is. It's comical but I don't feel like explaining it

Highly Recommend getting this game. 

The short version : 
This game is worth buying. There is so much to do in a really nice world to explore. Magic or brute force or use both as you explore the world and uncover quests. 
Do you want to save the world? then can do the main quest, do you want to be a wanderer instead? then just wander the land this game does not force you to do what it wants. Instead it says 'hey heres a big land go live in it' .

The not short version : 
You start off as a prisoner not knowing why you are there.
 About a minute into your cell time and the king visits you! 
And everybody is like 'what you doing here this cell is not meant to be used a cell...' 
Shortly after this you got some dungeon delving to do and learn how to swing a sword, fire an arrow, cast a spell, loot dead people and then after this dungeon bit you are set loose on the open world. 

This world is beautiful really rich with lots of countryside and lots of lakes/ponds to explore too. 
Which as you explore will reveal mines and dungeons and forgotten overgrown forts filled with monsters and loot. 
The difficulty can be set to whatever you wish which means if monsters get a little tough you can lower it and build up your skills a bit more and get better spells/equipment and overcome them in your own time or you can do the opposite and put the difficulty up to suit your own experience.

If you would like a little bit of direction but don't want to do the main quest there are guilds which will help you explore with purpose.
Currently I am playing in both the thieves guild and magic guild and being bit of a wanderer.
You will find these guilds very easily the mages guild has guild houses in each city and the thieves guild can be found in the poorer area 'waterfront' of the imperial city. 
There are other guilds and you can discover them yourselves (I don't want to give spoilers).
Advantage of the Thieves Guild is you can sell any stolen items to the guild and they will give you quests too. 
 - If you are sneaking about someones house stealing their stuff I suggest not to wear your big heavy iron armour gear instead wear something like leather armour that helps you be more quiet. 
Advantage of the Mages Guild is you can learn to create spells and enchant weapons and armour and get given quests to do too.
- Don't steal from Mages if your in the Mage guild.


What I really like about this game is the setting and playing it just makes the day feel better going out in the countryside or visiting a quaint village/town. 
You are encouraged to pick plants and these can be used to make potions and the more you do the better you get. Rarely have i ever rolled my eyes at not having enough money to buy something I want. I can go out into the world and find monsters/dungeons to loot and make potions to sell or go on bit of a thieving spree through a town and sell to get money.

The first main purchase I encourage you to get as soon as possible is the shack on the waterfront you need 2000 gold to get the basic shack which includes containers to store your valuables. 
I would make this the first priority of your game. It seems a little steep getting 2000 gold but it will help you learn and grow as a character. 
There are quests that can help you on your way to that 2000 gold too. 
Explore the city shops and you will find the Commerce building to buy the shack. 
There are other houses to buy in different towns you will find these in your own time and all can be decorated and have more containers/cupboards and furniture bought for them. As you acquire more mementos like weapons and armour or books and trinkets this helps organise the hoarded loot you might not want to sell. One goal of mine is to own a copy of every book in the game - and every book can be read in game too!

There are downsides to this game but not many. I would recommend saving often which is not hard to do. 
Sometimes the peoples voices can be a bit samey.
I would like to be able to make friends with some monsters rather than just go and batter them with an axe - but there are spells that can help calm them.
There is a bard class but its not like you can be a bard and sing your way through enemies its about your stats not a roleplaying style.
I would have liked to be able to build an army and conquer all the towns/city and impose my own rule upon the happy folk.
Its not that kind of game though instead you can become head of different Guilds and lord it over your peers. 

There is lots to explore, to do, to steal, to kill, to learn and you can do it all in your own time. It is easy to get sidetracked as you talk to the inhabitants of the game you may find more quests or learn of another mine to seek out and this helps break any feeling of missing out on something when being able to do things in your own time.

To sum up before i ramble on about everything in the game and lose the next several hours to writing...
Highly Recommended to get.

[h1]The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion® Game of the Year Edition[/h1]
The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion® Game of the Year Edition is the fourth part of the series, this time taking us to Cyrodiil; the heart of the Empire in times of greatest crisis on the continent.
[h1]The Plot[/h1]
We play here as the Champion of Cyrodiil; a hero chosen by the Emperor himself to, together with other important characters, save the world. It's not a very fresh concept, but the game mixes many interesting quests (which we can approach in different ways), that the plot definitely deviates from the norm in some parts. The characters are interesting, and even though most of them have the same voice actor, they have enough different personalities to be interested in them. The best character is of course Martin, played by Sean Bean (who of course eventually dies, afterall, he is Sean Bean, the master in art of dying). If I were to briefly describe the plot, I would assign it to the category of more fun to experience, but not as fun to think about. Perhaps the best aspect of it is the ending itself, where we fight in the streets of the Imperial City, against demons and the main villain, but every time I play it seems to me that it is also a very wasted part. Apart from the destruction around us, we do nothing but run from door to door, and this happens in the space of maybe one minute. I think Sean Bean's death sequence itself is twice as long. Apart from that, the game also includes the Shivering Isles story DLC which is really solid and it focuses on the madness in people's hearts. Each character acts like a TikTok user after a few minutes of not getting massive doses of dopamine into what's left of their brains. So yes, madness and mania are cranked up to the max.
[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Starting with the character creator, it is good, maybe even too good, but in a bad way. We have so many options, that we can create a Fallout mutant very easily, and since apparently Bethesda employees have never seen a real human in their lives, the characters look like stretched-out mannequins from the start, so creating a good-looking character is an almost impossible task. Moving on to the basics, there's a lot of cool armors and weapons, and a lot of it is given as rewards for completing some really cool side quests. Unlike Skyrim, a shockingly large number of these quests have interesting dialogues, interesting locations (the map itself has a lot of such locations, and although they are sometimes repeated, exploring a very large map is very exciting and interesting), not to mention interesting characters and enemies. There are, of course, typical fetch quests here, but they are not as painful as in the next game of the series. It is also worth mentioning that at the beginning of our adventure, we can create our own character class, so it allows for many possibilities in modifying our skills / attributes at the start. It doesn't matter much in the long run, but it's an interesting concept. Before I end this segment, I need to mention "difficulty levels", if I can even call them that. It's basically a bar that, when moved to the right, makes the game harder. Exciting as fuck. We have no idea how difficult or easy the game will become, at the highest "difficult settings" the game is not difficult, it's tiring. Enemies of (any kind) become sponges for damage, our armor turns to cardboard so we can die from a stronger gust of wind, and our weapons are so painfully weak, that it's like we're slapping someone with swimming pool noodles. Bethesda simply can't create effective difficulty levels for their games.
[h1]Technical Matters[/h1]
Although the game has its moments, let's face it, graphically it is terrible, especially when we talk about details and character design. At least the game never kicked me to the desktop. Speaking of bugs, there are a lot of them, but they are of the "very funny, not annoying" type. At times this game turns into pure comedy, and the very wooden animations are the icing on the cake. But it was the dialogues that made me laugh the most, as I said before, Bethesda had very few voice actors, so to make each character as original as possible, they had to improvise, so the voice actors often put their dialogue in very funny tones of voice, making the characters sound like they were going through a very aggressive voice mutation. This game is similar to the Star Wars Prequels in that aspect, there are so many memes and weird dialogues, that I just can't take it all seriously. I would also like to mention the music, which is great. Each piece is really well done, and it adds a lot of atmosphere to the locations. But at the end, nothing beats the music/theme from the main menu.
[h1]Summary[/h1]
A very good game that was a really great phenomenon in its day, however, it has not aged well, and this title definitely needs a remake. There is a lot of potential here for a really great game that can compete and even beat the current quality of games on the market. I've heard rumors that Bethesda has plans for an Oblivion remake, but it hasn't been confirmed. I'm also looking forward to Skyblivion, a fan project porting the game to the Skyrim engine, complete with existing and original mods, textures, assets, etc. I'm really interested in the future of TES: Oblivion, and I hope Bethesda doesn't ruin this opportunity to resurrect the classic.
