NOTE: I only have 60 hours on here, but I bought the game when it was new and before Steam existed. I must have at least 1000 hours into this game, and I bought it three times.

This is one of the most awesome games and at the same time one of the most broken games I have ever played.
Broken, not in the sense that it is buggy. In fact it runs almost perfectly, especially this edition with all the release bugs worked out.

What I mean is that while playing the game "normally" is loads of fun, the objectively best, most effective way is to play it totally wrong.
This was the first time Bethesda pioneered an adaptive level system, meaning that enemies are always as powerful as you. That means that if you choose all the spells as class skills but make your main attribute strength and endurance, then focus only on swords, you will only face imps and goblins your entire game.
Funny exploits like this are everywhere in Oblivion, but in the end if you want it to be easy just turn the "difficulty" slider all the way down. That way it will be easy without you making a fool of your character. :)

One thing I truly love is that you can choose to not start the main story. In fact, Oblivion is almost two games:
Play the main story, and Gates pop up everywhere, demons swarm out, and you get challenging dungeons filled with gore and epic loot.
Don't start the story, and no Gates, no Demons, but instead the landscape is unscarred and you see Cyrodiil in all its perfect beauty. 
You can even complete all the side quests, buy a bunch of houses, become master of all guilds, and only THEN start the main quest. If you do that, it will be very different indeed since the enemies match your level.

This is JUST the story, I'm not even getting into the many ways to play the game itself.
You can be a sword-master without peer, an bow-wielding stealthy assassin, even beat enemies with your fists.
Focus on one element to defeat your foes, or focus on all three. Or use magic in a more subtle way to enhance your abilities, convince people to fight you in crowded areas to avoid getting charged, turn invisible to walk right past a cave full of bandits, even goad enemies into fighting each other so you don't have to!
And best of all, you will probably end up doing ALL OF THE ABOVE since there are no classes. Given enough time, you can be a master of all things.

All paths lead to victory, in the amazingly weird world of Oblivion!
As of now i would recommend. Not to much of a step down from skyrim and still runs quite well on modern hardware. ( I have GOTY deluxe so can't speak for og version )
I have been playing this game since I was three and have been playing it since. First, I got it for ps3, then xbox 360, then xbox 1, then ps4, and now pc.

Oblivion is one of the best writen and most memorable RPGs to ever come out (except for maybe new vegas) and an enormous far cry from the awful pulp that is skyrim. 

I can guarentee that you will never forget the dark brotherhood or the thieves guild after you experience them and those are just the cream of the crop, the game is loaded with a lot of pretty original and memorable quests that each tell their own little stories ranging from comedy to drama that a surpising ammount of involve no combat at all, relying more on investigation, dialogue or stealth which makes them all the more fun because they can focus on the story instead of the fighting.

And the characters themselves are also amazing, the entire arena crew is so well writen, likable and dripping with personality, its impossible to not have Owyn grow on you after you grow on him and there isn't a person in the world that will ever forget Lucien Lachance from the brotherhood. 

And who can forget the shivering isles, bethesda's take on alice in wonderland that in of itself is so good it blows the entire base game out of the water and is imo one of the best expansions for any game ever, amazing narrative, characters and enviroments. Betwen oblivion and the shivering isles its guarenteed there's gonna be several quests/areas you end up loving even if you dislike the rest, everyone should experience this game, definitely recommend especially for how cheap it is.

~~~ Childhood experience ~~~
TES IV: Oblivion (2006) was the very first game of the Elder Scrolls series I ever played, and it quickly became one of my most favourite video games of all time. My brother had built a brand new custom computer and allowed me to sometimes play games of his collection - this game was one of them.

As a young child, I was first presented with the character creation screen - which was a new concept to me at the time. Whilst it was basic, it was nice to design my very own character and choose a race. The opening story line, with it's characters, voiced dialogue, and combat, was very interesting indeed. It was a rewarding achievement to finally escape the Imperial prison. I was quickly thrown to explore this vast 'alien world', which I knew nothing about. I did not understand the game's mechanics and had no knowledge of actual Elder Scrolls lore, but I was drawn from the start.

As a kid, I found the game very difficult and the combat very challenging, so I actually tried avoiding combat as much as possible. I did not know about the 'wait' feature - which replenishes the player's health. My main fixations at the time was exploring the vast world and completing the various quests throughout the world. It was a lot of fun!

~~~Adult Play~~~
As I got older, my game knowledge rapidly grew. I began to understand the game's features a lot better and starting to understand how challenging the vanilla's levelling system could be. By now, I knew the major vanilla quests ever so well. My favourite quests were the side miscellaneous quests. It was very rare that I would advance far throughout the main quest line.

The longer the videogame had been out, the more available guides, articles, and tutorials, became available on the internet. It was online articles and guides, as well as YouTube tutorials, which helped me fine tune the game to suit my own personal preference and liking. This helped enhance the game play and improve the sustainability and performance of the game it's self.

~~~Essential Mods~~~
The game's frequent crashes and bugs would sometime frustrate me beyond belief. I absolutely loved the game to bits, but hated the issues it was shipped with. Thankfully, I discovered different fan made MODs. Early MODs that I used just involved the Unofficial Patches, but it was later on where I would start to form even more advanced MOD lists with both 'essential MODs' - such as bug fixes - and 'additional MODs' - like better textures and companion NPCs.

~~~Personal MOD List~~~
Today I use Mod Organizer 2 (MO2), but have installed MODs manually. I have also used Wyre Bash in the past, as well as Vortex and Oblivion Mod Manager (OMM). By far, Mod Organizer 2 is my most favourite MOD manager utility, with built-in LOOT (Load Order Optimisation Tool). With TES IV: Oblivion, there are MODs which are essential - needed for everyone, and MODs which are additional extras - such as Kvatch Rebuilt MOD.

I have my very own custom MOD list here with some of the best community MODs ever released - https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3014674020

Despite the goofy memes, Oblivion has better vanilla content than its successor, better quests and better faction quests, quest have more weight here than Skyrim's because most of the side quests are actually failable and you will get punished by not earning a reward or getting an reputation hit, also the disposition system is a VERY rewarding tool if used right, you can befriend anyone if you have high personality and acquire information and pass quests that would be otherwise a hassle in an astonishing easy way. Sadly it has not appealing visuals (not even back in the day had) so people tend to ignore it just because of the graphics and "ugliness" despite being an excellent game. Mods such as OCOv2 can fix the NPC's visuals and blessed walking can implement the missing diagonal walking/run in 3rd person. Those two mod and their dependencies don't require wrye bash to be used, which is other reason people avoid Oblivion because most of the good mods under the sun require wrye bash to use and modders "gatekeep" people with tiring and long explanations and 3 hours essays of how wrye bash works and their impacts in the economics of yugoslavia or smth instead of saying "right click on the bashed_patch.esp and click 'build patch' and agree with whatever wrye bash recommends and if does not work, see the tutorials and the essays". One thing to be considered is this game is WAY more unstable that Skyrim and crashes randomly, so ALWAYS REMEMBER TO SAVE. 

One thing i forgot to say: The dungeon design is AWFUL, some areas are inaccessible without high level acrobatics in badlands and the dungeons in general are too look alike and does not circle (boss room  close to the entrance) like in Skyrim, which every dungeon is recognizable.

I cannot be objective, for my love is unconditional. This is my most favorite game of all time.
It has aged poorly in almost every way possible, and mechanically speaking it's objectively not good at all by 202X standards, but some parts, like the world itself, the writing, the exploration and the stories you can create for yourself have aged like fine wine.
A friend introduced me to the game when I was 8 years old, and I've sunk a LOT more time in it that the Steam hours counter shows.

You will definitely have to mod it at least slightly in order to make it less dated - I suggest something like Realistic/Ultimate Levelling to fix the broken level up system, and something else to combat scaling. The combat is quirky and weird, but you can get used to it and mess motherf#ckers up. The graphics are dated, too, and you will probably want to use OCO, unless you find humor in the absolute abominations that Oblivion facegen is known for. However, the dated graphics give the scenery this watercolor aesthetic, and I've not seen a game replicate the mix of styles quite as well as this game. The music is fantastic, and Jeremy Soule is a genius.

The main reason to play this game is the Cyrodiil. You'll get lost in the forests and dungeons and find thousands of interesting stories. It's not a fetch quest nightmare like Skyrim, being closer to Morrowind in terms of short, interesting stories within quests. The Guilds, the Dark Brotherhood, the Shivering Isles and the Daedric shrines provide fantastic plots that never get old, while the towns and villages provide extensive replay value. You'll always find something new when coming back to this game - something funny, mysterious or interesting; even if you've seen it all, there's not enough space in the brain to remember it all. I'm still SO far from having seen it all, though after 15-ish years. It's knowing there are still things left unseen, the small things, that make it even more interesting to come back to - like finding a dead troll under a bridge with a sad suicide note.

It's definitely not a perfect game. In fact, it's kind of a sh1t game in %current_year%, but to me, it's still the best game of all time. If you're a modern gaming snob, or if you're scared of dated mechanics and can't stand the lack of feedback in combat, you might just hate it, but if you're looking for an endless supply of interesting stories set in an excellent world (while being tolerant to some mild jank), you have to buy this game.

I have no idea why it has taken me so long to write a review for this game but better late than never and this game DESERVES it.

This is literally my favorite game of all-time. Always has been ever since I first stepped foot into Cyrodiil back in 2006 as a mere 8 year old. Had the old PC box set and everything. Had the DLC boxes as well. At the time, I just hijacked my dad's character and murdered everyone I came across haha. But when I made my own character, I began to appreciate and enjoy the world and quests for what they were, even as a kid. This was the first game that I truly fell in love with. 

Ever since then, I have played through it multiple times with different and unique builds. And every time I play, I found something new that makes me appreciate the game even more. It has the usual Bethesda jank and bugs but honestly it servers to actually improve the game experience to me. It has its own charm of being a buggy, jank, meme game and I love it. This is largely due to the laughable AI that is honestly just terrible, but in a good way. I would best describe the AI as a Neil Breen film (if you know, you know). 

While the main quest line is solid, the true highlight of this game are the side quests. Many of them are so memorable that there are some I haven't done in 17 years, and I still remember them. The guilds are very guild too. I find the fighter's guild to be somewhat weak here, but the mage's guild is great! The dark brotherhood and thieves' guild are just in another league though. They are absolutely stellar. I would recommend playing the games just for those two quest lines alone. The arena is a very unique experience as well and very fun! Especially the reward you get for competing it *wink wink*. 

The world and cities are also incredible. The region is very diverse with the snowy mountains that border Skyrim to the north, to the swamps in the south, and the massive forests with lakes/rivers in between. The Imperial City is an amazing area teaming with things to do and places to explore with many interesting NPCs to talk to. Other personal highlights include Skingrad, Bruma, and Bravil. I feel like each city has a myriad of unique side quests that will have you remembering that particular place for a long time. The DLCs is also incredible, both of them. The Shivering Isles is often regarded as one of the best DLCs ever made.

There are many weapons and builds that you can use as well. This game is much more of an RPG than skyrim. You can even make/name your own class here! My personal favorite is the sword/board or a greathammer. I also enjoy being an archer! Magic is very potent in this game as well, so if you enjoy playing a mage then you'll have a good time here.

All in all, this game is an absolute must-play for anyone who enjoys anything resembling an RPG. I have said this for years and I'll say it again, I have never met anyone who has played both Skyrim and Oblivion and preferred Skyrim. I love Skyrim, but this game just hits different.

This game is truly Todd "Godd" Howard's best work. Play it!

[h1] The flawed masterpiece. [/h1]

An ungodly amount of fetch quests, a broken leveling system, cheesy NPC dialogue/main quest, absolutely retarded AI pathfinding, all coupled with the tech limitations of a 2006 release.

And yet, none of these issues have put me off from investing a second 60 hours into a near-completion playthrough. Not one alchemical ingredient, not one dungeon, not one quest item was one too many, and all this without a single mod. No, one cannot simply put this game down once one has become an apprentice of the ancient school of console commands. It is true that, though some frown upon this forbidden practice, it has long tainted many an honest playthrough, whether that be due to poor save management or game-breaking bugs. And this author, indeed, is no stranger to such putrid chicanery. 

But let us not dwell on the foul stench of apathy, for the world of Cyrodiil commands a charm about it so enchanting, you will lose yourself at once in its vast and epic world, wherein every rock, hill, tree, lake, river, cavern, mountain, beachside, creek, and tree stump were put into the game with intent and careful thought. Not one corner of Central Tamriel has been left untouched, and even in 2023 it remains an impressive feat by the developers.

Of course, one of the most impressive and renowned features in these games is the player’s ability to open nearly every door in the entire world. Once you enter a city, make your way to a village, or spot an inconspicuous shed in the middle of the woods, all it takes is a lockpick and a bit of skill, and you’re inside a [b] fully furbished [/b] room, often with a dedicated NPC and an occasional quest item such as a note or valuable loot. This level of freedom is what I have sought in video games ever since playing Vice City for the first time eight years ago.

The other aspect at which these games excel is the lore. The hundreds of books in each game provide a staggering amount of background as to what the hell is even going on. Who is Uriel Septim? Why are the Daedra invading Tamriel? Who built the White-Gold Tower, and what are these ancient ruins scattered all over Cyrodiil? All these questions can be answered within a quick visit to the book store, or even by searching through a random NPC’s living room. And, of course, the in-game fiction praising one race and disparaging another in order to establish the politics of Nirn will never cease to amaze with its unwavering continuity.

Since I have already outlined my biggest gripes with the game in the first paragraph, I’ll just mention the occasional monotony of going into a dungeon, slaying a dozen or so creatures, and lockpicking a chest to retrieve a badass weapon or some other quest-related item. It’s definitely fun the first couple of times, but by dungeon number thirty-five, the mechanic certainly overstays its welcome. I’m not even going to mention Oblivion gates, as I had to enter no more than ten (compared to the 100 that spawn throughout the game) for the entirety of the main quest line. The previous and next games in the series did dungeons a lot better in my opinion.

[i] So come for the action and stay for the lore in this ancient realm of arcane cults and mighty warriors, the resting place of kingdoms of old and the cradle of change, all unified by the Glorious Empire!

8/10 [/i]

I played this game when it first came out on my Xbox 360 and fell in love with the setting, story, characters and gameplay. Over the years, I've tried this game also on PS3. The sole reason for my purchasing it finally on PC is because I discovered there were quests that didn't appear on the other platforms. I am so glad I switched to PC.

The game runs really well and the textures are gorgeous. As someone used to playing on console, the PC controls feel really smooth, although took me a little time to get used to. There's been no lag at all. And I can also play with mods!

I don't care if it's getting towards 20 years old; it has aged so well.  And I know there's the whole Skyrim vs. Oblivion vs. Morrowind argument out there that will never end, but Oblivion was the one that got me into Elder Scrolls in the first place, so it'll always hold that special place in my heart.

Definitely recommend, even with all the hilariously infamous bugs.

The game is very solid, although has some significant nuances. 
The gameplay is mostly very fun. Combat (unlike Morrowind) is more satisfying and although it isn't anything spectacular like in other first person games, it serves the task well for the scope of this game, being a vast role playing open world game with tons of things to do. However, my biggest complaint with the game is Auto-leveling, and Dungeons. Auto leveling results in the strength of enemies accelerating faster than yours, not slower, meaning that eventually, they become health sponges. Mods somewhat aliviate that, but not fully from my experience. Dungeons are also kind of bland. Not much variation, and much backtracking back to the entrance. Probably as a result from only *one* person working on the dungeons.
Beside those 2 gameplay nuances, the game doesn't have any other significant downsides. The narrative is somewhat decent, and like combat, serves the job well *enough*. But the side quests and the atmosphere are just phenomenal. While the game's looks seem to be generic, the music isn't at all. Many side quests have clever twists and turns, and some offer interesting experiences, such as the quest of stealing an elder scroll.
Character creation and leveling are very complex that there are many different classes that can be creating, enhancing role playing and improving replayability.
All in all, just install some patch mods and a mod or two to fix up auto-leveling, and maybe add some QOL features, and you will have a very fun experience.

If you've only ever played Skyrim, this game can be hard to get into, but man does it grab you. The sheer freedom this game gives you and its multitude of more complex RPG systems gives it a level of depth that Skyrim lost for the sake of new, more casual players. Dialogue is more varied and complex, there's a haggling and persuasion system, lockpicking is way harder, and you can make custom spells. This game has some drawbacks, its melee combat is floaty and many enemies are extremely spongey. The many dungeons this game offers are quiet bland and are hard to differentiate from one another, not to mention the graphics on the whole are pretty bad in the vanilla version of the game (although it's from 2007 so I don't hold this against it). There are a multitude of graphical mods and unofficial patches that can tidy up the edges of the game's aged nature.

Theory: The entire game takes place in a brush of Truepaint painting. I can explain how this is not only possible but more than likely.

1. The brush will paint whatever is in it's users imagination, if they are imagining photo-realism it will paint that imagined image.
2. When the 1st user (a descendant of Bravam Lythandas) stepped into the 1st painting he made he never left it, he only inhabits an imaginary version of the real world that fooled even himself perhaps.
3. Other people would (even if just by accident eventually) enter the painting with this 1st artist and could ever time become fooled or believe that they are free but they are not. These people and their decedents are who handed down the brush to it's owner when we find him.

If true this means the entire lore from the point the brush was created and 1st used by the descendants of Bravam is influenced by what that original artist might have thought about the world. How those ideas have grown on their own over the years as the brush users continue painting a painting inside a painting for fake clients thinking they are free is all we have. We know nothing about the "real" world of these games.

 As far as I know this is my idea, not sure if anyone else has realized this or not.

A sailing acquaintance reported rats on our sailboat. Significant damage to food containers, sundries and stores. To help make lemonade out of these rat lemons, I share my one-of-a-kind recipe for rat stew:

Ingredients:

1 rat trap

6 oz sharp cheddar cheese

One 12-oz can spinach

One bottle "cooking" skooma

1 box crackers, gnawed open

2 quarts water

One tbs olive oil

Pinch of salt

Set the trap, using a sliver of cheese. Bring water to a boil. Catch the rat and toss it into boiling water. Cover, reduce heat and simmer 30 minutes. Stir occasionally. Open spinach can, drain. Pour crackers into stew to thicken. Take salt and throw over your left shoulder. Rub olive oil in your hair. Eat the rest of the cheese, drink the skooma. Eat spinach out of can Popeye-style. Strain rat-water mixture into glass container (observing personal limit of two gallons fresh water daily), and use water to rinse hair and dishes. Pour the rat stew overboard. Feeds one mudcrab.

I've played Skyrim, Morrowwind, and now I'm working on Oblivion and I love it. Morrowwind was a bit too dated for me, but if you love the Elder Scrolls series you should give it try to see the evolution.

I was worried about the graphics going into this Oblivion. But from the very beginning and now 5+ hours in I'm not worried about that anymore. And I was sure to complete a few big quests before this review. 

The graphics are just fine and it doesn't detract from the game at all. Even more - In some places, while it remains obvious that Skyrim's "graphics" are far superior, you can actually argue that Obvlion is more visually appealing and more creative in many ways. And I'm saying that just 5 hours in, as I've played hundreds of hours in Skyrim. The architecture, layout, maps, etc of Oblivion are all very interesting. I could argue even a notch above Skyrim.

Regarding game play? It's practically just an earlier version of Skyrim with a different interface, and I actually much more preferred diving into this game. Skyrim is always a little tough at first, whereas with Oblivion I dove right in and didn't feel overwhelmed by anything.

Older graphics..., clunker interface..., sure. But a great game so far.

I have played this for the third time. Each time it plays well so long as I stayed within the general continent of Oblivion, however each time I get into the Shivering Isles I begin to have serious issues when I am about half way through. My first game through played to level 44 and became unplayable. The second quit at level 42 and this last stopped at level 37. The problem begins with a 'cloudy' effect around my character which in time makes it difficult to see. In my first play through it became impossible to see anything except periphery and the cloud effect. In the second game I came to a door which should have opened, but came open only half way. In each game it refused finally to load the last saved game and so ended any opportunity to go further. In my second game, I would save the game, but on trying to load the save later was told repeatedly the file was corrupted. Going back to a previous save which did work would not change the corrupted file behavior later. 


The game itself was fine, but no Skyrim. The player leveling system was limited, but I could deal with that. It seemed the game took a LOT of management which continually took me out of combat, etc. This is a good enough game for something different but I won't have any expectation of actually being able to play it through.  

OK. I have played this again after unchecking any gaming added in (Shivering Isles, etc.) to play only the basic game. I did not pay for any teaching and never fast traveled. At level 44 it began the 'cloudy effect' and after several minutes I was in a cave and the game just went away. I tried three times to load at the last save but it would not. I tried at the previous save and it would not load. The save prior to that did load, but to a significant loss of play time. Experience tells me the game will not play going forward and the game is finished. I did not get to do the Great Battle for Bruma, or any subsequent quests leading to the final battle at the Imperial City. For me, this is a game that is good enough to play for fun but the satisfaction of actually finishing it is not there at all. Too much time invested for what I get out of it.

I played this game on the Xbox 360 and enjoyed playing it again. This game is a broken mess of treasured moments, you probably have seen many many memes so far but let me tell you what others will not. This game has ALOT and I mean ALOT of dull and repeatable dungeons. Yes they may have a unique layout in one or two but because everything looks SO MUCH the same? You will find yourself lost or you will get frustrated. The missions main and sides are pretty fun but if you are looking for Skyrim level explore and find cool things? Another disappointment. The landscape is beautiful and still holds up really well but you will find really steep hills for no reason. Rocks that just dont make sense and lets face it Bruma looks like a homeless town. If you are looking for a unique experience then please follow the quests and side quests it really was an amazing game but just remember its OLD.

DO NOT BUY THIS GAME THROUGH STEAM!!!!  The operating systems that this game plays best on is no longer supported by Steam.  Buy your classic games through someone else, unless they decide to start supporting the OS's that they used to support

This game is a blast from the past.  This is arguably the best of the series due to the shear volume of story lines and stuff you can pull off in this game.

Negatives: 
#1 Steam no longer supports the operating systems that this game will work best on.  That means that it is a coin toss whether you will have a very buggy experience or an amazing one.
#2 your mods will need to be activated after you get out of the initial prison you are stuck in, otherwise the game will not launch properly.

Oblivion is, in my opinion, marred by mediocre, even poor, design decisions that feel more like a misguided over correction to Morrowind's apparent, and genuine, limitations and flaws, turning the game into a boring, at times meaninglessly frustrating, slog. Honestly, if I had to recommend anything about this game to anyone, it would be to only buy it so you can play the fan remake in like 2-3 years. This game as a whole is a disappointment, not because of some arbitrary idea of it showing its age, but because of simple poor design. Do not buy this game unless you are interested in the remake. Go buy Skyrim or Morrowind instead.

While Skyrim is a great game it was geared towards people who loved the series as well as people who had never played it and introduced a lot of features to help users who were not familiar with RPGs. 

Oblivions quests have a greater variety and seem much more plugged into the lore than Skyrim. 

Oblivion features many more skills and trees then the other iterations of elder scrolls games. Even jumping increases exp in a skill tree.

The game centers around the assassination of the king of cyrodil and his hier, a secret child whom has no idea of their heritage,
And the deadric princes of oblivion whom have begun an invasion of cyrodil through newly erected portals to the planes of oblivion that serve as their homes. 

The gameplay is fluid and exciting while also having many areas to explore and adventure,
A great deal of side quests and guilds to complete and join, a vast array of magical relics and items to obtain, a system for magic and many trees of combat skills including unarmed for pugilistic players. 

The final DLC for this game titled "The Shivering Isles" explores the realm of sheogorath the deadric prince of madness. It is arguably the best piece of elder scrolls content that exists to date. 

The graphics of this game have not aged well, but can be improved to modern standards through the use of nexus mods, and I highly recommend doing so. There is a great deal of interesting and game improving mods available for this title and they are extremely easy to implement using nexus mods manager or vortex mod manager. 

Overall I would say that oblivion has the best high fantasy feel of the elder scrolls series and is an extremely enjoyable game that has withstood the test of time. It has great replay value and can easily net you hundreds of hours of enjoyment with it's vast collection of nexus mods.

I was introduced to the Elder Scrolls series about 20 years ago when Morrowind came out. I was kinda young and didn't really get that far. But when Oblivion came out, I was absolutely addicted! I had this game on Xbox 360 originally and must have put in over a thousand hours into it. Then, when I switched to PC; I got it on disc version. Finally, I ended up getting it on Steam too. 

What can be said about this title for those who love Skyrim, but have never played Oblivion? The transition might be hard for you... The graphics are vastly outdated now (Heck, even Skyrim is), the combat system is very simplistic. The NPCs are absolutely ridiculous and can't be taken seriously... 

That being said... Oblivion is vastly superior to Skyrim in every other way. Let's take the mages guild as an example. In Skyrim, you join up with the college with next to no difficulty at all. Your first assignment is to go on a little field trip. On that first assignment, you uncover something that leads you on a small-ish journey. By the end of that journey, you become the Archmage for some reason... That's it. You're done... In Oblivion, you must travel across the entire province of Cyrodiil. You must visit every single chapter of the Mages guild, where you learn new spells, are imparted with wisdom and knowledge of all things magical and collect recommendations from all the chapter heads. Once you have been recommended by every single chapter, you are permitted to join the University. You are now an Apprentice! Your first task is to go collect wood and such to construct your first staff. You also now have access to creating your own spells (Amazing system!). Hooray, all those hours of travelling the province for those recommendations has paid off! But you're just an Apprentice... The journey is just beginning. You slowly carry out tasks for your master and rise the ranks, 1 by 1. You become more powerful and you get closer and closer to the top of that career ladder. Eventually, a big villain is introduced who could have easily been a villain of an entire game. You end up vanquishing him and saving the Mages Guild and rise to the esteemed rank of Archmage after proving yourself over time and time again. 

That is the difference between Skyrim and Oblivion. This same scenario is repeated for every single faction! I can't express how much I resented Skyrim for how crap the guild factions were... 

Anyway, the game is ridiculously cheap so if you can get past the outdated graphics, simplistic game mechanics and goofy NPCs... You'll find a gem in Oblivion!

The Elder Scrolls saga speaks for itself and Oblivion is no exception.

You'll find yourself in an open world rich with lore, people and locations ready for you to discover in any way you like. You can be certain that you'll find adventure anywhere you go. Even if you're lost walking through the wilderness, you'll probably end up helping a small village affected by a careless mage experiments.

As any gem, it has its flaws. It is of no mystery that Oblivion difficulty is a problem. Unlike Morrowind, the enemies level as you do, but unless you take care of the way you level up, your character will end up weak against most of the enemies you'll find. This can be dealt with, either through native gameplay or mods, but for a newcomer it can become tedious, so be prepared for this.

The community is still pretty much active, you can find plenty of content out there to improve the game as you desire and the expansion, Shivering Isles, is one of the best expansions in gaming.

One of my favorite games I've ever played, from the story to the character design, amazing. If you're looking for combat like skyrim and magic + an armor system like Morrowind this is simply the best of both worlds. I highly recommend this game to anyone.

Oblivion's core story and quests, in my opinion, surpass Skyrim in almost every possible way. There is far less "chosen one" nonsense, though sadly the game is not entirely free of this common Bethesda trope. The gameplay is also, in some respects, better: I prefer the game's approach to spells for example, because switching between a two handed sword and spells in Skyrim is far more cumbersome.

That being said, it definitely shows its age. The smaller cast of voice actors means that you can witness entire conversations playing out between two or three characters who sound the same. The animations are stiff. The models are severely deficient in detail. Even the Imperial City feels oddly small. And while modding the game can do a little for its looks, it's never going to hide that this game launched in 2006.

And then of course, there's the crashing. Especially with mods this game crashes very frequently, so be prepared to save extremely frequently.

The most egregious thing is that the game lists both a GOTY edition and GOTY "Deluxe" edition on Steam to this day. There is no way to upgrade from standard to Deluxe after buying one of them and most mod packs require the Deluxe, so be extremely careful when buying that you don't get the objectively inferior version. I also recommend buying the game on sale as its normal price is still rather high for such an old and in many ways broken game.

I'm enjoying myself with this one, for the most part, but I simply cannot recommend the game without the caveats that it is unstable, buggy and very much a product of its time.

This is one of those classic games that you look back on and realize, "gaming was a much different time back then." I actually really enjoyed Oblivion, especially because when I was a child I gave up pretty quickly so it was nice to actually do most of what the game had to offer. Now, this game has a ton of flaws, no doubt. The leveling system is very complicated, despite being a very interesting take. The scaling is god awful and basically requires you to do the main story as quickly as possible to prevent character deaths because NPCs dont scale with you even though enemies do. The dungeons get very repetitive very quickly and can make the game pretty boring once you play enough of it.

Despite all of that, I still very much enjoyed by time with this game and I still encourage people to play it. You may not love it, but it is worth a try especially with the low price.

Having played Oblivion back in 2006 and playing it now in 2023, I have to say that I enjoy the game even more today. In 2006 I was coming off several years of intensely worshipping Morrowind and found the altered combat mechanics (more FPS than RPG) annoying, I mised the lore, the long conversations and the mandatory walking and pathfinding. But now after playing Fallouts, Skyrim, Dying Light and other modern shooter RPGs, the game feels just right. It mostly comes down to general ambience. I appreciate the game world a lot more now than I did 17 years ago. I like the serene walks along the country roads, gathering potion  ingredients, figthing bandits along the way. I like the settlements, the quests, the geography of Cyrodiil with it's different regions and people. Ok, enough waxing. 
The game shows its age here and there, but overall it's a fine experience. Yes, the leveling is broken, the main quest is nonsensical, and the Oblivion plane is a rather dull place, but there's enough fun to be had nevertheless. And at high settings, Cyrodiil is a pretty place.

This is one of those games that make you forget about everything in the world, enjoying its cozy atmosphere.

The main focus in Oblivion is the story and quests, not the combat system. Although there are combat moments in the game, and they are quite satisfactory, this is not the aspect of the game to focus on. Instead, the game engages you in numerous quests, each with its unique style.

Oblivion's soundtrack is unparalleled. Tracks like "Wings of Kynareth", "Harvest Dawn", and "King and Country" have become particularly famous. They perfectly reflect the world of Cyrodiil and can induce nostalgia in those who have spent many hours in the game.

However, the game is not without flaws. The auto-leveling system, which was supposed to ensure the player's constant development, turned out to be less than ideal. Many players consider it broken, as it can lead to situations where enemies become too powerful compared to the player.

I recommend to anyone who enjoys exploring the world.

Oblivion is so good and then BOOM Oblivion Gate or dungeon.

What I'm saying is that I don't like Oblivion Gates and dungeons. They all look the same. They give me a headache whenever I have to go into either of them. 

The rest of Oblivion is pretty fire though, area design-wise.

I honestly like Oblivion's levelling system, I just wish the enemies didn't scale quite as much as you level up. Even if you know what you're doing, you will probably eventually reach a point where many of the enemies you face are just bullet(or arrow or sword slash)sponges. 

Apparently Bethesda gave Patrick Stewart a 90 page document outlining Uriel (?) Septim, a character who dies after the first 5 minutes of the game. They did this, but then had the rest of the voice actors read their lines in alphabetical order instead of in conversational batches. It makes most dialogue sound a little awkward and some dialogue sound extremely awkward. 

This fun fact, along with the graphics, soundtrack, physics system, and like a billion other subsystems in the game, end up making playing Oblivion feel like you're playing through a dream. I really like this vibe, I think that it scratches a really weird and really niche itch that no other game can scratch. 

Also, significantly better writing than Skyrim.

The amount of hours I have put into this game and each time i play through I still find something new to love about the game. Story time. Before i was a PC gamer and was just a young lad, my Dad and I would rent games every weekend when I went to see him. One weekend he picks me up from school and is like hey, I got this awesome game you are just going to love. Hes explaining to me all the different races and how cool the game is. I remember being so excited while we road home. I created a woodelf but the intro scared me so I had my dad play through it. Now I can do the whole thing with my eyes closed. It was my first time in an open world RPG and I loved exploring every little bit. Each step I took into a new cave or ruin was a new adventure for my dad and myself. He ended up buying the game for me and I dedicated my life to playing it. Not only because it was a fun game but it helped me in life. It gave me an outlet when i didnt have one. It was there for me during 10 years of abuse from my stepdad. (My mother and I got out after 10 years and are now living amazing lives as we have always wanted so it does get better friends.) It gives me such a rush of nostalgia when that main menu boots up. Now im playing through this masterpiece once more and I cant wait to show my children this game and hope to be even half the father mine is to me.

Sixteen years later, this game is still captivating. Morrowind may be the “best” Elder Scrolls game, but this will forever be my favourite. It’s cheesy. It’s expansive. And everything looks like it’s covered in vaseline (or, at the very least, through a bloom filter).

Pros: 
- The guilds in this game are second to none. The Dark Brotherhood and Thieves Guild quest lines in particular hold up as superb.
- Everything is very pretty and vibrant. Even the more decayed areas still have an eye-catching colour palette.
- The main story is pretty good. Not amazing, but about what you’d expect for a Bethesda game.
- The DLC stories are even better.
- It’s just…fun. Easy to get lost in.
- Hasn’t everyone always wanted an obsessive fan?

Cons:
- The combat is whatever. Even for 2007 it was whatever. 
- The random NPC dialogue is bland.

As an avid fan of The Elder Scrolls series, I decided to revisit The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion despite its dated graphics. While the game may not hold up well in terms of visuals compared to modern titles, its charm lies in its immersive world and captivating gameplay.

One aspect that disappointed me was the limited and buggy controller support. To fully enjoy the game, I had to use both the keyboard and controller simultaneously since some game mechanics weren't compatible with the controller. This inconvenience made me question the usefulness of using a controller with the game. If you're a fan of using controllers, you might find this aspect frustrating.

However, for die-hard fans of The Elder Scrolls franchise, revisiting Oblivion can be a rewarding experience. The game's vast open world, rich lore, and engaging quests still manage to captivate players even after all these years. Exploring the detailed landscapes, encountering unique characters, and embarking on epic adventures are still as thrilling as ever.

One of the game's redeeming qualities is the extensive modding community that has flourished over the years. The NexusMods platform offers a plethora of free mods that can enhance and customize your Oblivion experience. With the user-friendly Vortex mod manager, even those with limited technical knowledge can easily install mods. This allows players to tailor the game to their preferences and breathe new life into the aging graphics and gameplay mechanics.

Overall, if you're an Elder Scrolls fan, The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion is worth a replay. Despite its outdated graphics and limited controller support, the game's immersive world and captivating gameplay make it a worthwhile experience. The availability of free mods further extends its longevity, allowing players to customize their adventures and add fresh content to the game.

The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion, developed by Bethesda Game Studios, stands as an absolute triumph in the realm of open-world role-playing games. With its breathtaking scope, immersive storytelling, expansive world, and unparalleled sense of freedom, Oblivion continues to be hailed as one of the greatest games ever created.

At the heart of Oblivion lies an engrossing narrative that takes players on an unforgettable journey through the mythical realm of Cyrodiil. From the moment you step foot into the lush and diverse landscape, a captivating sense of wonder and adventure envelops you. The depth and intricacy of the lore, combined with richly developed characters and engrossing questlines, breathe life into a world teeming with political intrigue, ancient prophecies, and personal tales of triumph and tragedy. Each interaction and decision carries weight and consequence, ensuring that every step of your journey holds both meaning and significance.

The world of Cyrodiil itself is a breathtaking masterpiece of design and attention to detail. Vast cities, sprawling forests, majestic mountains, and ominous dungeons await exploration, each with its own secrets to uncover and challenges to conquer. The sheer scope and scale of the open-world are staggering, immersing players in a living, breathing universe teeming with possibilities. Whether delving into the depths of ancient ruins, engaging in political machinations, or venturing into the realm of daedric princes, every corner of Cyrodiil holds an adventure waiting to be discovered.

The level of customization and character progression in Oblivion is staggering. With an extensive skill system, players have the freedom to mold their characters into whatever they desire, be it a master swordsman, a cunning mage, or a stealthy rogue. The multitude of quests, guilds, and factions to join offer a wide array of gameplay experiences, allowing players to tailor their adventures to their preferred playstyle. The sense of agency and the ability to forge your path in the world of Oblivion is truly unparalleled.

Furthermore, the attention to detail in the visuals and audio of Oblivion is nothing short of exceptional. The sprawling landscapes, architectural marvels, and atmospheric lighting transport players into a realm that feels both fantastical and believably real. The hauntingly beautiful musical score, with its stirring melodies and evocative themes, enhances the sense of immersion and elevates the emotional impact of each moment.

Lastly, the modding community surrounding Oblivion has contributed to its enduring legacy. The game's extensive modding tools and support have allowed players to create and share their own adventures, expand the game world, and enhance the overall experience. This vibrant and creative community has breathed new life into Oblivion, ensuring that even after all these years, the game continues to evolve and offer fresh experiences for both new and returning players.

In conclusion, The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion stands as an incomparable masterpiece, offering a rich and immersive world, captivating storytelling, and limitless freedom. Its sprawling landscapes, complex characters, and boundless possibilities combine to create an experience that remains unparalleled in the realm of open-world RPGs. Oblivion is a testament to the power of interactive storytelling, forever etching its place in gaming history as an unparalleled epic that has touched the hearts and souls of countless adventurers.

Elder Scrolls: Oblivion holds a special place in my heart as a defining chapter in the beloved franchise. From the moment I stepped into the vibrant world of Cyrodiil, I was transported to a realm of magic, adventure, and limitless possibilities. This personal review is a testament to the profound impact this game had on me and countless other adventurers.

As I emerged from the dark and eerie prison cell, I was immediately captivated by the breathtaking beauty of Cyrodiil. The rolling hills, dense forests, shimmering lakes, and bustling cities painted a picturesque landscape that begged to be explored. The attention to detail in the world design was nothing short of awe-inspiring, with every nook and cranny holding hidden secrets, treasure-filled dungeons, and intriguing characters awaiting discovery.

The freedom of choice offered in Elder Scrolls: Oblivion was liberating. I could be the valiant hero, the sneaky thief, or the masterful mage, forging my own path through the rich tapestry of quests and storylines. The main questline, centered around the mysterious Oblivion Gates and the threat they posed to Tamriel, kept me on the edge of my seat as I unraveled the intricacies of the Daedric realms and their influence on the mortal plane.

But it was the seemingly endless array of side quests that truly made Oblivion shine. From helping the desperate citizens of towns and villages to joining various guilds and rising through their ranks, each quest felt like a story in itself. Whether it was infiltrating a secret society of assassins, embarking on a perilous treasure hunt, or saving a town from a vampire infestation, the world of Oblivion was teeming with captivating tales that wove together to form a tapestry of epic proportions.

The NPCs of Oblivion breathed life into the world. Each character had their own personality, desires, and fears, making interactions feel genuine and immersive. Engaging in conversations with the denizens of Cyrodiil often revealed intriguing details, quests, or even unexpected friendships. I still recall the witty banter of Sheogorath, the Daedric Prince of Madness, whose unpredictable nature added a delightful touch of chaos to the game.

Combat in Oblivion, while not as refined as later entries in the series, offered a satisfying blend of strategic decision-making and visceral action. Whether I wielded a sword, cast powerful spells, or unleashed arrows from the shadows, the battles felt engaging and rewarding. The character progression system allowed for deep customization, allowing me to mold my character's skills and attributes to suit my preferred playstyle.

The world-building in Oblivion extended beyond its landscapes and characters, with a hauntingly beautiful musical score that perfectly captured the essence of each location. The soaring melodies and haunting melodies added depth to the already immersive experience, evoking a wide range of emotions as I journeyed through the diverse regions of Cyrodiil.

That being said, Oblivion was not without its flaws. The character models and facial animations, while decent for their time, felt dated compared to modern standards. Occasional bugs and glitches could disrupt the flow of gameplay, although they were relatively minor and did not significantly impact my overall enjoyment.

Elder Scrolls: Oblivion remains a shining example of the power of immersive open-world RPGs. Its vast, enchanting world, engaging quests, and endless opportunities for exploration continue to resonate with players to this day. It's a game that ignited my passion for the Elder Scrolls series and left an indelible mark on my gaming journey.

In conclusion, Elder Scrolls: Oblivion is a monumental journey that captured the hearts and imaginations of players worldwide. Its influence on the genre cannot be overstated, as it set a new standard for open-world RPGs and solidified The Elder Scrolls franchise as a powerhouse in the gaming industry.

The sheer scale of the game was staggering. From the towering Imperial City to the mystical realm of the Shivering Isles, each location was meticulously crafted, immersing players in a world teeming with lore, history, and diverse cultures. Exploring the vast countryside, stumbling upon hidden caves, and stumbling upon ancient ruins filled me with a sense of wonder and discovery. The attention to detail in every nook and cranny made the world feel alive and constantly rewarding to explore.

The depth of character customization in Oblivion was remarkable. From choosing a race and class to fine-tuning skills and attributes, every decision shaped the gameplay experience. Whether I wanted to become a master swordsman, a cunning thief, or a powerful mage, the game accommodated my choices and allowed for dynamic character growth. The ability to level up and progress in various guilds and factions provided a sense of purpose and accomplishment, further enhancing the immersive nature of the game.

The narrative of Oblivion was rich and engrossing. The main questline, which thrust players into the role of the fabled hero destined to save the realm from the Daedric invasion, was epic in scale and filled with unexpected twists and turns. Interacting with iconic characters such as Martin Septim, the last heir to the Empire, and the enigmatic Blades agents added depth and emotional weight to the overarching story. The sense of urgency and impending doom drove me forward, eager to unravel the mysteries and confront the forces threatening Tamriel.

The side quests in Oblivion were where the game truly shined. Each quest felt meticulously crafted, offering memorable characters and captivating storylines. Whether I was assisting a troubled ghost seeking redemption or embarking on a journey to recover lost artifacts, these quests were engaging and left a lasting impression. The choices I made had consequences, branching the narrative and shaping the world around me, further adding to the game's replayability and depth.

Combat in Oblivion was a blend of real-time action and strategic decision-making. Engaging in sword fights, casting powerful spells, or utilizing archery required skill and tactics. While the combat mechanics may have felt somewhat clunky compared to more modern releases, the variety of weapons and spells at my disposal kept the battles engaging and enjoyable.

The soundtrack of Oblivion was a symphony of enchanting melodies that heightened the game's atmosphere. From the haunting choir in the iconic theme to the stirring orchestral pieces that accompanied exploration and combat, the music perfectly captured the essence of each moment, immersing me deeper into the world and evoking a wide range of emotions.

However, Oblivion did have its fair share of technical issues. Occasional graphical glitches, AI quirks, and quest bugs could hamper the experience. While these issues were relatively minor and did not detract significantly from the overall enjoyment, they were noticeable and occasionally frustrating.

In conclusion, Elder Scrolls: Oblivion stands as a landmark title in the realm of open-world RPGs. Its immersive world, intricate storytelling, and countless hours of exploration and adventure make it a masterpiece in its own right. Despite its technical imperfections, Oblivion's enduring legacy is a testament to its ability to transport players to a realm of fantasy and wonder. It remains a must-play game for anyone seeking a truly immersive and unforgettable RPG experience.

[h1]Introduction[/h1]
Released when I was just 16 years old, Oblivion was a game that captivated me with its groundbreaking graphics, immersive gameplay, and intricate NPC AI schedules. As an open-world role-playing game, it offered an unparalleled sense of freedom, allowing players to embark on countless side-quests, interact with diverse NPCs, and shape their character's destiny. The game seamlessly blended combat, magic, and stealth skills, offering a wide range of possibilities for character development. In this review, I will delve into the significant gameplay features, plot points, and their interconnectedness, showcasing how Oblivion made a lasting impact on the RPG genre.

[h1]Gameplay and Character Development[/h1]
At the heart of Oblivion's gameplay was character development. Players were given the choice to select one of ten races, each with its own unique abilities, and customize their appearance. The game introduced the concept of major and minor skills, with major skills being crucial for leveling up. As players improved their major skills by ten points, they gained the opportunity to enhance their attributes and unlock new abilities related to the skill.

The game's 21 skills were divided into three categories: combat, magic, and stealth. Combat skills encompassed the use of heavy weapons, while magic skills allowed players to manipulate the physical world, control minds, summon creatures, and heal wounds. Stealth skills emphasized cunning, enabling players to crack locks, manipulate NPCs through speech, and engage in stealthy combat. The game world offered various tools and equipment, such as weapons, spells, and lockpicks, which players could acquire through purchase, theft, or looting.

Oblivion presented players with the choice of playing in either a first- or third-person perspective, except in the mobile phone version where an isometric projection was the only option. The level of difficulty could be adjusted at any time, allowing players to fine-tune the game to their preference. The heads-up display constantly provided crucial information about the character's health, magicka (used for spells), and fatigue. Managing these resources through rest, spells, and potions played a vital role in ensuring the character's effectiveness in combat.

[h1]Dynamic World and Level Scaling[/h1]
The world of Oblivion was teeming with diverse enemies, ranging from fantastical creatures like imps and goblins to natural predators like bears and wolves. One of the game's notable features was level scaling, which ensured that enemies and equipment became more challenging and powerful as the player leveled up. This mechanic aimed to maintain a consistent level of difficulty throughout the game, but it also drew criticism due to potential imbalances. Some players discovered that leveling certain skills too quickly resulted in disproportionately difficult enemies.

[h1]Plot and Narrative[/h1]
Set in the province of Cyrodiil during the Third Era, Oblivion followed the events of The Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind but was not a direct sequel. The game's narrative commenced with the player character imprisoned for an unknown crime. Emperor Uriel Septim VII, accompanied by the Blades, the Imperial bodyguards, arrived in the prison seeking an escape route from assassins who had murdered his sons. In a twist of fate, the emperor is slain, but not before entrusting the player with the Amulet of Kings, a critical artifact tied to the barrier to Oblivion.

The main questline revolved around closing the gates to Oblivion, which had been opened due to the lack of a legitimate heir to Uriel Septim. The player's mission was to find Martin, an illegitimate son of the emperor, and aid him in reclaiming the throne, relighting the Dragonfires, and ending the Daedric invasion. Throughout the journey, the player encountered various factions, including the Mythic Dawn, a cult dedicated to the Daedric Prince of Destruction, Mehrunes Dagon. The cult played a significant role in the assassination of Uriel Septim and the theft of the Amulet of Kings.

The questline took players to various locations, including the city of Kvatch, which had been devastated by Daedra. The player had to close an Oblivion Gate to reclaim the city and persuade Martin, who survived the attack, to join the cause. As the Hero of Kvatch, the player returned to Weynon Priory, only to find it under attack, leading to a series of events that culminated in Martin being recognized as the emperor. The player, now part of the Blades, embarked on a quest to retrieve the stolen amulet from the Mythic Dawn, ultimately confronting their leader, Mankar Camoran.

The climax of the game unfolded in the Imperial City, where the player and Martin fought against the Daedric forces and Mehrunes Dagon himself. In a sacrifice to save Tamriel, Martin shattered the Amulet of Kings, merging with the spirit of Akatosh and becoming his avatar. Together, they defeated Dagon and closed the gates to Oblivion, securing the future of Tamriel.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
Oblivion, with its impressive graphics, revolutionary NPC AI schedules, and immersive gameplay, set a new standard for open-world RPGs. The intricate character development system, dynamic world, and interconnected plot points created a truly immersive experience. While the game faced criticism for its level-scaling mechanics, it remains a landmark title in the RPG genre. Even now, reflecting back on my experience with Oblivion as a 16-year-old, it continues to hold a special place in my heart as a game that captured my imagination and provided countless hours of exploration and adventure.

Went from consistent crash upon exiting the sewers, to inconsistently crashing every half-hour, to crashing every several hours or only if I alt-tab many times. Chalking it up to the jank I'm used to from playing it on a console back in 2010-2011. I love this game so much, because it's so broken but in a way you are free to take advantage of, and even encouraged to, with a difficulty slider that simply adds or subtracts enemy health/damage values. Best open-world fantasy RPG ever made, in my opinion, requiring only a few mods to bring it to a working, enjoyable, modern state.

Take heed of the crashes, though. If you're not good at dealing with them or identifying causes, you'll be unable to enjoy the experience. It happens most frequently due to age of the game and conflicts with modern GPU drivers/default settings. Use NVProfileInspector, and load the Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion profile(as written there) which is built-in to the driver package, and that sets most everything in a fashion so as to not crash on loading areas. 

It still crashes sometimes, but doing this rules out the graphics processes, leading me to conclude that it's a miracle that I can even play it today. 

Pro tip: throw a few hard-to-level skills into your class, so your character level climbs super slowly, allowing you to get other skill-ups that contribute to attribute gains upon leveling up, maximizing the benefits of leveling up. In other words, never level up until you've earned +5 in 3 attributes worth of skill-ups. +5 requires 10 skill-ups of constituent schools(for strength, +1 blunt, +2 blade, +7 hand to hand would give +5 strength as a choice upon leveling up, if those skill-ups occurred after the prior level) - It's quite difficult to optimize this, and perhaps completely unnecessary, but its a fairly obscure way to optimize against the leveled lists of the game, and if you neglect this, level 25+ will kick your ass.

The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion is a big, stupid mess. As a fantasy RPG, I can't take it seriously at all. The gameplay is stiff and janky, the character models look like walking potatoes, the main story is overshadowed by literally every other questline in the game, and the AI is dumber than a sack of hammers. So why am I recommending it? Because it's a comedy gold mine, that's why. There's never a dull moment in Oblivion. Even things as small as NPC chatter are so weird and disjointed that I can't help but laugh at them. You should absolutely play Oblivion at least once, but my advice is not to take it too seriously. My final rating for it is 8/10.

Coming from Skyrim it takes a little bit of getting used to, but if you want something that bridges the gap between the simplicity of Skyrim and the complexity of Morrowind, this game is perfect for that. I actually like a lot of the features in this game more than in Skyrim. Lockpicking feels like it's a skill you can actually learn and not just random chance that you can waste perk points making less random. The voice acting is insane compared to Skyrim. So many people in that game sound so tired and unenthused. Oblivion's characters are the complete opposite. Exploration is more fun when you don't have a giant white arrow pointing you exactly where you need to go at all times. I can see why people don't love the persuasion minigame, but I kinda love having little minigames like that that I can use to gain certain characters' favor to then get different chat options out of them or even haggle for better trade prices. The level up system is also much better than in Skyrim in my opinion. First, it gives you a reason to sleep. Second, leveling up in Skyrim, especially at higher levels, sucks when you can only choose a single perk among like two dozen perk trees. In Oblivion, you can level up three "perk trees" (they're not perk trees in Oblivion but they're what turned into them in Skyrim) and each of those perks will often have several points added instead of just one. The magic systems in both Oblivion and Skyrim have their merits, but there is something I like very much about being able to have a specific spell hotkeyed that I can use at any time while having my main weapons equipped (Skyrim kinda has this with shouts, but it has a long cooldown compared to what you can do in Oblivion with magicka and a few potions). The music in both games is perfect for different reasons. There's not really much reason to compare these, one is emulating a rural nordic sound and the other is going for a bombastic imperial sound (though some of Oblivion's cave music makes me feel like Indiana Jones).
I'm not sure what my point is anymore, so let me get back to that. Oblivion is good. If you like Skyrim and you want that but with more freedom, complexity, and apparently better quests (I can attest that the earlier story quests are better imo than Skyrim's, but I'm excited to get to the later ones like the Dark Brotherhood and other faction questlines that people have been telling me about for years now), I think it's worth a shot.
Okay, enough rambling. Game good, me likely.

If you really like TES, this one is probably worth picking up just so you can experience Todd's genius a bit more.

Otherwise I would consider looking elsewhere for open world RPGs. This game has been frequently laughed at for it's broken levelling system and for good reason. The first 5 or so levels tend to have all your enemies be made out of toilet paper, but levels 6-20 tend to be a painful slog where everything becomes way tougher than it should be because Todd is a genius. Then everything becomes really easy again at level 25 because you can find several OP items to get 100% physical resistance and simply become immune to most attacks.

Not to mention the combat itself feels janky as ever, not like Morrowind where you can magically miss someone right in front of you because the Nerevarine was a bit out of breath, just janky and awkward like the rest of Bethesda's open world RPGs except worse because it's Oblivion.

The scenery is really beautiful for such an old game.  There is plenty to do in the way of quests and independent exploration.  Finding the ideal (for you) character configuration is quite challenging and there is always something new to learn about how to get the best from your character.  (I had several false starts initially until I found a character configuration which suited me and, also,  working out how best to approach the game environment.)

On the negative side, there are several bugs which vary from amusing to somewhat annoying, but, so far (1000+hours) I have found none which are game breaking or which, for me, "have" to be fixed with a mod.
Because, and this is personal, even in a game I cannot bring myself to commit murder I am, by personal choice, excluded from one major quest line - The Dark Brotherhood.  Some of the scripts, question lines and cut scenes go on too long for my liking and so break immersion.  I wish that it was possible to "repair" the damage to the landscape from the Oblivion Gates and so I deliberately delayed starting the main quest as long as possible.  Horses are not an easy travel option and I simply find them not worth having.

All that said, there is still far more to the game which for me is positive.  I have definitely had more than value for my money in game play and enjoyment.  Significantly, I am on my 2nd full play through.

This is a gorgeous game and perfect for the independent gamer.  You don't have to play with others, in fact you can't!  The world is large and it is a lot of fun to explore the maps and uncover dungeons, caves and towns. There is a main quest-line, but you can really play the game your own way and in many different ways thanks to the varied quests, the different classes and different guilds. I would recommend this game to the solo gamer and would encourage new gamers to give it a shot - it's easy to pick up and a lot of fun!

Without a shadow of a doubt, Oblivion has THE BEST vanilla experience, out of the main-line Elder Scrolls titles.

People whine and moan about the graphics, faces, and the voice acting, and while there IS some truth to that, the good heavily outweighs the bad; and even then, some of the odd quirks of the bad, adds to the charm. 

Oblivion and Daggerfall are tied for first place, in terms of how much I love them, when stacked up against the other TES titles. (Morrowind taking a not-so-close second).

People claim the combat is too floaty and lacks impact, which is genuinely bollocks.
If you're spamming Mouse 1 without a care in the world, then I suppose yes, it can feel that way, when analyizing footage.
However, if you don't play the game like a lobotomized AI, and use the tools at your disposal, you quickly find that it is a much better combat system than people give it credit for.

And of course, the questlines are among the best in the series.
Any equivalent faction quest (and the main quest too), in Skyrim - Oblivion does better.
Every single one of them.

Hell, Oblivion even does "annoying characters" better.
The Adoring Fan tops Nazeem and Delphine any day of the week.

All in all, BUY THIS, AND SHOVE SKYRIM IN THE TRASH.

This is the first game I'd ever followed it's development online, back in 05'. I bought the game before I had a graphics card that could properly run the lighting and I still loved it!
The game was released between Morrowind and Skyrim and most aspects of the game also lay between. 
I'll start with the bad:

-BLOOM! Oh my goodness, I guess Devs back in the mid 00's thought Bloom could fix anything and everything, it looks terrible and is likely one of the worst parts of the game.

-The AI was good for it's day, but can be a little annoying and frustrating at times to fight. The block/stagger mechanic of the game isn't great and the AI takes full advantage of this at all times. 

-The dialogue isn't anywhere near as good as Morrowind or Skyrim. Oblivion is full voice acted, which is fantastic over the text boxes of Morrowind, but the writing isn't anywhere near as good, however the voice acting isn't as good as Skyrim, again an in between.

-Though the Magic System is amazing, it isn't quite as good as Morrowinds magic spell creation system and you have to constantly go into your inventory to switch spells as there are no hot keys.

-Lastly, it was designed to be used on the Xbox 360 and like a lot of these games, the Cities and other built up areas are all enclosed by walls and doors, giving you lots of load screens!

Good stuff:

-The story is solid, personally I liked it better than Skyrim!

-The Magic system is top notch! You can effectively cast spells while armored and carrying a two handed weapon or sword and board. So your fighting style won't block your spells!

-The combat and AI were pretty top notch for the day and still hold up except where I mentioned above.

-The music lands the mood of this game very well!

-The lighting, I actually think Oblivion has the best lighting out of all the TES games! There had been plenty of times I've been searching a dungeon and I'd have some big bad come out of the darkness like a horror game jump scare! You don't get that in Skyrim! 

I know I've mentioned more bad than good, however the good is story, combat and magic, which is 90% of the game over all! The bad stuff is simply from observation over the years. 
I'd still highly suggest this game, despite it's aged look and sometimes mildly frustrating mechanics.

This was the first game that I played in the Elder Scrolls series and one that I still go back and play on occasion. 

A true open-world game with only a few transition screens and plenty of places to go and explore. The main story line is good, but doesn't exactly get your heart racing. More than enough side quests and dungeons to keep you occupied and interested.

The graphics are certainly dated, but not so archaic as to be distracting like Morrowind. Combat system is efficient and fairly quick to master.

The game is surprisingly stable considering its age and I've rarely experienced a hard crash.

One of the best games ever made.

It's a vast world brimming with deep, enthralling quests and lore. Despite being released in 2006, the graphics and artstyle are still impressive today. The soundtrack by Jeremy Soule is legendary and features some of the most incredible music I've ever heard in my life. In many ways, this game even outshines Skyrim. Although the combat system could be more elaborate, it is still enjoyable and captivating.

I love this game to death. Oblivion has had a significant impact on my life and who I am today. As a child attending elementary school, Oblivion introduced me to the English language. Since there was no Czech localization for many years, I was compelled to improve my English profoundly. Spending my summer holidays with Oblivion helped me become the top student in my English class. I have been studying and adoring the language ever since. To this very day, I continue to learn new expressions from Oblivion. I believe many gamers have had similar experiences with their English improving after playing tons of games. I'm just inspired to take this knowledge to the next level and possibly even dedicate my career to English, my native Czech language, or the digitally infinite marvel called natural/human language.

I am forever grateful to Bethesda for creating this masterpiece. Thanks to this game, I found true love.

I give it a perfect [b][u]10/10[/u][/b].

I must express my unequivocal admiration for the Elder Scrolls Universe, which undoubtedly stands as the most remarkable among its counterparts within the realm of fantasy worlds. My inaugural venture into Tamriel occurred through the auspicious medium of ES V Skyrim. After completing every quest and succumbing to an inevitable ennui, I resolved to embark upon the path of Oblivion. ES IV Oblivion boasts a myriad of NPCs, a profusion of architectural marvels, and quests of unparalleled grandeur. Nevertheless, one must concede that its graphical prowess fails to surpass that of Skyrim. It is pertinent to note that I commenced my journey with the aid of mods, thus regrettably rendering me oblivious to the vanilla experience. I can confidently assert that this augmented state of gameplay remains entirely viable, thereby enhancing the overall immersion. Notwithstanding, I have a penchant for assuming the role of the "chosen one," and Skyrim captivated my attention expeditiously, as I assumed the mantle of the Dragonborn from the very outset, imbued with an inescapable sense of destiny. Conversely, although the position of Hero of Kvatch afforded a modicum of gratification, the overarching narrative primarily revolved around Martin, leading to a partial loss of interest. Moreover, it is worth mentioning that the breathtaking expanse of Cyrodiil rivals the sublime beauty of Skyrim, albeit bereft of snow, it nevertheless exudes an unparalleled ambiance. To summarize, I wholeheartedly recommend immersing oneself in the enchanting world of Oblivion or even delving into the Elder Scrolls' antecedent installments such as Morrowind, Daggerfall, and even Arena. Nonetheless, I implore you to augment these experiences with the judicious application of mods, thereby ensuring a substantially more gratifying sojourn.

Plus, this game is also a ton of fun to mess around with mods on. But for its time, the graphics and textures aren't bad in my opinion, may not be as good as other newer games now a days but still not bad. I would recommend playing this if you haven't already. 10/10 :)
