(To preface this review: Yes I have tried using mods to fix some of these issues, but the problems are too core to the game's design to be fixed without some massive overhauls. I kept myself limited to more vanilla-oriented mods since it's not really fair to review a game that's been practically rewritten from scratch. Also I wanted to actually play Oblivion, and not some version of it that's been changed nearly beyond recognition.)

By far the worst Elder Scrolls game imo. Everything feels far more artificial than even Morrowind before it. I felt no atmosphere when trying to get into this one. There's a whole lot wrong with it but I'm gonna just give some bullet points.

-Enemies, and the player, are super spongey. Combat is an awful unchallenging slog, and was never fun. Enemies healing themselves makes this even more annoying.

-Every single face in this game is butt-ugly. All NPC's blend together a lot as well due to similar designs, and only having like 5 voice actors. It's nearly impossible to tell who's an important NPC and who's just a random citizen. Even Morrowind did this better, and Skyrim as well.

-Scaling is all kinds of wack. The difference between a damage skill at 0 and 100 is only 50%. Just... really? As a result of this, combat never stops being the slog it already was.

-Wandering around in these games usually results in finding some pretty cool stuff. But in my attempts to do so in this entry, all I found were dull-as-frick caves and dungeons. No stories, no interesting landmarks, nothing.

-The menus are just, ehhhh. I especially dislike how unorganized the quest menu feels. And the map has no zoom. There's also no way to view the perks you have, including ones you aren't even told you acquired by starting a skill at a high enough level. Quality design there, lol.

-This game also has an earlier attempt at the world scaling that Skyrim eventually got right. This issue is pretty infamous, but bandits will end up with glass armor by the end of the game, and multiple entire enemy types disappear from the spawn pools completely. As mentioned earlier, the world here feels more artificial to me than anything else BGS has put out, and stuff like this is a huge reason why.

Out of every Elder Scrolls game, this one certainly feels the most generic and dull. Everything is exactly what you would expect from a medieval fantasy setting. There's no cool spins or twists on the genre. It's all your typical fantasy guff, and wow is it fricking boring. In regards to gameplay, it's like a strange limbo between the more raw RPG style of Morrowind, and the more streamlined style of Skyrim. Except it completely flops in both categories.

The verdict? Game sux.

I would recommend Morrowind or Skyrim instead. Depending on if you want a more hardcore type of RPG, or a more accessible one.

Playing this again after spending the last few weeks playing Morrowind for the first time, holy hell is this game leaps and bounds better than Morrowind. Walking into random Waterfront huts and talking to the random NPCs in there I encountered unique dialogues and back stories (3 siblings down on their luck working at the docks, but one of them only works as much as he gets paid while the others call him lazy, a dog, and a pig). In Morrowind, it's the same exact greeting and responses when talking to random NPCs.

I cannot help but mention the epiphany that hit me while playing this game after so many years and right after Morrowind. It overwhelmingly feels like Morrowind was the test vehicle for Bethesda to commit to a larger and fully realized project that would be realized through Oblivion. They took Morrowind to the nth degree and fully fleshed out. 

Especially important to note that because Bethesda managed to roll this out in 2007, Oblivion does not suffer from the mediocrity of balancing, oversimplying and streamlining gameplay, or the mainstream overcorrection of optimizing the fun out of the game that came later with Skyrim.

Also, each house you enter here feels unique. The towns feel different. The stories in each town are different. Even the random NPC houses you enter are intricately decorated and furnished, prime examples of medieval fantasy houses. Morrowind had cookie cutter barren houses that were bland, boring, and clearly filler material to give the illusion that the empty world of Morrowind isn't empty.
This still remains my all time favorite Elder Scrolls game.

Chapter 4 of The Elder Scrolls, being Oblivion, is one of the Best Elder Scrolls Game next to Morrowind & the First Elder Scrolls Game to be released for Xbox 360 and one of the last games to be Published & Developed by Bethesda Softworks with some help from 2K Games before becoming the Self Publisher of later games with Bethesda Game Studios as the Developer.

This Game came in Standard, Collectors & Deluxe Editions when it was first released. As for the Story, Tamriel enters the last hours of the Third Age & the Gates of Oblivion are approaching. Once again, you play as a convicted inmate ready to be shaped into whatever character you want with its new Character Modding Tools. Like Daggerfall & Arena, the Imperial Prison acts as the Tutorial Section where you select your Birthsign and Character Class, or make your own Class. Then after you carry out the Emperor Septim's Last Request to protect the Amulet of Kings, the world opens up entirely.

Like Morrowind, you're free to do what you want. Play the Main Story, Side Stories, Join any Faction (Hero or Dark), wander around, just to name a few such as buying a house or horse.

Oblivion has more Dynamic Settings than Morrowind such as Shop Hours and NPC Schedules. A New Leveling System where enemies scale to your levels where the stronger you are, the stronger the enemies are. Still, you better not break into any Closed Shops during Nightfall, the NPCs will call for the guards and you'll be arrested for breaking & entering, trespassing, etc crimes.

Elder Scrolls 4 also has an All-Star Voice Cast which makes the game suit its Triple A Game Status for Generation 7 Consoles & PCs. However, Elder Srcolls 4 had plenty of DLC & Updates. But the First one was a Re-Rating from T to M in 2006 as locked coding like GTA San Andreas were accessed through modding in the PC Version, Wizard's Tower, Shivering Islands & Knights of the Nine DLC along with Horse Armor. In 2006, DLC was new at the time along with In-Game Purchases that you would find in Mobile Games later on as a sign of things yet to come.

The Final Version being the GOTY Deluxe or 5th Anniversary Edition was released in 2011 offers the complete Oblivion Experience until Skyrim arrived bringing the whole "My Precious" & "One Elder Scrolls Game to Rule them All, One Elder Scrolls Game to Find them, One Elder Scrolls Game to Bring them All and then the Darkness binds them." to The Elder Scrolls Series, months later after the Elder Scrolls 4: Oblivion 5th Anniversary Edition.

I am a 52 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son found this game at Christmas, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. Loaded into the game world and started playing but I was stuck on what you were supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he helped me. Loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Oblivion was my first TES experience, and I still think that it's the most well-rounded and flexible experience for different play types. There's a great collection of mods for it, many with recent updates.

To get the full experience, this needs to be either Steam or some other PC-based approach; modding is really a must, both for bug fixes, and for graphical improvements. Beyond that there is, of course, also a legion of new options.

The game has a star-studded cast with Patrick Stewart, Sean Bean, and Terence Stamp. The main quest is intriguing, but leaves plenty of room for the main point of the game, which is to explore and get involved in this world that has been created for you.

It's less RPG style than it's predecessor, Morrowind, There is much less reliance on text menus, and the replacement UI is consolidated, the text enlarged, and looks like ink on paper. Doubtless a consideration for consoles in that design.

There's a great deal more voice acting, but not for the player character, who just makes noise when in pain plus makes "effort" sounds.

The graphics are a lot better than Morrowind, and can look convincing at times. From 2023's standpoint, it's hopelessly outdated, but it's a nice looking game that can look a lot nicer with some modding. The Colovian Highlands at sunset on horseback is something that you didn't know you needed.

The character creation face design interface is quite detailed, but is limited by how faces are done in the game. They're all a little funny looking, and yours will be, too. It was a joy to get into when it first came out, but this is an area where it's particularly dated now (2023).

Instead of Dwemer ruins, we have Ayleid ruins, which are more traditionally Elvish. This has been a knock on the game: that it hews too closely to the look of traditional sword and sorcery genre fare, rather than the more unique material of the last game. I'd say there's truth to that, and maybe it's me playing Morrowind later, but it didn't bother me. It's an incredible world that they've built for Oblivion. Some of it gets repetitive, but I'd rather have that than a smaller world.

Where the game really shines, like all TES games and other Bethesda titles, is the ability to just go out and do whatever. 

Explore and add markers to your map. Join a faction. Harvest crops. Teach a highwayman better manners. Go swimming; catch a fish. Collect alchemical ingredients. Practice your skills. Get Armorer to the point where you can repair enchanted items. Accept minor quests from complete strangers because why not? Get a horse and go. Explore a dungeon. Loot it. Kill that skeleton with the bow who's been shooting you for the entire fight that you just finished. Cast area spells and get in trouble. Buy and furnish every available house. Waste a ridiculous amount of time mountain hopping for a "shortcut." Finally get enough Magicka to cast a spell you bought ages ago for too much gold. Accidentally select Reynald instead of Guilbert and get the "celebrate" line. Move on to a new character because you've played this one out.

The levelling isn't great. Essentially, it's possible to hopelessly mess up your game by winging it. There's a system, and if you want to max your attributes without cheating, you have to get on top of it. You need to at least be aware in order to prevent nerfing your character.

Levelling aside, the skills and attributes are still fun, and the guild quests are pretty good overall, with the occasionaly roughspot. There are a host of mini and micro quests, being a completist can take quite a long time. These are a mixed bag, but mostly good, and there are many gems that keep interest going.

My big takeaway is Cyrodil is a place where I like to be. The Planes of Oblivion themselves, not so much. I really only visit there long enough to get my fill of Transcendent Sigil Stones, mostly.

Take the best part of Morrowind, the fact you still have Attributes and Skills that change how you move around the world, then cripple the levelling system even more and mix in the best NPC conversations you'll ever hear in a video game.
There you have it, Oblivion.

Jokes aside, it's one of my favourites when modded to hell, Vanilla though, it's got a lot of problems, biggest one is that's rather boring. Training is limited to 10 sessions per level, which is 5 Attribute points that you can at least pay for, the other 10 will need to be grinded for and of course that'll take ages to do. If you don't level well the enemies will be sure to show you the error of your ways and you'll be thanking Todd for including that difficulty slider.

The Quests really are the best part of this game, You can just stay at Level 1 and use quest related items to gear up, every quest line is a treat to go through for the most part, highlights being the Dark Brotherhood and Fighter's Guild. Shivering Isles is also the best DLC put out for a game I'd say.

Combat is now engaging unlike in the previous games that used dice rolls for everything. That said, combat boils down to you and your enemy waving your weapons like feather dusters hoping somebody will be staggered first. Oh, I should write this now, pump your Agility up unless you enjoy not playing the game when you're in a group combat scenario, take a shot when you get disarmed and knocked down from an arrow fired by a bandit you didn't see or when an Imperial Guard appears out of thin air to arrest you for stealing somebody's carrot.

You'll spend so much time watching the back of your character while running around the open meadow that is suppose to be Cyrodiil, it might start to bug you that your character's head almost never moves.

(Review contains spoilers about the game) In complete seriousness, Oblivion: TES IV is my favorite Elder Scrolls game out there right now, as someone who's played all 5 main-series games and ESO. Its main flaw is (obviously) graphics, the characters don't look very realistic or pleasant and apart from their heads and hands, their bodies are all one solid color, the signs are a little hard to read. But that flaw becomes a blessing very quickly to people with a sense of humor and plenty of time to spend on the character creation menu. 

Although, that's about my only problem with it. The factions are great, having fleshed out, full story-line Fighters, Mages, and Thieves guilds like Morrowind, as well as an arena (although unlike Morrowind it's an entire faction you can fight all the way to Grand Champion in) and the Dark Brotherhood. The other factions and DLC factions such as the Knights of the Nine were great too, each offering an interesting plot for your character to go through and another title to increase or decrease your Personality depending on the faction.

The pantheon of gods and Daedric princes your character can worship in the game are fun to me, too. The Nine Divines and their virtues are fun, and like I mentioned I loved the Knights of the Nine storyline, and I appreciate that you can be cured of diseases by praying at their altars. I also loved going around and doing the quests for each Daedric Prince, because the voice acting of each one and the personalized quests they sent me on added a lot of character to each one and made me understand other character's reasons for worshipping them. But the best part is that none of this is forced on you, and unlike Skyrim, you're not really banned from worshipping any given one. It's totally okay if, like Else God-Hater, you "hate the gods. All gods. They can all bite my garters. And if you don't like it, YOU can bite my garters, too."

I find it a little silly that at the end of the main quest, you're considered the Hero of Kvatch, and there's STILL no Emperor, but at no point do they think "hmm, maybe this hero that's saved our lives and was the one responsible for tracking down the last Septim heir should be our new Emperor." I get that for historical reasons leading into Skyrim, you can't have Martin Septim turn into a literal dragon and then just have some dude with no discernible features step in and be mediocre, but they could have at least added you to the Elder Council or something, maybe made you an advisor to a new Emperor. But not a huge deal, because I feel like most people end their playthroughs soon after beating the main quest.

All in all, an amazing game that I've poured almost 200 hours into at this point and will continue to play until I run out of free time to play it or TES VI comes out, whichever comes first. Give it a shot!

Oblivion was an experience. If you can immerse yourself in this game you will not want to put it down. Looking past the dated visuals, and 7 voice actors will make this a game to remember. The customization is so vast that it leaves room for multiple play-throughs. The world is huge, and full of caves and side missions that can get  a bit old. I would recommend playing on the lower difficulty level as higher difficulty just inflates enemy damage and HP, making fights a very tedious inconvenience. 
The freedom of playstyles lets this game feel alive with out you chose to interact with the world. Leveling up through playing is a clever way to keep players engaged. I do wish the magic was more reliable, but it is very impressive the vast array of spells in the game. The main story is very fun and was the last thing I did and was easily my favorite part. This is my first Elder Scrolls game and what a start it is. I would absolutely recommend this to anyone who wants a 3D medieval open world with innumerable ways of approaching it. If you enjoy the side missions you'll love them all. I see myself playing this again in the future with a different playstyle. I am really looking forward to playing Skyrim next.

I've stopped playing it for the time being, though, because the Skyblivion mod is actually very close to completion, they're estimating around a year until release from what I could find, and it looks AWESOME. So hyped for it.

So anyway, I'm waiting for that to finally drop first before I complete the game, but I do recommend Oblivion in its current state. Not like it really matters, pretty much everyone who is interested in TES IV has played it already, but still, I wrote a review anyway.

The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion is a classic role-playing game that was released over 15 years ago, yet it still remains a beloved title in the genre. The game has earned a reputation for its immersive world, deep lore, and engaging gameplay that keep players coming back for more.

One of the standout features of Oblivion is its expansive world that players can explore at their leisure. The game's open-world design allows players to traverse a vast landscape filled with unique environments, from lush forests to sprawling cities. The game's attention to detail is remarkable, and players can easily lose themselves in the game's world for hours on end.

The game's lore is also one of its strong points. The world of Oblivion is richly detailed, with an extensive history that players can discover through exploration and questing. The game's NPCs are also well-written and provide players with a wealth of information about the game's world and its inhabitants.

However, one area where Oblivion shows its age is its graphics. While the game was groundbreaking for its time, the graphics are undoubtedly dated by today's standards. Despite this, the game's art style still holds up, and the world is still beautiful to look at, even with its lower resolution textures.

Another area where the game could have improved is its story. While there are many quests to complete, some of them can feel like they go nowhere or lack satisfying conclusions. However, this is a minor issue when compared to the game's strengths.

In terms of gameplay, Oblivion is excellent. The game's combat system is intuitive, and players can choose from a variety of weapons and spells to customize their playstyle. The game's leveling system is also deep and provides players with a sense of progression and growth.

In conclusion, The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion is a classic RPG that still holds up today despite its dated graphics and some quests that feel unfulfilling. The game's immersive world, deep lore, and engaging gameplay make it a must-play for fans of the genre. Whether you're a long-time fan or a newcomer, Oblivion is an experience that you won't soon forget.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Memes aside, this game is a bonafide masterpiece, ive lost track of how many times ive played it since original launch on the 360. More recent versions of windows make the game a bit unstable (save often!) but you can edit the oblivion.ini file to increase the amount of ram the game can access - reducing crashes and improving framerate. As far as gameplay, the combat is vastly improved from Morrowind and has aged nicely. The ability to cast spells while wielding weapons makes this the ultimate battlemage simulator. My first game on my first Velocity gaming rig in 2006 and one to remember in a lifetime! [b]Oblivion[/b] is more complex than the beloved [b]Skyrim[/b] we all know. You have to [b]repair your equipment[/b] via hammers or visit a vendor who can fix your stuff, or else it will break during battle, and you know what follows. More interactions with NPCs where you try and [b]befriend[/b] them with a neat little mini-game wheel! Doing that also improves better chances of bartering; yes, you get to [b]barter[/b] with your vendors!

The lockpicking mechanic is different from the modern style that Bethesda uses for Skyrim and their [b]Fallout[/b] series, which is (to me) plain and boring. In Oblivion, depending on the lock difficulty, you get a mini-game where you have to push down springs and, with the right timing, lock that spring in place until you get all the springs to unlock the door/chest/etc.

Animations are... clunky, but this is a classic unless you mod the game. Mods make a huge difference in [b]The Elder Scrolls[/b] series but like Skyrim, the modding community is thinning due to different circumstances. If you're not used to modding and would like to get into it, I recommend Skyrim since it's more modernized than this potato and far more accessible to mod than Oblivion.

Oh, the soundtrack... the Nostalgia! The tracks make you feel like you are in a different and immersive world! Sometimes it is daybreak, in-game, and real life that I forget I have something to do. Oblivion was the perfect game to lose myself back in its day. I'll stop the review here since I can continue with this game forever.

This is a Hit or Miss title, Not much to appreciate now with the next generation of gaming and demands, but I still recommend Oblivion for the storyline.

I know I know, the game came out in 2006. And?
Here's my take on it.
First I am biased. Oblivion is THE game that started my long and storied video game passion. I discovered this game when I was 17, and realized there was an entire world of undiscovered adventure in video games. I'm 35 now and currently on my umpteenth play-through of it haha. I've grown up, started a career in the military, got married, adventured IRL across the world, experienced so many amazing and epic things, got divorced, and am currently about to retire from the military in little under five years. The entire time, This game and so many more have been with me both while playing them, and in my mind as I have walked IRL. Games like Oblivion have helped shape me as a person in many fundamental ways. But enough sob story let's talk about Oblivion!

First, even for a game released in 2006, it still holds its amazing wonder and epic beauty. Yeah, it's older, its 
NPCs and engine are dated. Even the dialogue is very dry sometimes lol. But it holds re-playable value quite well. It's a game I recommend any avid RPG lover play if they never have. 10/10 playable today for the first time and fully replayable.

Combat is very well done for the time and still is very playable today. It's dynamic, provides a cool third or first-person pov, and factors in all of your stats, both major and minor. 10/10 

The story is definitely epic. So many amazing characters involved, with Sean Bean as the primary NPC voice actor, and the story provides a struggle that makes you fully connect with the world at play. 10/10

Graphics are definitely very good for the time and hold up very well on modern machines. I play it on a 3080 with the latest ram and processing power and so on. For its age, 10/10

Dialogue has always been a bit dry in this game. the voice actors are re-used across many NPCs and the conversations with most can become repetitive. At the time, Bethesda was a lot smaller with a smaller budget and thus it really showed in the dialogue play. 5/10 for the dialogue itself, 10/10 for the nostalgic feels.

Questing is vast and takes you across the entire world. If you play every major and minor quest, you will see every inch of Tamriel in all its glory. 10/10 

DLC was always hit or miss. Knights of the Nine and Shivering Isles are definitely huge additions to the game that really brought their stories into the fold well. The rest is just fluff to me personally. 7/10 

Modding is very doable in this game. There are many many amazing mods that give new life to an already amazing game by so many modders. Many of them are absolute odes written and developed by gamers who clearly love the game and only wish to make it better than it already is. 10/10 for modability.

Overall, I give Oblivion a 9/10. It is an amazing game that is worthy of every gamer's chance to play through it at least once. I have countless hours on older machines lol. I've played it on every rig I've ever owned including PlayStation. RPGs truly are the root of all gaming, and Oblivion imo is one of the best of the best out there. I strongly encourage anyone who is interested in giving this game a run-through. 
Happy gaming and if you do, good luck on closing shut the jaws of Oblivion!

Oblivion is a classic open-world role-playing game that offers players a vast and immersive world to explore, filled with endless adventures, quests, and characters to discover. Developed by Bethesda Game Studios, Oblivion takes place in the province of Cyrodiil, a land of forests, mountains, and ancient ruins, where players take on the role of a prisoner who is tasked with saving the realm from the evil forces that threaten to destroy it.

One of the game's standout features is its open-ended gameplay, which allows players to approach the game however they see fit. Players can choose to focus on the main questline, or they can explore the world at their leisure, engaging in side quests, interacting with NPCs, and discovering hidden treasures and secrets.

The game's combat system is also highly customizable, with a range of weapons, spells, and abilities that players can use to take on enemies. The game's leveling system is also unique, with players able to customize their character's skills and attributes to suit their playstyle.

Visually, the game is stunning, with a rich and detailed world that is both immersive and believable. The game's sound design is also exceptional, with a dynamic soundtrack that adds to the game's atmosphere and sense of adventure.

Overall, Oblivion is a classic RPG that still holds up today, offering players a rich and immersive world to explore and countless hours of gameplay. Whether you're a fan of the genre or new to the world of RPGs, Oblivion is a game that is definitely worth playing.

The primary complaint people had with this game?  It's TOO open.  They throw you into a world and let you loose.  If you want to be a better thief, you steal things.  Want to be better at jumping?  Jump more.  Want to be better at fighting?  Kill things.

It's not D&D where killing rats makes you better at picking locks.  This is much more immersive and real.  And FUN.  Gathering loot and making yourself the hero of prophecy is much more engaging than having a story hold your hand and lead you into a role.  

This is a true ROLE PLAYING GAME.

Oblivion holds up well on its own, but benefits immensely from modding to fix the level scaling and outdated graphics. Some mods even add entirely new environments and biomes. However, it isn't as stable when modded as Skyrim, and thus needs to be handled with meticulous care.

Of the most recent three mainline Elder Scrolls games, I'd say Oblivion is my favorite. It is in many ways the perfect middle ground between Morrowind and Skyrim, and also has plenty of interesting qualities of its own. If I had to briefly describe the strengths of the game, I would say that for me it really boils down to:

1. Oblivion retains most of the RPG elements of Morrowind with none of the frustrating and clunky gameplay elements. It's really nice having a game with depth that gives you something to work towards if you want it but also handles in a relatively enjoyable manner. An actual class system with major skills, attributes, and birthsigns, lots of magical effects and stuff at your disposal, etc. make the RP aspect of it all plenty interesting, unlike Skyrim which dropped a ton of character building stuff. Magic is particularly fun in Oblivion which I really enjoy, but any playstyle is perfectly viable.

2. Oblivion's world is stunning. The landscape isn't super detailed by today's standards but it is still incredibly pretty, and the soundtrack supporting it is perfect as well. The cities are decent sized and well designed too. The dungeons are relatively simple but dark and moody, and not too long. The Shivering Isles expansion is fantastic looking also, and completely unique. Definitely my favorite world to be immersed in out of probably any game I've played.

3. The game is chocked full of really creative quests, and a lot of them take you into some really interesting hidden areas. And youre rarely forced to go into some generic dungeon for a quest, which is a breath of fresh air if you played Skyrim and didn't like that 75% of the quests in the game send you into some incredibly repetitive Nordic tombs. There are also a few different types of enemies that you can find inside dungeons in Oblivion, which makes them a little less monotonous despite the basic designs.

There are a few issues some people have with the game that I should mention also. One is the level scaling, and how difficult the tougher enemies you fight as you increase in level can be. The game is designed for you to make good use of the leveling system and increase your stat gains when you level up, so if you understand how the leveling system works then it won't be a problem (in fact, the really cool enemies you fight at higher levels make the scaling a good thing imo if you're prepared for it). But if you're wanting to play through more casually and not have to focus on your attributes as much then it may be a little frustrating unless you turn the difficulty down. Another thing is that the despite how good the environment looks, the NPCs do look a little odd and the random dialogue between them is pretty goofy. I've never been bothered by it much, but it's a turn-off for some people. The main quest sends you into several interdimensional gates that are neat the first couple times but get pretty old after that. I recommend leveling up a bit before doing them much so that you at least fight more interesting enemies inside, but it is a bit of a grind at times. Finally, a lot of people say the more archetypal medieval European setting of Oblivion is bland and boring, but I don't get that vibe at all. If anything it's nice that it's at least significantly different from the more rugged settings and themes of Morrowind and Skyrim, but the idyllic surface of the game is also a mask for some really dark and macabre areas and concepts underneath. 

Overall, I very highly recommend playing Oblivion. It is a little dated in some areas but it's a lot of fun and it's a game I love to be immersed in. If you enjoy developing a character, doing interesting and creative quests, and/or strolling through a gorgeous environment, then Oblivion's weaker areas won't bother you much and it will be an enjoyable experience.

The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion is a magnificent masterpiece of a game that seamlessly blends together immersive gameplay, compelling storytelling, and stunning visuals to create an unforgettable gaming experience.

From the moment you enter the world of Cyrodiil, you are transported to a beautifully crafted fantasy realm full of wonders and dangers alike. Whether you choose to follow the main questline, embark on various side quests, or simply explore the vast and diverse landscape, Oblivion offers an incredible amount of content to keep you engaged and entertained for hours on end.

One of the most impressive aspects of Oblivion is its attention to detail. Every corner of the world is meticulously crafted, from the sprawling cities and bustling towns to the dark and ominous dungeons. The game's visuals are simply breathtaking, with stunning landscapes, impressive character models, and detailed textures that bring the world to life in vivid detail.

The gameplay itself is also top-notch, with a satisfying mix of action, exploration, and strategy. Whether you prefer to engage in epic battles with swords and magic, sneak around undetected, or use your wits to solve puzzles and overcome obstacles, Oblivion offers a wide range of gameplay options to suit any playstyle.

But what truly sets Oblivion apart is its compelling storytelling. The game's main questline is a thrilling adventure full of twists and turns, and the side quests are just as engaging, with well-developed characters and interesting plotlines. The game's lore is rich and deep, with a fascinating history and mythology that adds depth and meaning to every aspect of the game.

Overall, The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion is a true masterpiece of gaming, offering an unparalleled experience that is sure to captivate and inspire gamers for years to come. Its attention to detail, immersive gameplay, and compelling storytelling make it a must-play for any fan of RPGs, and its stunning visuals and epic scope are sure to leave a lasting impression.

Bethesda doesn't realize that they accidentally created a horror game. There is nothing more traumatizing than sneaking through the guard barracks as a kid in silent ambience, and the camera swivels into the face of a man who yells "STOP". They don't even tell you that you might be trespassing. If you even imagine a crime, a guardsmen will manifest from thin air. They're even on the game cover to make sure you buy this game properly like the law intends. 

If you need further explanation, every guard is Earl in full sprint from Cloudy With A Chance Of Meatballs. Once you see it, you can never unsee it.

I must say, I am impressed. The graphics are stunning, with beautiful vistas and detailed characters. The world that Bethesda has created here is simply breathtaking and full of interesting quests and characters to explore.

The combat system is also very well done, with a variety of weapons and spells at your disposal. The enemy AI is also very advanced, giving you a challenging fight even on the easiest difficulty setting.

The soundtrack is also great, with a variety of tracks that fit the mood and atmosphere of the game perfectly. I especially like the main theme, which is quite catchy.

Overall, The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion® Game of the Year Edition is an excellent game that I would highly recommend to anyone looking for a great RPG experience. Highly recommended!

Unequivocally the Greatest (overall) Elder Scrolls game, by and by!
I cannot attest to how phenomenal this game is without sounding biased, because it's my favorite game, not just in the ES franchise, but in general. I'm unabashedly biased. As someone who has dumped countless hours into both Morrowind and begrudgingly into Skyrim; Oblivion is the best middle ground between the more traditional RPG elements of Morrowind, and the (excessive, borderline dumbing down) streamlining of Skyrim. Graphics for a 2006 title are actually pretty dope! Yes, there are a few NPC's that are, for lack of a better term, tragic looking, but honestly it isn't *TOO* bad, certainly nowhere near as severe an issue as people make it out to be. Most of my hours spent playing this game was on the Xbox360, and now on the Series X, but I literally downloaded Windows on my Macbook, just so I can buy Oblivion again and have access to it on my laptop! If that does't at least make you want to try it, go look at some gameplay or reviews on YouTube, you will be enthralled!

It's a shame they changed the quest and dialogue system. Morrowind is superior in this regard, not walking you through the game, but encouraging you to interact with all the NPCs to gather needed information.
In Oblivion, they adopted the generic dialogue system with voice acting, which limits the possible options of dialogue (most of the NPCs have only 3-5 options, of which at least 2 are practically useless, besides some character/setting flavor). Thus, most of the time you are forced to follow the markers on the map to finish the objective, since you can barely get any useful information or clues regarding the objective via dialogues.

Altogether, it's a good experience, with some good life lessons, plenty of moments admiring the landscape and ambiance music. Will replay this for sure!

Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion is a timeless classic that stands out as one of the best RPGs of all time. The game's immersive world-building, rich lore, and engaging gameplay mechanics make it a standout experience that is hard to replicate.

One of the standout features of Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion is the game's attention to detail in world-building. The game's vast open-world environment is packed with memorable characters, intricate quests, and hidden secrets that are waiting to be discovered. The game's visuals and sound design are also impressive, further immersing you in the game's world.

The gameplay mechanics in Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion are intuitive and enjoyable, with a wide range of character classes and abilities to choose from. The game's combat system is enjoyable but rough, and the game also features a unique leveling system that rewards you for using different skills and abilities.

Another feature of the whole Elder Scrolls series is the game's rich lore, which is both deep and complex. The game's numerous factions, each with their own unique storylines, provide a wealth of content for players to explore and enjoy.

As a fan of RPGs, I have played many games over the years, but only a few have ignited similar feelings to Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion. Kingdom Come: Deliverance is one of those few games, with its own unique take on immersive world-building and engaging gameplay mechanics which I'd also recommend to those who enjoy this game.

On its own this game is certainly good! Has a pretty solid main story doesn't drag too much. The voice acting ranged from decent to pretty good I think. The dungeons were often fun too except the oblivion gates which got very repetitive very fast. I also found the world is pretty plain and not all that fun to explore, especially when compared to skyrim or fallout 3. The combat was pretty boring and repetitive as well, although that could be because I almost always prefer to play weapon-based classes instead of magic-based ones in games like this, but I have heard that apparently this game has pretty interesting magic system so maybe it is more fun going that route. I also wish the pc version had controller support. I mostly play on tv and using mouse and keyboard binds with a controller feels a bit awkward. I ended up finishing the game on my xbox because of this.

If you like open world rpgs, especially bethesda ones, then you will probably like this game. I imagine with mods, this game could be improved a ton, but I just played the vanilla version. Overall not amazing to me, but was worth the time to finish the main story.

What can I say after playing it for 300 hours in 2023.  Did I like it? Of course. It's great.  I played it for 3 or 4 hours back in 2007 on the Xbox, and put off playing it through until I had a few weeks of free time, and a computer advanced enough to really enjoy it.

Yes, I waited too long (16 years), but after reading so many articles by people saying how much better it was then even Skyrim, I wanted to do a deep dive into it.  It has flaws, and painful redundant moments of grinding if you want to be able to do certain things, but they aren't terrible. 

I installed 3 major mods, one graphics based, one for the interface, and one to fix bugs, so perhaps I'd have much bigger complaints if I didn't, but at this point it makes sense to install things that don't really change gameplay, only just improve the experience.

Instead of trying to 'finish' the game, I ended up starting the main quest, and then switching over to finishing all the individual guild quests. Several of these quests are considered the most fun things to do in the game.

My biggest struggle with the game is how it is a bit too hard in the beginning and a bit too easy at the end, due to the way your character's advance in levels. This is a well known problem so reading up on how to best maximize your stats and not level up too quickly is a requirement to being able to play it through well.

Behold the great RPG experiment of the 2000s. This game was buoyed on so many promises about immersive character interactions and exploratory wonder, and they came true in a "child god's janky first universe" kind of way. Yes, the AI governing the NPC's behavior is the exact opposite of seamless and will constantly produce bizarre emergent interactions and bugs. Yes, when they talk to each other it sounds inane and alien. Yes, this game has a billion voice lines and they were all recorded by half a dozen voice actors, with no context, in alphabetical order. Yes, everyone looks like a potato at the best of times, including your PC. But these are *features*. This game is a goofy delight. This game knows what it's doing and will lean right into it. There's even some epic adventure at the heart of all that jank. Just take a lot at some of the essential mods out there like a UI fix for high resolutions and a bugfix patch and see what you might need to make it playable to you. It even comes with the horse armor! They used to make you pay extra for that!

The best in the series as far as atmosphere and story goes. Gameplay is a little rough if you're used to newer games- at least it is hard for me to go back and play for the first couple of hours. I definitely recommend this title if you like adventure games such as Zelda or Skyrim. Some of the dungeons feel copied and pasted, but some of them are quite unique. In terms of quality of play, this game is very easy to get lost in for hours, and is actually quite immersive, though I would recommend just playing with the brightness up, as some caves and dungeons can be very dark, and in-game lights don't add a whole lot. Haven't played with mods, but I have hundreds of hours on several characters, prior to purchasing through steam. The DLC is awesome.

The open world, the main and side quests, and even the faces to me are what makes this game phenomenal. I enjoyed every second of what I played and I'm sure you will too. 10/10, would recommend to everyone.

The quintessential early 2000s RPG PC experience. In today's gaming world, it still holds a place in the RPG world for its rare balance of well-preserved graphical wizardry and its smorgasbord of quaint bugs and glitches that make every playthrough unique and funny. Enough to show you the wonders of what the game can do, but enough madness to remind you that's it's just a game and to enjoy the weirdness the AI can write as well as the brilliant questlines the team at Bethesda can.

Modern games only aspire to have the longevity of TES IV and to be remembered as fondly... and there's good reason for it.

UPDATE 3 YEARS LATER

I played Skyrim first, and I like this one better. Though to be fair, I am not playing Vanilla. I am now using the standard Through the Valleys mod collection. That out of the way, this game has more physics. Better quest design. Better level design. More advanced NPC technology. Even more complex game mechanics. For example, weapons actually need to be repaired, similar to Fallout 3 and New Vegas which I personally prefer to the way things are handled in Skyrim and Fallout 4. Lock-picking is also different, and more challenging. At first, I didn't like this older style of lock-picking but I am finally starting to get the hang of it (listen for the sound). Personally, I would prefer a game that has both styles of lock-picking based upon the type of lock and/or it's difficulty.

My favourite Elder Scrolls game no doubt about it! I wasn't able to appreciate Morrowind when it originally launched which is why this game was my first step into The Elder Scrolls series and it remains my most memorable one. I've played over 500 hours worth on my Xbox 360 several years ago which is what I'm basing my recommendation on.

You have to remember it came after Morrowind but before Skyrim, so while it added a lot QoL changes after Morrowind it also lacks a lot of what Skyrim eventually came to offer.

So you've got your open world concept which is done well, lots of NPCs to mingle with, plenty of dungeons to plunder and explore, the map is quite large and although the game looks a bit rough these days, it still has a certain charm to it that I appreciate to this day.

It still remains at the top of my list for favourite open world games that encourages taking your time to explore and speak with everyone. If you played Skyrim you might feel like it's missing something and I wouldn't blame you but it is worth the time to at least play through once.

The Principalities have sparkled as gems in the black reaches of Oblivion since the First Morning. Many are their names and the names of their masters: The Coldharbour of Meridia, Lyg, now Molag Bal’s realm, Peryite’s Quagmire, the ten Moonshadows of Mephala, and… and Dawn’s Beauty, the Princedom of Lorkhan… misnamed ‘Tamriel’ by deluded mortals. Yes, you understand now. Tamriel is just one more Daedric realm of Oblivion, long since lost to its Prince when he was betrayed by those that served him. Lord Dagon cannot invade Tamriel, his birthright! He comes to liberate the Occupied Lands!
At this point, if you're thinking about playing Oblivion, you probably know what you're in for. Just like all the other main Elder Scrolls games, it's great.

Some of the best quests, atmosphere, and music I have ever seen in gaming. No game does it quite as well as Oblivion, and I wish there was more of it.

Its simply the best Elder Scrolls game. It has easily the bests quests of any ES game, the mages guild quest line beats out every single quest in skyrim combined. The story in Oblivion is unmatched, not even Morrowind can tell a better story and I love Morrowind. The story of Oblivion makes you feel like a badass Daedra slayer without making you 'the chosen one' like in skyrim and Morrowind. Hell, you start off in some rinky-dink ass dungeon, and the only way you escape is because some old fart recognized you in his dream.

 While it becomes a drag in the later game, the combat is fun and streamlined, and it allows for more diverse play styles compared to skyrim. Oblivion isn't perfect, however; the AI and level scaling are absolutely horrendous. While the AI can be funny, the god-awful level scaling makes even the most experience player not want to level up.

But despite its flaws, Oblivion has the best Story, Quests, and some of the best combat in the Elder Scrolls. If you like action RPG's at all, then play Oblivion, you don't even have to play any other Elder Scrolls games to understand it, you can just jump in and get started. I couldn't recommend this game enough, just play it already!

Morrowind was the first TES game I played, the second was Skyrim. I loved both, though I had a hard time getting into Oblivion after playing Skyrim. I do recommend Oblivion, but I would rate it lower than both Morrowind and Skyrim.

After several aborted attempts, I finally managed to complete the game (or at least, the parts of it that I wanted to experience, which were the main quest, the Thieves Guild questline, and the Dark Brotherhood questline). My playtime reflects that, but you could easily get 80+ hours from this with a more thorough playthrough or multiple playthroughs. 
 
There are some things you may want to know before playing (especially with regard to how leveling works), outlined [url=https://beforeiplay.com/index.php?title=The_Elder_Scrolls_IV:_Oblivion]here[/url]. Detailed leveling explanation [url=https://en.uesp.net/wiki/Oblivion:Leveling]here[/url].

As with most Bethesda games, the experience can be improved by mods. Everything from unofficial bug fix patches (that fix over 2,000 bugs), to UI improvements, and more. Console commands are also handy if/when glitches occur (e.g. "tcl" to toggle clippling if your character gets stuck). 

Note for Linux users: The game runs fine on Linux with Proton, however modding is a bit trickier. SteamTinkerLaunch supports the Vortex Mod Manager and makes modding easier.

I'm puffing on Cyrodiil shadow garden grown in the darkest depths of Oblivion. The soil was enriched with the souls of 36 Daedric lords, and the buds are so black they make the void look like a rainbow. This strain will have you seeing visions of the Mad God himself. It's so potent that it can disable even the most powerful enchanted pacemakers. The sourness is like a Daedric prince's curse on your lungs. This necromancer kush is so deadly, it can raise the dead. The buds are studded with Daedric diamonds, making the THC to CBD ratio more powerful than Mehrunes Dagon's fury. Just a whiff of this strain will transport you straight to the Shivering Isles. This nefarious evil sorcerer moon grass is not of this world; it's straight from The plains of oblivion. This strain is what killed the lucien lachance. May he rest in peace.

I didn't think I would play this game much because it was full of bugs and performance issues. I also didn't like at first the fact that the enemies evolve with the main character's level but the overall gameplay formula of this game is very good considering all the details of the game. 

I got some improvement in unusual performance issues with the old "Shutter Remover" mod and there are also unofficial paths in the form of community mods that propose to fix some bugs in the game.

The most obvious problem with this game is the fact that the HDR option is broken (causes a blue screen ingame, you can't see anything else) at the moment, without using any fixes, and this HDR if I remember correctly is marked as default in the game's high quality option, which can lead to many cases of a new player getting to know the game right away with a problem right at the beginning.

Recommended if you like some gameplay detail that is in this "Oblivion" that is not in "Skyrim" or also for example if you want to collect the entire Elder Scrolls series. I bought this one instead of "Skyrim" because my PC is weak, if you prefer better graphics, a more updated game, you better buy "Skyrim".

Being conducted on a mostly vannila edition of the game, no spoilers,dlc for the newbies that might be coming from other newer projects

Setting: Cyrodil, (Imperial Providence.)
Background: The Emperor, and His Bloodline, are under the Attack of a cult belonging a Deadric Lord, Mehrunes Dagon, and a Human Leading it. The Player is tasked with both finding and protecting the last heir, and ultimatly stopping said lord,
(Non DLC).
Type:Old School AD&Dish Fantasy.Sandbox,Dungeon Crawler
World Size:Not as big as Skyrim. but it does make up for it other ways.

Pros - Make Your Own Character, Abusable Level Cap,,Create A Class,complete with Sign, Perks are giving with most skills. Adjustable Difficulty. VERY Low System Requirements, alot of the useless skillsets have been dismissed from its predeccesors, Morrowind and Daggerfall, and Simplefiled to a degree, although a few arguably still exist, Still somewhat moddable,but bear in mind its still old, and some mods made no longer be updated, multiple questlines,guilds to persue,land to own, sidequests, Dungeons Crawling, (For Some) Level,Item,Dungeon,Enemy Scaling),Fame/Karma/Imfamy Systems in play. ,some puzzles with guilds, but can be looked up wikis if problems gave, and everything, resets in 3 Days,Interior, Exterior,Dungeons,shops,it works well here. Gold on shopkeepers Dosent Run out, but there is a max on them,Dynamic World, very few radiant quests,still a companion system to a degree.
 
Mixed: (Unmodded) Graphical Errors, Stat raises under vanilla can prove to be a pain at times,For Some, Older Graphics, Older Mods, For Some,Scaling, some quests require Fame, or Infamy, Some Minigames may be a little offsetting at first to some. ,for newer players in the series (IE Skyrim), the durability and repair system might be a bit awarkward. (For some) the combat system a bit dated. (But can also, be modded.) 

Cons - Omnipocent Guards, Unmodded parts can cause some problems, usually not enough however to break the main, undlced quest,Scaling again for some,some bugs...

usually most problems can be fixed with a console. if you also need it there is also an unnoficial patch.

Price For Content Verdict, Very High.
Game Originally Made:2006. older game, smaller audience.
Expected Game Time: as long as the player would like (Near Infinity).

The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion is an action role-playing game developed by Bethesda Game Studios and released in 2006. The game is the fourth installment in the Elder Scrolls series and takes place in the fictional province of Cyrodiil.

Oblivion features an open world where players can freely explore the province of Cyrodiil, completing various quests and engaging in combat with enemies. The game's main story revolves around the player character, who must close the Oblivion Gates that have opened up around the province and prevent the demon-like creatures known as Daedra from invading.

One of the strengths of Oblivion is its depth and complexity. The game features a wide range of skills and abilities that can be developed over time, allowing players to customize their characters in a variety of ways. The game's quests are also varied and engaging, with a mix of main story missions and side quests that offer plenty of content for players to explore.

The game's graphics, while somewhat dated by modern standards, were impressive for their time and still hold up reasonably well today. The game's soundtrack is also excellent, with a mix of ambient and orchestral music that helps to set the tone for the game's various locations and encounters.

However, there are some downsides to Oblivion. The game's AI can be somewhat wonky at times, with NPCs sometimes behaving in odd or unrealistic ways. The combat system can also feel clunky, particularly for players who are used to more modern action RPGs.

Overall, The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion is a classic of the genre that is still worth playing today. Its depth, variety, and immersive world make it a game that can keep players engaged for hours on end. While it may not be perfect, it is a game that any fan of action RPGs should definitely check out.

Skyrim has always been my favorite game growing up and still is to this day. I decided to pick up Oblivion to help better myself around the Elder Scrolls Lore, have a new game to play and have the ability to watch Oblivion videos on Youtube. After playing a handful of hours of Oblivion and actually getting into the game, it made me realize that I like Skyrim as much as i do because of Nostalgia, now Skryim is still absolutely amazing, but I think Oblivion is the better game. The quests are much more comprehensive and feel less of, go fetch this for me and I will reward you, that Skyrim has. When questing I find myself talking to more people to gather informative and get clues. In Skyrim most of the Lore is written on books and stuck on Bookshelves that barely get read and gather dust. Although I only have 26 hours I feel I have learned so much about the Lore and i'm yet to pick up a book. NPC'S have random conversations with one another which makes them feel more alive (Regardless of the fact that their conversations are sour and robotic). I keep on noticing things that spark my interest in this game and it's making me realize what I have been missing out on. I CANNOT wait to continue playing and learning more about this masterpiece of a game.

I have played All of the main games. I have beaten 1 Arena,2 Daggerfall, 4 Oblivion, 5 Skyrim. And In my opinion it is The best game of the decade it was released in. (I have tried playing morrowind but I am waiting for Skywind to really try it)

I like many people played this game on a different platform years ago. And Rest assured the real Time I have spent playing this game is in the upper 100s if not low thousands.

It is not Skyrim by any means, but it IS worth playing through at least once thoroughly.

I will start off with the Cons then go into the Pros

Cons(IE things that can be fixed Easily with mods... Except the main story)
-Combat is a grind. If you play this on Vanilla I would not play above normal as it turns combat into a Complete Grind, Both Time wise, as well as Equipment Wise.
-Equipment Durabilty Is absolute trash. Do not get me wrong you can deal with it, but Man is it an annoyance.
-Main story Kind of Sucks.
---I literally avoid starting it in every subsequent play through, as it adds in gates. Which suck hardcore after the first few. Heck I have only ever finished it once, and Man... Bleh, Lame.
-Leveling your character actually turns out to be a Bad idea "Shrugs" and can actually make the game Unplayable if done poorly.
-NPC/Player models are... Playdoughy Though there is fun to be had here :)
-Some glitches/Bugs
-Dynamic/Leveled World Enemies(Why the poopershnigel am I leveling up if I get no reward from it?)
-Nirnroots

Pros
-Oh my goodness The world is/Can be Beautiful. My first game I was traveling at night and stopped on a bridge near the mountains to look out through the trees and saw the Imperial city sitting under the stary night with Moons hovering over it.   10/10 Was amazing. The Scenery is absolutely wonderful elsewhere and I think it is better in this regard to anything in Skyrim.
-Missions are fairly diverse Some story lines are repetitive.
-I enjoy dungeon Delving and This game offers a lot of it. (Some people hate the Dungeon designs but I think they are great)
-Moddable to death.
-This game is Art.
-Is really cheap when On sale for Possibly 100s of hours of gameplay.

Side notes. I do recommend some mods. Here are things to Make better. 
***TBH I would change these even before playing through a vanilla run.***
***Some mods require third party Mod Loaders, It can be a hassle but I have never personally had a problem with any of them.***
-Find one that changes the level up system to suite your taste. I have seen some "Fallout" Style ones, some that Changes it to Passive level ups with attributes auto given. There are plenty of options.
-Find one that Makes enemies' levels Static. Sure it stops you from exploring some areas early on. But Killing an Archlich at level one with ease only to run in fear of A Rat at level 50 is just stupid.
-Find one that Changes enemies to be less Damage Spongey. There are plenty of mods to choose from. (This also fixes Equipment Degradation to a degree)
***End of These are Must Mod Changes In Tony's(My) opinion***
-Get a mod that Displays Actual HP of enemies. The base *HP bar* on enemies is Just annoying and not really helpful.
-I always found the User Interface(UI) to be alright as I used a controller, but if you play with mouse and Keyboard people love to be vitriolic about the base UI so Maybe if you want to... find a UI Mod. But to be honest they have always been more trouble than they were worth in my opinion.

-I have never once found an NPC makeover mod that escaped the Curse of the Dough. Explore at your own peril.
-All of the "New lands" Mods I have tried have uhh... Been really bad. But I suppose that is part of their charm?

Tips.
-Always Keep Multiple saves of the same run. IE Never save over your previous save without having a few hours of backup saves. This sucks as I Really hate having a bunch of save files, BUT it is REALLY worth it trust me.
-If you screw up in a guild and have to do their "Filthy long Fetch Quests" Just reload a save as they are just annoying mass fetch quests that offer nothing of value.
-If you want an easier game Make use of Spell Making for Skills. IE Armorer +100 for 1 second is long enough to repair EVERYTHING EVER if it is in your inventory.

The end. 

                                                                                                 Sincerely
                                                                    Your Loving Supreme Overlord and Emperor Tony

- More interesting magic than vanilla Skyrim, less obtuse than Morrowind's magic.

Months passed, and I finally got the money for an Xbox 360 and Oblivion. After months of hard work dreaming of playing Oblivion for myself I got the console only for it not to work and be filled with sawdust for some reason, I cried that night and it was a life lesson.

Holy fuck i never reviewed oblivion! Before we knew the term meme, before we crawled into the ooze that is modern gaming, we had some true transcendent experiences. Oblivion is simultaneously responsible for my fat distribution, bad back, and love of nature, all incongruous elements of my being that were forged in the proto memes that were stockpiled on the border of cyrodil. There are uncountable hours, thought provoking and wasteful at the same time. i can never get this time back, but i would never want it back. I will still willingly dive into this game for another 1000 hours every 10 years if it meant that the game was going to evolve at the same clip that it has. Charmingly stupid, deeper than the modern kiddy pool, somehow still enormous mod scene. Classic classic classic. 10/10 heartbreak feels good in a place like this

Awesome

Oblivion. Where to even start? 
1. The graphics are stellar. I have never seen a game hold up so while through the years. 
2. The soundtrack. Nothing immerses you more in a game than the music and Oblivion does not hold back. It feels like you are actually traveling through an enchanted forest: like you can smell the clean air, and feel the breeze on your skin and the weight of your armor. The dreadful heavy music that comes up when you're facing a boss is just amazing. 
3. The storyline is really in-depth and well done. The endless side quests that get you experience and materials.
4. The leveling up system is the best. One thing I would take away from this game is how you level as a player. Want to improve your sneak and thievery? You have to use those specific skills. You do not get level-up points to put into specific attributes. You have to use those skills to get good with them.

In my personal opinion, this game is the weakest out of Morrowind, Oblivion, and Skyrim. The rpg aspects are good, but the game has aged quite poorly. NPC’s sometimes use 5 different voice actors in one character, for example, giving gold to a beggar and asking for rumors to the same beggar will sometimes have a completely different voice. This is quite immersion breaking. I know that Skyrim has a lot of the same voice actors, but it doesn’t have the issue of one specific character having a trillion voice actors.

The game is a bit glitchy, and was the first roots planted in the game industry for MTX (horse armor dlc).

In this game, you aren’t really the main hero, Martin is. You just help him fulfill his challenge of defeating the main villain. You’re essentially a playable side character in the main storyline.

HOWEVER, for some positives, while it is true that you’re essentially the side character to Martin’s journey, the story is still fairly fun to play through. The quests are fun, the guilds are cool, the main complaint I have is that the dungeons are repetitive, HOWEVER, every elder scrolls game has that, so I won’t hold it against Oblivion.

Overall, I feel like in 2006, this was a masterpiece. But to 2023 standards, especially compared to Skyrim, my personal favorite TES game, it doesn’t match up well, while Skyrim has aged perfectly in my opinion. I’ve been playing continuously for ten years, while for oblivion, I just don’t feel that way that I do for Skyrim and Morrowind. Not a bad game, just not the best either.

Even by the graphical standards of 2006, it looked a bit dodgy, and nowadays it’s hideous, with no shortage of potato-faced NPCs, but look past the surface and you’ll find a spectacular world. While many consider Morrowind to be the pinnacle of the Elder Scrolls series (and I would agree that it’s an excellent game), Oblivion, for me, achieved that sweet-spot trade-off between player quality-of-life and narrative complexity. 

Mechanically speaking, Oblivion polished the template laid down by Morrowind and made it an outstanding continuation of the Elder Scrolls franchise, introducing fast travel, a new map system, improved quest logs, more advanced dialogue trees, voice acting, and a more vibrant colour palette. Morrowind undoubtedly had a more sophisticated narrative, but the clunkiness of the game itself made it so much harder to get into, particularly as I came to it in retrospect. 
Likewise, Skyrim (Oblivion’s successor) is a thrill to play, but I feel some of that RPG quality was lost in the gap as the studio made the leap to mainstream popularity and accessibility. Oblivion, however, sits directly in the middle, neither as mainstream as Skyrim or as niche as Morrowind – which is perhaps why it’s often overlooked in favour of either of those two. 

Many of the games I’ve recommended on Steam have a common quality – when I think back, I immediately picture particular scenes from them whenever their names are mentioned. Whether it’s Final Fantasy’s Midgar, The Silent Cartographer of Halo, or even Ostrheinsburg Castle in Soulcalibur, for me the environment and the ‘feel’ of the game is often the important part. Very few action scenes or even character moments have lodged in memory in that same way. Oblivion is a game replete with these seminal moments. 

This isn’t to wax lyrical about a game with flaws, of course. Oblivion suffers from the Bethesda problem of “quantity over quality” in many regards, particularly in the case of the titular Oblivion Gates, which are style over substance and rapidly become the most tedious part of the game – which is a real shame. But the game itself is full of memorable scenes and stories. I’ll never forget cresting a hill in the middle of the verdant countryside, only for the sky to turn crimson as a foreboding Oblivion gate comes into view; or the first step into the Shivering Isles, where Haskill’s grey room disintegrates in a shower of butterflies to open out onto a vast, primordial landscape; the moment in the Fighter’s Guild questline when you go back to the sleepy town of Water’s Edge and discover what really happened there; the treasure-hunt come murder-mystery that is ‘Whodunit?’ (and for that matter all the rest of the Dark Brotherhood quests); the hauntingly-memorable Daedric Prince quests. Too much about this game is great to justify spoiling it with the bad parts – and if that’s inconsistent, I don’t mind.

I may be blinded by nostalgia but I absolutely adore this game, from its genuinely awesome moments to the NPCs being kinda wacky. Oblivion may feel like a cracked out fever dream sometimes but that's why I love the game. Although it crashes from time to time I've never really lost much progress and most of the time when I do its easy to make up. I 100% recommend the game to anyone, fans of The Elder Scrolls or not. Its such a wonderful game to just wander through despite the old graphics the settings are still beautiful, and the soundtrack only amplifies the experience whether its the serene beauty of a forest or the eerie air of a decrepit ruin to music to amplify the feeling of being locked in an epic battle. I love all the skills you can level to build a unique experience for the different builds one may try or the different characters you may make for the world of the game. From heavy hitter to the stealthy assassin or a frail but powerful mage and everything in between. There's plenty of side quests and places to explore alongside the DLC if you don't care much for the Main Quest or want something else to do. 

Again, maybe I'm biased by my nostalgia in my love for this game but I love it nonetheless.

Kind of considered the red-haired middle child of the family between cult favourite Morrowind and polished pedestrian pleaser Skyrim, people make scrunched up little baby faces if you mention Oblivion like weehhh wehhh the bloom lighting, wehhhh weehhhh potato faces, wehhhh wehhhhhh levelled loot, because they're cowards and it's actually a very good game. Virtually every quest, even the hum-drum ones, have some kind of twist in them. Very few of them ever solely send you off to clear dungeons- you're going to be mostly travelling, sleuthing and convincing.

Tries a few new things for the time: mechanicalizes speech into a minigame like lockpicking (but they didn't tutorialize it so people complain about it without knowing how it works), gives characters meaningful routines that affect or can be affected by the player.

There are multiple factions to join and things to pursue, none of which feel like a participation award. You can build an interesting character, you're not forced to become stealth archer. 

The game looks good- in some or most lighting conditions.

Overall it's a shame that Bethesda walked back some of the braver risks they took with this game, and that it's now looked back upon as kind of banal because of everything that's come since.

Oblivion, it's the misunderstood middle child of The Elder Scrolls franchise (more specifically the big 3). Oblivion for me personally, was the soft middle ground between Morrowind and Skyrim. Like the other games in this franchise Oblivion has some flaws and faults mostly just the voice acting and dungeon designs feeling copy pasted. A man can only loot so many ayleid ruins and decrepit fortresses full of claymation looking models so many times. 
Oblivion still holds onto the skill system from earlier titles while managing to not be too much to take in for newer players. It removed the "RNG" combat that Morrowind was notorious for and stripped down the attacks to your basic light attacks and directional power attacks, a stark contrast to Morrowinds diverse weapon attacks.
Oblivion has allot of interesting and thoughtfully constructed quests that take you to a lot of interesting places, I think oblivion has some of the best and most memorable quests and characters in the franchise. It's easy to get stuck on how doughy and plastic everything looks but make no mistake.
Under the over saturated color palette and doughy characters, medicore and sometimes down right awful voice acting, D tier dungeons and the worst leveling system in the franchise there is allot of fun and enjoyment to be had with this game.

This is the first game I ever played on Xbox 360, and even today it holds up as an excellent game. I like it more than Skyrim even, because although having choices and fluidity in your class is a good thing, I like how Oblivion wants you to stick to one method, but perfect it. Become the ultimate mage, warrior, thief, assassin, monk, whatever you choose. "The game looks bad," yeah this game is from 2005, it is almost 20 years old, yeah it is gonna look terrible. I remember booting this game up and thinking "Wow, these graphics look so real!" Here I am though, still obsessed with all the side quests, factions, and places to explore in Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion. This is a perfect game for the Steam Deck, as I wish I could play this more often. Can't wait to get into the 200 - 300 hours range of this game.

I've always had a hard time nailing down which Elders Scrolls I consider the best. From game to game there isn't much difference but over the span of the games I've played (Elder Scrolls 2 Daggerfall to 5 Skyrim) ... there's quite a bit different. I'm sure everybody has their own list but (with mods and everything considered) I think Oblivion is the best. With Daggerfall Unity I'd have to say that's my second favorite. I really like Morrowind but somehow missed out on it when it was out so for me I have a hard time getting use to the jankyness of it sometimes and Skyrim always feels like a chore to play. Like it's laborious.

Over Skyrim, Oblivion has a better story line, better character progression (you aren't a dragon god from the beginning of the game for example), slightly better combat, MUCH MUCH better cities (I mean Skyrim doesn't even feel like an Elders Scrolls game when it comes to the settlements), better terrain overall (Not everything is at the top of its own individual mountain), and I've never had the main campaign irrevocably fall into a dead end. 

The graphics aren't as great but can be greatly improved upon with mods and I'll always hate how an NPC will be shouting in anger one sentence only to return to the default smile pose then get super serious the next. Really takes you out of the immersion. Still the best.

I have always been critical of Skyrim for taking itself too seriously and leaves itself too gray but I have the opposite concern with Oblivion. Oblivion staunchly refuses to take itself seriously at all. (Except ironically in the sections where you would not expect... looking at you Sheo!) Morrowind was always on point with its ability to take itself seriously enough to be engaging but also lean back and crack jokes at its own expense.

Oblivion feels like a game that is apologetic for its own existence. It shouldn't be. Oblivion, despite its flaws, is a remarkable and fun experience... and it can be downright beautiful at times.

I just love getting lost and wandering in this world. I've come back to this game at least once a month for the last 4 or so years. It's fun enough that I keep coming back after small breaks. It's got some flaws depending on what you like in a game or what frustrates you, but you can really get a ton of mileage with mods.

I'd recommend this game mainly to devote fans of Bethesda games and those who have played Skyrim and want more of the Elder Scrolls series. The games graphics are a bit infamous for aging poorly as by today's standards they are pretty ugly (especially the faces). There are also some confusing/ odd game mechanics such as having to sleep to level up or enemies leveling with the player to the point where leveling too much can drastically increase difficulty. The other main issue is that dungeons/ caves are very copy paste in design which makes exploration of these areas rather dull. The story, however, is top notch and the main reason I stuck with this game. There are also tons of cool side quests like most Bethesda games. Additionally, I found exploring the major city areas rather fun and immersive. It is definitely worth playing for hardcore fans of the Elder Scrolls series but not for not for most other gamers in my opinion. This game certainly paved the way for modern open-world RPGs and its impact on future Bethesda games was immense so I have to give credit there. I'd personally give this game a 6/10.

An absolute classic. It was cutting-edge for the year it came out (2006 wow I’m getting old) but frankly the graphics don’t look much worse than games now, aside from the NPCs. I remember being on the edge of my seat watching my friends play. Played it myself a couple years later, then again in 2015 and now again in 2021 to prepare for the Elder Scrolls VI release later this year (hopefully!). 

Someone below reviewed that the gameplay was clunky. Not really though. Nothing like older school games, such as Resident Evil 4. 

What you should play for primarily, is the story. This game has one of the most memorable main quests and side quests of all time. 

Yes the AI isn’t great, but it’s by no means game ruining. Yes the graphics are older, but they’re still pretty dang good. No this isn’t an FPS, so the combat system isn’t perfect, but it is by no means boring considering there are many diff play styles you can incorporate into your gameplay. Some of the complaints I’ve seen are totally valid, but they will never overshadow the story. 

Will always recommend this, as well as Morrowind and Skyrim. It’s a fantastic series.

As someone who played Skyrim first, I though Oblivion was also pretty good. It is a bit less linear, in the sense you can gain aid from cities in any order, but the story is definitely more of a railroad than Skyrim.

While the game isn't extraordinarily pretty, it was good enough to where I didn't bother to install graphics mods. I didn't really have any technical issues and it never lagged for me.

Overall: +1

An all-time great and classic. Even after all this time, I can always find some form of amusement in playing Oblivion. While very much ahead of its time, it's also somehow both charming and very hilarious in some of its more dated instances. When it's good, it's great, and when it's bad, it's endless comedy in an endearing type of way. There is so much fun to be had with this game, I would even insist I prefer it to most of Bethesda's newer releases. Amazing replay value, and even in one playthrough you'll find yourself keeping busy for hours and hours on in. It still hooks me, it still challenges me, and it still makes me laugh. I have nothing but praise for a game like this, especially when all the ways it could be considered flawed are so absolutely enjoyable. There really aren't many ways that Oblivion can do wrong for me. I've found this to be true even after all these years.
