I got this game on Steam as a bit of nostalgia. Elder Scrolls IV Oblivion with its expansions was one of the first games I got for the Xbox 360 and I put at least 100+ hours on that copy of the game. This game is a joy to play with a wonderful amount of main quests, secondary quests, and simple side quests to keep a player busy. 

The game world itself is a wonderful balance between breath and depth. You feel that locations on the map are just far enough apart to give the sense of distance without it being tedious to move around. While you start off with the main cities on the map, it is up to you to find everything else by exploring the world. Combat was amazing when the game was first released and is still very respectable at this time. The replay value is also very high with the mix of Races/Classes/Birthsigns giving you very different play-through each time.    
 
Now, there are a few things any RPG game lover will need to consider before buying this game. The first is that this game came out in 2006. That means that the graphics, while very good for there time and still rather nice, are dated compared to other games out there. Elder Scrolls V Skyrim being a prime example. There is also the fact that there have been changes in the Elder Scroll series between the various editions. If you have first played Elder Scrolls V you might find some of these shifts noticeable at first. 

None of the changes mean that Elder Scrolls IV is "worse" or "better" than its sequel or other more modern RPG games available. They instead reflect a difference in both design and style that has changed throughout the years. A prime example of this is the leveling system Elder Scrolls IV uses which is tied to 7 "major" skills and you level up as you improve these skills. Furthermore, you need to rest to level up once you meet the requirements. This is actually rather useful because it allows you to work the "minor" skills so that all your stats level up higher than if you automatically leveled up. 

If you are a RPG game lover you will want to add this game to your collection. You may also want to consider this game if you are interested in seeing if the RPG style game is right for you. Even without a sale you get dozens of hours of enjoyable game play at a very good deal. The relatively minimal hardware requirements compared to modern games in this style is also good for someone looking for a fun game without being a big gamer or having a gaming computer.

When I was but a wee lass, I was gifted an Xbox 360 for the holidays. Alongside the console was 1-3 games, one being The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion. I had never heard of this game, but I booted it up to appease the person who gifted this to me, and low and behold… it was like the clouds parted and the warm light of the RPG Gods smiled upon me that day.

All dramatics aside, this game has been quite legitimately life changing for me, personally. It has shaped the way I tell stories, it has changed the way I approach RPGs and TTRPGs. This game introduced me to dynamic characters, shocking plot twists, and an immersive lore-rich world that is unlike any other. I know that everyone talks about Skyrim being a work of art, but you are truly missing out on some of the best storytelling of your life here, buddy. Nearly every quest is absolutely enthralling. The Dark Brotherhood quest line will have your jaw on the floor. You thought the Theives Guild in Skyrim was wild, buckle up, buttercup.

I really can not recommend this game enough. You have to put your grown up pants on and suffer with some crummy graphics, but it’s worth it. I would almost advise against modding this for your first play through, because honestly some of the bugs and absurd character face designs are just too funny to miss out on. The good is GREAT and the bad is funny. Glitching through the floorboards is endearing in most instances, and it’s really a small price to pay for how amazing this game is. Please do give it a shot because otherwise, you’re really missing out.

[h1] Don't skip this assuming it's inferior to Skyrim; in many ways, it's the better game [/h1]
The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion is the game that set the template for modern Bethesda games (both the Elder Scrolls and Fallout series), and (because the formula was so successful) modern open world games in general.  Like any modern open world game, you always have access to an in-game map with quest markers shown clearly all over the place; you will never get lost.

In some games, this doesn't work well and you feel like you're just following the arrow from one objective to the next.  Oblivion does the same thing, but the quests are varied and interesting enough that it somehow works.  It helps that there are actually very few of the typical "collect five rat tails" kind of quests you find in lesser games.

Oblivion has a very satisfying main quest, but it's also very enjoyable to just roam around exploring and setting your own goals.  As you wander around town, you'll see and hear NPCs having conversations with one another; listening to these can sometimes even clue you in to optional quests.  It's a very cool touch and makes the world feel a bit more believable, even if the conversations end up becoming complete ridiculous the longer you listen to them (they are not scripted, but somewhat random).
[hr][/hr]
Oblivion is somewhat infamous for its level scaling mechanic.  In short, enemies and loot are all scaled to your character level only.  However, you skills only advance though use, and so this can place you into a difficult situation where your level is high but your important skills are weak; meanwhile, all the monsters in the game have scaled up your high level.  There are several ways around this, but here's what I recommend:

Create a custom class and tag the skills you WON'T use as your major skills.  Your character only gains experience toward leveling up when he uses a major skill, so you can stay at a low level while your useful skills continue to improve.  I used this strategy and ended up completing the game at level 2, and the scaling mechanic was never a problem.
[hr][/hr]
Although I was able to complete the main quest (and lots of other content) in only 40 hours, I really only scratched the surface of what this game offers, Oblivion is truly a game you could play for hundreds of hours.  Highly recommended!

I originally played this game on disk, so I probably have close to 300 hours rather than the 60 it says. I originally got the game at 11 and had no idea what RPGs could be. Oblivion was my first Elder Scrolls game, and I got totally engrossed in it. The only thing that eventually turned me away was the level scaling issue, because I did and still hate grinding for levels so that the game wouldn't level faster than me. The level scaling is the single biggest problem in the game, but most of the content can be done at level 1 anyway. Definitely worth the money, you'll have sunk at least a 100 hours before you rage quit from the idiotic leveling system.

[h1]Introduction:[/h1]
Oblivion is an open-world role-playing game developed by Bethesda Game Studios and released in 2006. I decided to play Oblivion because I had heard good things about it and I'm a fan of Bethesda's other games, such as Skyrim and Fallout.

[h1]Gameplay:[/h1]
Oblivion's gameplay involves exploring a vast, detailed world, completing quests and objectives, and leveling up your character's skills and abilities. The controls are generally intuitive and responsive, although there were a few times when I had trouble using the mouse to look around. One unique feature of Oblivion is the ability to create your own spells and enchant your own weapons, which adds an extra layer of customization to the gameplay. During my time playing, I didn't encounter any major bugs or glitches, which is always a plus.

[h1]Story:[/h1]
The story of Oblivion revolves around the player character being chosen as the "Champion of Cyrodiil" to close the gates of Oblivion and stop the invasion of the Daedra. The main story is fairly straightforward, but there are also numerous side quests and activities to keep you occupied. The characters in the game are well-developed and have their own motivations and personalities. The pacing of the story is generally well-done, although there were a few times when it dragged on a bit too long.

[h1]Graphics and Sound:[/h1]
Oblivion's graphics are definitely showing their age at this point, but they still hold up well considering the game is over 15 years old. The landscapes and environments are beautiful and detailed, and the character models and animations are solid. The frame rate was generally smooth, although there were a few instances of minor stuttering. The sound design in Oblivion is also excellent, with a great soundtrack and memorable voice acting.

[h1]Replay Value:[/h1]
Oblivion has a lot of replay value due to the sheer amount of content it offers. There are multiple endings depending on the choices you make throughout the game, and there are also numerous side quests and activities to keep you busy. Additionally, there are multiple difficulty levels to choose from, so you can tailor the game's challenge to your liking.

[h1]Conclusion:[/h1]
Overall, I really enjoyed my time with Oblivion. The gameplay is solid, the story is engaging, and the graphics and sound hold up well despite the game's age. While it does have a few minor flaws, it's still an excellent RPG and I would definitely recommend it to others.

Hello Sharks, I am here today to pitch a game called Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion. Now, I know what you're thinking - another fantasy role-playing game? But trust me, this one is different.

First off, the graphics in Oblivion are absolutely stunning. The environments and characters are richly detailed and really bring the world to life. The gameplay is smooth and immersive, and there's just so much to do and explore.

But what really sets Oblivion apart is the character customization. You can create your own character and choose from a wide variety of races, including humans, elves, and even Khajiit (cat people). And let me tell you, those Khajiit females are seriously hot.

But it's not just about the eye candy - Oblivion is a true test of skill and determination. It'll push you to your limits and then some. But if you've got what it takes, if you're the kind of gamer who doesn't flinch in the face of danger, then this is the game for you.

So Sharks, I'm asking for a $500,000 investment in exchange for a 10% stake in the company. With your help, we can take Oblivion to the next level and make it the biggest role-playing game on the market. Thank you.

Some of my fondest memories in gaming are playing Oblivion. It is jank as hell, but it is so worth the experience. I wish I could sit here and tell you that it is still worth playing in 2022...

But it's not. Not by a long shot. Why?
Because this PC port ala Bethesda is a broken mess of a game riddled with numerous game breaking bugs. Now, don't get me wrong, the original Xbox 360 title HAD game crashing and what not, but this is a little different. We're talking even WHEN I mod the ever loving soul out of this game just to prevent technical issues (Which depending on what random circumstances you have going on, you won't even be able to play this game on PC WITHOUT mods due to compatibility issues), this game still never fails to hit me with an absolutely game busting bug somewhere along its run.

Years ago it was a glitch I happened to get that completely corrupted my game file and would cause it to become terminal; literally crashing ANY time I entered a Save trigger. Even when I edited the files to that I could only manually save, Manual Saves would trigger this crash too. So that file that I had invested 40 hours into already was basically gone.
What happened after that?
Well, my next two saves from last year and now this year were plagued by a time based bug that caused the game to crash, for whatever reason, about 3 minutes after startup without fail. Why? I couldn't tell you, it's Bethesda coding.

This game was always running on duct tape and crafting glue and its port to PC has never failed to do anything but leave an utterly sour taste in my mouth. I WANT to play this game again and get sunk into it like I once did, but I can't. The game LITERALLY won't let me.

Based on the fact that I literally can't play the damn thing for too long before it bricks itself, this gets a big fat thumbs down from me.

So here's a quick story on why I like the game, There I am minding my own business fighting a few gobos in a fort when one goblin warlord just wouldn't die! We even named him, he would be known from that point on as chuckles. I reloaded my save found him again and with the help of some handy mods I was able to keep his rage at bay but he may have become friends with me although all other creatures were met with his rage. This game is one of my all time favorites.
I spent countless hours on the Xbox 360 version of this game, and I still have yet to finish the main story line. Getting lost in the plains of Oblivion, as well as the province of Cyrodil, is ridiculously easy to do. Choose a direction, and walk that way until you find one of the many Ayelid ruins, caves, forts, castles, or settlements. This game is just plain fun.

The graphics are old by today's standards, but I enjoy retro gaming. For me, I like it. The bloom on the Xbox 360 was something you could not turn off, but alas! We can in the PC version! Huzzah! I can tell you that running this game on anything above a zotac zbox en970 will result in a completely maxed out experience. There is one huge drawback with this game, and that is the UI was designed for console first. That can be fixed by installing a mod.
Oh, btw, MASSIVE modding support over on the Nexus. Check that out, if you want.

The controls are useable, and mostly rebindable. However, there are several hidden controls with nothing to refer to them other than in the opening tutorial. (Hold shift and left click to drop an item in menu? Who tf is going to remember that after not playing the game for a few weeks...why can't it be right click to drop, or press q?)

The sound design is both great, and very bad at the same time. The balancing of all the effects is truly awful, and can lead to hearing (or missing) ques to search, attack, or run. The sound effects are more than adequate, as well as the music and voice acting. HOWEVER, all of the above has a very small quantity. There are very few voice actors, the musical score is very small, and most of the sound effects are simply related to the material type without variation. For exaple, a steel sword and a daedric sword have the same sound effect when used, or dropped. That carries across all the items.

This version comes with all of the DLC, including the controversial Horse Armor. seriously, google some gaming news articles related to Horse Armor DLC. After that, come back to Steam, and then sigh, depressed knowing the people who wrote the anti-Horse DLC articles predicted the future.

You want my review here?! How 'bout over there? No? Here? Very well. 

I won't tell you this game is the greatest RPG you can play. It isn't. It has the normal amount of Bethesda bugs that follow it. Which doesn't make it a bad game. 

I am going to assume that you all ready know something about The Elder Scrolls since you're here. (You've most likely played Skyrim and not the others.) 

This is somewhat very different from Skyrim. I don't mean that for the worst either. I'm sure you could ask many others that have followed TES and they would tell you that Bethesda actually tends to remove features from previous games. So, don't expect to have a game that feels exactly like Skyrim. 

I'd say this is my second to almost a tie for favorite in The Elder Scrolls Series. It feels closer to Morrowind than it does Skyrim. To me..it feels like Morrowind upgraded, changed and had a few things taken away.

It's a great game. If you're willing to deal with it's age and the many bugs that are in it. 

If you only like Skyrim for the "Modern" feel. I use that loosely as Skyrim does have some age to it now. I'd say this is a no. 

If you enjoy older games or just really enjoy The Elder Scrolls. I'd say it's a yes. 

You really have to take this game for what it is. It's an early seventh generation game, that's also made by Bethesda. Which I'm not trying to insult them, I enjoy almost all of their games. But, even fans of them have grown to know what to expect.

It's a great game. I hold this title very dear. I have countless amounts of memories with it. So, while I'm not trying to write a review that may seem like I'm pushing you to purchase this title. This truly is more than a game to me. It's a part of my past that is very meaningful to me.

One of the greatest RPGs of all time. Packed full of memorable quests, a fun magic system, and Shivering Isles-- possibly the single greatest DLC to ever be created. It has aged quite well outside of the leveling system and is an absolute blast to this day. You can mod it if you want but in no way does the game require it; the unmodded experience is fantastic.

I have first played Oblivion 15 years ago, in 2007, on a laptop at 720p. I'm not sure how many hours I put into it at that time, but I really enjoyed it. And although my English was way worse at that time, the atmosphere and the lore were so attractive, I felt like I could play this game for hours, and hours, and hours. 14 years later, having a proper gaming rig, I decided to revisit the Oblivion universe, and did not regret it. Although this time I decided to mod the game, since the vanilla visuals aged quite unpleasantly, I still enjoyed the result and invested 200+ hours into play-through of all major quest lines. It is still challenging, especially if you move the difficulty slider even a bit to the Hard side :)

To sum it up:
1. Best side quests and faction quests in any TES game (especially the dark brotherhood)
2. Objectively funniest NPC interactions (radiant AI can be so random, so you might see guards calling their lords something like "uncultured peasant"
3. Worst combat (which can be fixed with mods such as "deadly reflex")
4. Worst level scaling-the damage sponge problem- (which can be fixed with mods such as "deadly reflex")
5. Ugly character models (I REALLY suggest mods)
6. Amazing music, atmosphere, and visuals (for it's time)
7. Endless hours of gameplay after the main quest and faction quests are finished, if you're into dungeon crawling
DON'T install this game if you want to play a game with a deep story, interesting companions, and a movie-like experience.
DO install this game if you want to play a game which is so rich with lore, it makes you stop and read the in-game books, a game in which the main character is the world itself, a sandbox experience which gives you somewhere close to absolute freedom while trying to simulate a living world with immersive simulation aspects.

Where do i even start? Oblivion is one the finest RPG gaming experiences.
I have played 200+ hours in 2019 (With a bunch of mods installed) and still feel there is so much more to do and get lost in the world of Cyrodil.
I always play as an Archer - A Wood Elf in the Elder Scrolls series games or i play as a High Elf as a Pure Mage.  I dont like mindless button mashing of sword fighting. An Archer or a Mage is where its at!
I have finished the following
 - Basic quests given in cities
 - Mages Guild All Quests (You do this first, as you get access to enchantment and spell making)
 - Thieves Guild All Quests (You do this as they are great fun and you get the Cowl of Nocturnal - which is very useful to zip across Cyrodil and the 120 ft Detect Life enchantment)

200+ hours completed and I still have not completed  
- The highly rated Dark Brotherhood Quests 
- The average Fighter Guild Quests
- The super fun Daedric Quests
- The Arena Quests (which i doubt i would do!)
- The Shivering Isles
- The Knights expansion

So Let me update this after i finish the rest!  See you guys in 2023!

[b]Introduction[/b]
Oblivion really is the midway point between Morrowind and Skyrim. It maintains the RPG mechanics from Morrowind but brings it into a new HD age with more responsive combat and physics like Skyrim. Unfortunately, it's weaker than both, featuring none of the mystic and lack of handholding of Morrowind, or the polish and style of Skyrim.

Oblivion is a game that succeeds due to its freedom and despite its endless faults. Still, I wouldn't recommend this unless you've already played Morrowind and Skyrim and really want more. It's much too heavily flawed.

[b]The Great[/b]
++Side quests are way more memorable than Skyrim's.
++So much to do and explore. There's an overwhelming amount of content on offer here.

[b]The Good[/b]
+Looks beautiful for 2006. It's just the character models and animations that let it down.
+Cyrodiil is a wildly different landscape to Skyrim and Morrowind, which makes Oblivion feel distinct.
+Weapons actually hit your opponent when you see them physically hit, as they should (unlike Morrowind).
+Okay RPG mechanics. Too much to go into depth here.
+The DLC's solid.

[b]Mild Issues/Things to Note[/b]
-+No Xbox controller support. Not entirely unusual for 2006 despite the game's release on the Xbox 360, but still annoying. Northern UI fixes this.
+-The Elder Scrolls beyond Morrowind is generic fantasy through and through. Oblivion is the worst of the 3D era games in this regard.
+-Performance is questionable for a game from 2006.
-+Being as they're one of the only ways of healing, and avoiding damage is nearly impossible, I think healing potions are too expensive and uncommon.
+-Enemy health bars do a poor job of actually indicating enemy health.
-+Heresy to say, but... the soundtrack's only okay. I much prefer Morrowind and Skyrim's in all honesty.
+-Sound design is below average.
-+The AI's bad.
+-The main quest is okay.

[b]The Bad[/b]
-Voice acting is just odd. The number of voice actors is tiny and everyone over acts... or sleeps through their lines. They also sound like they're reading the script for the first time as they act. Often times the voices change in different sentences with the same character. Also, why do the beggars have english accents when no one else in the game does? Lastly, there's a single voice actor for all Argonian males, and another actor for all Argonian females... what a joke.
-The lock-picking mini-game blows.
-The speech mini-game is ridiculous.
-This game has no memorable characters.
-The map sucks. Why is it so zoomed in and slow to scroll?
-Some locations are able to be fast travelled to immediately and I'm not sure why. Others require you to physically visit them first even if marked on your map. This makes it hard to explore every part of the map as you're not sure where you have and haven't already been. There's also no indication of what you've already explored and haven't.
-Ghosts are a pain. Why have an enemy that only one class type can destroy (until later stages)? There's no other obvious barrier like this in the game.
-The difficulty slider is complete bullshit. Most players are going to struggle at some point on the medium default difficulty, let alone the lower ends of the slider that turn even rats into absolute damage sponges.
-Enemies will chase you to the end of the earth.
-FOV is tiny by default and requires a mod to change. Console commands won't do the trick here.
-You can't be exclusively a blades man or exclusively a marksman, or you're going to find yourself in positions where you stand no chance. You need to be a combination of things.
-Story is forgettable.
-AI sucks.
-Oblivion portals aren't fun.

[b]The Terrible[/b]
--The world scales around you which is lame. I much prefer visiting areas and finding out I'm in over my head and need to come back when my character is stronger rather than have everything always be a threat whether I'm a peasant or a God. It also turned parts of the main quest into an absolute chore. I reached a roadblock where I was being killed by a single opponent because none of my weapons did any notable damage and hers killed me in 5 hits. This is with me dumping all my skill points into blades and bows. And there were 4 more of her enemy types around the corner. Atrocious difficulty balancing.
--Dungeons have two themes and differ very slightly between each other. They're not fun to explore and they're extremely repetitive. Even the loot is almost always completely useless. They're also quite non-linear but in a bad way, making them slightly confusing to explore.
--Combat is horrible. Archery results in your flinging literally dozens of arrows into an opponent B-lining towards you. Melee results in you being staggered repeatedly and blocking every once in a while, while mindlessly slashing away. There's very little skill or tactics involved in either. I haven't tried magic, but it looks similar. Difficulty spikes can be huge for little discernible reason, healing methods do little and are uncommon, the AI sucks, blocking isn't overly helpful, power attacks take too long to be useful and there's next to no strategy involved in combat.

Content/Replayability: 9/10
Audio: 3.5/10
Graphics: 6.5/10
Gameplay: 5/10
Overall: 5/10

[b]Conclusion[/b]
I had fun with it. There were times of frustration, times of boredom, and times where I could simply appreciate and enjoy the game for what it was, but it's a game that has dated very poorly and has been surpassed in all areas by other entries in the series, and certainly by other RPGs on the market.

Yeah, this games a mess. Its buggy, it looks like a potato and the sound effects are questionable at best. But I love this game. There is a reason I prefer this to Skyrim. The story has more care put into into even if the world feels a bit mundane. I wouldn't change it for the world. Part of its infinite charm is that fact it doesn't work as intended but that's what makes it special. I have countless hours playing both on PC and PS3 and I have enjoyed them all thoroughly.

I've been playing Oblivion ever since I was a child and even then I was obsessed with it, but now I can fully appreciate the game for what it is. Oblivion brings a special type of enjoyable experience that I feel has not been replicated in a long time. 
While the game is dated, this only helps the game achieve a unique art style, reminiscent to watercolor. The dated graphics also make the dungeons feel creepy as hell. 
The mechanics of the game are very different from newer games but they feel as if there was a lot of thought put into them, especially the spell system. 
My favorite part of the game has to be the side-quests though, each one feels completely different from the next. There's a quest where you literally go into a painting and fight trolls made of paint!
In total, this game may be old but it still has charm to it. I cannot recommend an Elder Scrolls game like I can this one.

Absolutely great game. A pure pleasure to go through.

The story of the main quest is very immersive and fun to play through. The guild's quest lines are mostly good with some of them being among the best I ever played. The shivering isles DLC took some time of me to get into it because it felt so weird I couldn't understand it but as I progressed through it, it started making more sense and I realised that it always did. Wonderful DLC really.

The combat system is really nice and I particularly enjoyed magic as the game gives me total freedom to craft spells and with a bit of imagination you can really hack the game with your custom spells.

Graphics wise, the graphics of the characters has definitely aged, actually they looked bad even for the time but other than that I believe this game's visuals are still very decent.

Sound is also nice. The OSTs are lovable and the voice acting can be weird sometimes but that has a nice thing to it.

There are some issues of course. Some quests are annoying, some are way too easy and frankly disappointing (looking at you mannimarco), mounts are a complete joke, the leveling system is a bit complex imo and again everyone looks ugly.

Many will also mention the bugs. True you will find some but I believe Oblivion is one of the few games which are broken to perfection. The bugs do add something nice to it particularly the dialogues.

Overall, with all its issues, I think this game is a masterpiece that is totally worth playing even today.

TLDR: One of the great games of all time. A world that you can spend ages exploring.

You can find stories in every nook and cranny of the map. You can become anything. The quests are deeper than "fetch this and I'll pay you." Characters you meet will tell interesting stories, say more than a few stock lines. 

The game is also hilarious. The shock of seeing a grinning guard spontaneously running off a bridge into the Oblivion fires was made funnier by the fact that the quest he was featured in was so serious that I felt emotionally invested. Also the really dumb minigame where you charm someone. There's so much potential to cheese everything in the game, but it's so silly that it doesn't even detract from the rich and beautiful experience, it just adds comedy. And this game came out in 2006. Half of the stock lines have already been turned into memes by now.

It's also good that the game doesn't take itself too seriously either. You get an even split between funny and dramatic. Sometimes even a funny quest can hit you in the feels, like Mazoga's. 

As of the time of writing this, I have yet to complete the main quest. Yes I modded Oblivion a bit (to make the faces look less stupid and for bugfixes), but I went in pretty much vanilla and played for 80 hours. Besides from the Mages Guild, I have completed no major questline. There is just so much to see and do. Plus, I hear Shivering Isles essentially adds a whole second game to play. 

CONS: It's clunky. You're not playing this game for cool fighting mechanics or anything, though fights still feel fun because you have to apply some old-school RPG tactics to your combat. Also some may get turned off by the graphics, but those are easily tweaked via mods. 

TIPS: Leveling is broken. Feel free to move the difficulty slider around to the most fun level to play. No one's giving you medals for doing the hardest difficulty, where your hits do only 1/6th damage and rats can oneshot you. Invest in acrobatics, and you can pretty much roll away from any enemy. Save often, never trust the autosave. And becoming a vampire is actually really useful and good for combat, unless you hate never being in the sun.

VERDICT: Must-play. A classic that stands the test of time.

As I escaped the tunnels leading out into the vast land of Cyrodiil, I encountered two strange people. Bandits! One began to fire at me with his bow. Another charged at me. The bandit ran past me and dove directly into the river behind me, where I can only assume she was fighting off a vicious trout. Alas, she did not prevail and died in the lazy flow of water. 
I quickly bashed in the head of the other bandit, looted their bodies, and resumed my journey. I was now invigorated by the encounter I just experienced. A strange promise of the good times that laid before me as I set out into this buggy landscape.

Back in the day, circa 2002, I played vanilla Morrowind and enjoyed it thoroughly, and actually completed it, largely because (I think) the mod scene wasn't anything like it is now. 

Oblivion and Skyrim are my white whale. My sisyphean tasks doomed to never be completed. I've never actually finished Oblivion (or Skyrim, for the same reasons). Each time I've tried to start I've instead found myself modding it for hours on end over the course of several days before eventually getting distracted by something else and I "forget" about it. I once spent two weeks modding the non-Steam version of Oblivion back in 2008. I still remember buying all the original DLCs from the official Bethesda site, including the infamous horse armor DLC, and then spending hours upon hours combing through the mod collections on Nexusmods to find all the best mods, from unofficial patches, to UI improvements, to graphics mods, to whole new content packs with their own dungeons or questlines. I still have all of those original files saved on my NAS, totalling 16GB, neatly organized by category, all these years later.

If you enjoy tinkering with mods, play-testing each one after install, troubleshooting mod compatibility issues, using/learning archaic and obscure third-party mod managers (BOSS, OBSE, OBMM, Wrye BASH, TES4Edit, etc.), optimizing the load order of each mod, learning new scripting languages, and generally not getting anything done because you waste all your time on modding a game instead of actually playing it, then Oblivion (or Skyrim) is the game for you.

10/10 - would start to play again and never finish, every time. This is my fate.

*This review brought to you by the Steam Awards 2016, because I'll do just about anything for a Steam badge and some XP.*

i think TESIV: Oblivion is my favorite Elder Scrolls game. the intro/tutorial integrated most gameplay elements smoothly, the class/skill/stat customizations were the sweet spot between the incredibly detailed system of its predecessor & the very generalized system of its successor, & once you finally set out on your own, you are greeted w/ an unforgettable sight of Cyrodiil. it's such a gorgeous game even now. the storyline stands out as you are not some foretold legend, something that i personally dislike especially in TESV, but you still are a vital part of the story, a hero who make a name for themselves, not a prophecy to fulfill w/ some special ability only available to you. the only complaint i have is that "cur" does not ring the same as "milkdrinker" in Skyrim / "nwah" in Morrowind.

I played Skyrim first (a latecomer to it, put it off until 2022 ... but loved it and spent hundreds of hours earlier this year), so this is mainly from the perspective of someone who was always meaning to "get into" the Elder Scrolls, but was always daunted until they gave Skyrim a good chance. Skyrim is my only direct play experience before Oblivion, and I assume it's the same for a lot of others.

If you LOVED Skyrim and are craving more of that feeling, I can promise you that Oblivion is filled with it. Your Skyrim instincts will come in very handy, and a lot of things will transfer over directly. Other things are quirks to get used to, and I have to encourage people to work through whatever obstacles may come up that prevent you from getting into the game at first -- I almost put it down in frustration trying to get it to work the way I wanted it to, but I'm glad I stuck with it.

Pretty much everything that turned me off at first can be modded around, one of the foremost of which is the leveling mechanic. There is an easy fix to the finicky way this game handles attributes and skillups -- I would recommend looking up something called "Ultimate Leveling" on Nexus Mods, and doing some reading on how it works in vanilla versus the options the mod gives you -- you can make it feel a lot more like Skyrim leveling, or even traditional experience point based leveling, if you want to. If Vanilla works for ya', -- go nuts..

I would definitely recommend making sure to get the official and unofficial patches, just like you would expect to do in Skyrim in 2022 -- they're old and buggy games, but apparently I'm not the only one to forgive them those flaws. ;-)

You should also consider Darnified UI, which requires a little bit of reading and setup to get working properly (you'll need the equivalent of Skyrim's Script Extender installed and working first), but once you have it nailed, it improves the interface and HUD drastically -- especially the map, which was a big one for me! I have a very weak sense of direction, in video games and real life. You can expand it so you can see more of it at once.

Side-note: I wish I could pull up a minimap in my brain for reality (would be most helpful), but that's part of why I spend so much time in Tamriel instead.

Final observation -- just like with Skyrim, the NPCs are hilariously stupid, and their AI can be mercilessly exploited. I've found great fun using the "charm" spell so far, and enemies can be baited into friendly fire in helpful ways. Bathe in the molten, hot cheese of it all, and enjoy. :-)

I think Oblivion is probably the only game from my youth/childhood that's EXACTLY like I remembered it, for better or worse. Among my Elder Scrolls enjoyer friends I've always been the only one whose favourite was Oblivion, and I know some consider it the weakest of the bunch, but to me it's always been special for some reason. Maybe because I was so excited to hear about "Morrowind's sequel" (lmao) before trying, but regardless, it became one of my favourite games of all time even though I NEVER played through the main quest, only exploration, guilds and secondary quest. 

With all that out of the way, if you are reading reviews to decide whether to get Oblivion, you probably don't know about it, so to put it simply it's a clunkier Skyrim in a completely different setting, and I personally prefer Cyrodiil with its woods and plains to the frozen north of Skyrim. Combat is pretty bland and you usually just block and mash attack until the opponent ragdolls, but exploration has always been pretty fun, there's always some dungeon to see or some quest to find. For a Bethesda open world game it's a classic, recommended to fans of those (including Fallout 3).

Definitely a fun experience. I think the main story, like with skyrim, is not the best part of the game, but is fun overall and lets you continue with side quests afterwards.

Some of the side quests are ridiculously good to play through, while others are tedious and can be done simply by outrunning the enemy.
Immersive storyline, interesting game mechanics - worth a play.
The best game ever made

An amazing game that never gets old with tones of replay value. The story is intriguing and interesting, with all the side quests making the world feel vibrant and alive. Plenty of roleplay opportunity that feels missing from many other RPGs. This is a must-play game. The DLC stories are all brilliant as well and add so much extra content and intrigue to the game.
The levelling and scaling system isn't optimal and takes a little to get your head round but despite this, once you understand how it works and its flaws, you can easily work around it, especially with one or two mods (though modding is definitely not a requirement).

I have played this game for about 2000-3000 hours before getting it on Steam years later. If you play it vanilla, it is pretty good. But once you get into mods, it even surpasses Skyrim imho, since it is easy to mod, the choices are endless and you feel like you are writing your own fantasy-story.

This is a VERY old game, so it took some getting used to, but I'm actually enjoying it quite a bit.  It has a good story that makes sense.  I've had to go online on occasion, just like any game I play, and I had to lower it to easy mode, because I'm a crappy gamer but love to play.  I used a cheat to give myself some gold and some health potion, which also helped.  The horse takes some getting used to. (just hit enter to get on/off, and use A and D to steer.)   Collecting loot is a bit weird - if I'm doing it right - I always have to beat the container or person a few times then hit the space bar.  I'll have to check to see if there's a better way.  Anyway, I ended up playing almost ALL DAY and had a lot of fun with this antique of a game.

You typically favor the game that introduced you to the series, and this was mine. I spend far too long figuring out the leveling system, the glitches galor - both game breaking and hilarious. I remember I played this on 360 for a few days and gave up when, shocker, my merchant based character died too often. 

This game is far larger than Skyrim, or at least it feels like it. There are some big empty areas or long treks up mountains that can be a bit tedious. Compared to newer titles, this combat system is a little clunky. Playing a sneaky archer is an approachable build, if it's your first time. The NPC audio is stunted, which is both awkward and funny. 

I don't care about graphics or sounds typically, so this is fine to me. Immersion and roleplay are certainly possible -- even more so with modding.

This game is my favourite Elder Scrolls so far, with Daggerfall. It had more depth than Skyrim and a better story too. The landscape was better looking and the quests, better designed. I used to have this game in GOTY edition and I bought it back. If you can't get beyond the godawful faces, just play it. It's a really memorable experience.

Once upon a time this was my first Elder Scrolls game...

I remember popping Oblivion into my Xbox 360 and losing myself for days in its bloom drenched neon green forests. Sneaking around homes, my heart beating fast in my chest, taking the priceless loot for my horde. Walking to shrines of the princes and fulfilling their mad bidding. Talking with the people who felt more alive than anything I had ever played before. Getting lost in the quests both rich and complex. How each new dungeon was filled with danger and opportunity. How the crowd of the Arena made my heart soar. Yes, I remember it all. 

It has been over 15 years since I last played Oblivion -- hard to believe for a game that meant so much to me. I was hesitant at first but here I am, just over 7 hours in, and it feels just as good -- just as fresh and new as it once did. I don't think a good game can be anything but good, no matter how much time passes over it. Sure its got jank and some questionable design choices. The vanilla faces are nightmare fuel and the world is a bit one note. But we've had mods for all that for a long time. 

At its core Oblivion was a game that didn't take many risks and yet managed to be revolutionary. While Morrowind's atmosphere and main quest may always be the best in the series, the more I play Oblivion the more I realize that it's strength was its quests and characters. If Skyrim is a game of exploring, Oblivion is a game of immersing. If Morrowind is a game of wonder, Oblivion is a game of nostalgia. I'm so happy to be back. In truth I'm sorry I ever left. But that's enough for now. Chances are you aren't here to decide if you should be buying this game or not, you already know the answer. Instead I imagine, like me, you're here to reminisce. I hope you were able to do that for a minute or two.

Now if you'll excuse me, I have Sean Bean to find.

I have played this game as an ailment to my chronic anxiety of dealing with the real world for a decade and a half, just about. It is my greatest pleasure to now be instructing my daughter to explore this incredible world to escape in.

ive been playing this game for 11 years, and not once have i regretted buying it on any platform. it has the charm of a fairy tale, where you are not the hero of the story but the hero's brave and supporting background character. you're prince charming's steadfast companion, his right hand. the awkward and strange delivery from most of the voice actors is famously hilarious, and contrast in a goofy and lovable way with the serious and professional tone sean bean brings to his performance as martin septim. the world of cyrodiil as presented in oblivion is one of the most beautiful worlds i've seen in a video game. the landscapes are absolutely out of the pages of watercolor fairy tales you'd read to a child, with knights and heroes and gods and demons. watching the sun set and rise on the painted leaves of cyrodiil's forests, fields, and castles has long been a nostalgic event for me, and i often play the game with no fast travel just to see where the road and the setting sun take me. if you're one of the lucky ten thousand who have never had the delight to play or even hear of this game, do yourself a favor. buy it, especially if it's on sale. it's worth it

Back in 2006, when this game first came out, I thought that this was IT. The pinnacle of gaming. The story, graphics, soundtrack, AI, voices, mechanics, and setting were perfect in my eyes SIXTEEN years ago of me making this review. I never beat it back then, but I did play it, and boy was I blown away back then.

However, how does it stack up now in comparison to modern western RPGs? Well, not the best, but I still like it. And after over 200 hours of exploring, talking to people, and becoming the Champion of Cyrodiil (and Sheogorath...?), I can finally say I've beaten the game. It was an amazing journey. I'm not sure if it's all that nostalgia I've had for this game, but I enjoyed my experience with this game as much as New Vegas, and I considered that to be my favorite western RPG.

Getting this game to even just comply with modern hardware can be insanely annoying too. For my playthrough, I wanted to keep it as original as possible, so I only used 2 mods: Oblivion Script Extender (OBSE) and a custom FOV script to make sure my FOV stays at 110 without the menu becoming so small you need a microscope to navigate it. There are so many more mods you can install to make this game feel a lot more modern and look the part too, but in my opinion that feels like overkill. I don't know if it's just me being a person who's childhood was in the 2000s, but I like how everything played back then, and Oblivion is no exception.

Overall, would this game be worth adding to your library in the year 2022? I'm not sure. On one hand, Skyrim is a lot more accessible for those who don't like installing mods, and Morrowind has quite the charm of an old game. However, this game defined a period of my childhood, and I am insanely biased on this one. At least give it a shot.

S0UL: Anyway, for real though, Oblivion is an amazing game. Allows quite a bit of freedom compared to Skyrim. Fans of RPGs will absolutely love this game and sink 100+ hours into this game. The magic system is fantastic in this game, allowing you to craft your own custom spells with multiple effects as you progress in the game. I will admit, melee combat can be a bit clunky and the dialogue between NPCs while walking through cities can be... bizzare to say the least. But a lot of the shortcomings with Oblivion can be improved or outright fixed with mods. I would definetly reccommend the Unofficial Oblivion Patch as a minimum, along with other good gameplay mods (such as Deadly Reflex) and graphical enhancement mods to modernise the game. The major expansion for this game is the Shivering Isles, allowing players to enter Sheogorath's plane of Oblivion of the same name. This is one of the best Bethesda DLCs ever and anyone will have an amazing time. The game combined with its DLCs, I would rate a 9/10.

TLDR; Buy this game already if you haven't (100% recommend) but remember this game came out in 2008 so some parts will be a little clunky. Nothing that mods can't fix!

I played about 4000 Hours of this game on my Xbox 360 when I was younger. It always seemed like I was able to find something new in the game to do. Then I got it on PC and modded it a bit, I played about 40 hours of the game and spent 14 hours making the mods work. It was worth it though. The fact that I can just choose to play whenever I feel like i s  very pleasing to me. I do want to get an original disc copy of the game though, just so I can play offline once in a while. The game has tons of bugs, but there's unofficial patches that fans have made that fix most of them. It's not the prettiest game, but there's tons of stuff to do and a lot of different playstyles. The difficulty has a very sharply increasing difficulty curve if you've never played before, I'd recommend a mod that fixes the enemy scaling, there's a few options. But if you want to play the game vanilla I'd recommend playing on a medium level of difficulty so you don't get killed all the time.

It's been 15 years since Oblivion released, and it's still one of the most immersive games you can play. It puts you in a vast world that is packed full of lore and details, and gives the freedom to do whatever you want. The world is dense, full of towns, cities, and dungeons to explore, and you can pretty much go anywhere and talk to any of the NPCs. It's graphics may be dated, but it still possesses a warm and serene beauty, perfectly balancing the darker and more mysterious stories and quests. While epic in scale, the main story is slightly generic, but the guilds and side quests are some of the most memorable and varied in any game. All this is enhanced by an otherworldly atmosphere, and an unforgettable masterpiece of a soundtrack. The combat kind of sucks though :(

Whether you decide to follow the main story, one of the many side stories, or just explore the world, you're sure to find discoveries around every corner. Oblivion promises to give you an epic adventure, but what makes it so special is that personal discovery of your own adventure. It's a game that makes you feel like a kid again, living another life full of excitement and mysteries, where you can be whoever you wish to be.

[h1]The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion[/h1]
 
[b]Short introduction[/b]

Back in 2006, one of the cult and at the same time one of my favorite RPG games was released. Yeah, it was TES:Oblivion. At one time, I spent almost all my free time in this game, because everything what I needed was in there. Starting from the most full customization of your game character, one of the most filled lore in the game industry, interesting and elaborated quests, and ending with an excellent soundtrack and wonderful graphics for that time (2006). And all this stuff together took hundreds of hours of my life in the distant 2008. And, you know, I was satisied with this :)
I spent all my free time in this game for several months back in the days, because it was really worth it. And so far in my memory echoes of those distant years spent in this game were heard. And now, after more than 10 years, I decided to plunge again into the world of Oblivion, into a world that I loved so much.

[b]In this review, I will try to talk about everything in order, considering the game in modern realities. So, let's begin the review: [/b]
[list]
[*][h1]Gameplay[/h1]

The first thing that meets us is the customization of your character. It's just great here. Everything according to the standard - from the choice of folk to the height and shade of your eyebrows. In general, a complete immersion in the creation of a unique game character, and even in 2019, many games this is still not possible. Personally, I spent about 30 minutes just to create a “perfect” character. But when I was younger I made some really funny characters, the game is allowed to do [b]anything[/b].

Then the player is given the opportunity to choose the "class" of his character. In this case, in the game it was really possible to play back several classes - a swordsman (heavy armor), a magician, an assassin/thief/archer (light armor). At the same time, you should make a choice in advance, because the initial “setup” of the character greatly affects the gameplay as a whole and an incorrectly created character can ruin [b]the whole[/b] impression of the gameplay. 
Personally, I liked playing the thief in Oblivion, and although the game itself is not about “this,” but I got a lot more pleasure than in the same “Thief”, stealing more than 15,000 items for the game... I don’t know, maybe I have problems, but it’s really interesting to steal things here, because each character lives his own life, on his own schedule and each has his own secrets and “skeletons” in the closet, and the loot is very different and interesting.

Well, when the character is created and now we are allowed to get acquainted with the game interface, the combat system and various other features of the game. Here, in principle, there is nothing to say - everything is just fine, the game pleases with a [b]huge[/b] arsenal of spells, interesting alchemy, the ability to enchant various armor and weapons, which in turn are also very many. The pumping system is quite logical and I always liked this. Do you want to learn to own something at a high level? Practice is the key to success, that's all. It is also nice to have teachers of crafts, martial arts and magic, who can greatly accelerate process of leveling . All they ask for in return is a small number of Septims. In general, I really like the character pumping system in TES. And yeah, almost forgot, you can go ANYWHERE since you've finished the "prologue" of the game. Absolutely freedom!
There is only one controversial moment in the gameplay for me. It's the thing that level of enemies is adjusted to the level of development of your character, it's because the game tries to maintain the interest of the player until the very end. It’s a pity, because I really want to feel like a tough guy, who can kill anyone with a couple of blows, but in the end we get that being the head of the guild of magicians, fighters, thieves, a listener of a dark brotherhood, and some goblin still can beat you... These are here are the problems of dragonborn :)

[*][h1]Storyline and Lore[/h1]
The main plot in Oblivion is dull and uninteresting, I’ll leave it aside, game is just not about that...
Specifically for lore - I take off my hat! A huge number of books, quests, remarks ... I wouldn't want to talk about this topic for a long time, there is something to say, but I will say only one word. Bravo! Lore is [b]ENORMOUS[/b] and elaborate.
Quests deserve special attention. Some of them are just awesome. No matter how I like other RPG games, quests in Oblivion are just best. They are original, vary, there's not only "go, bring/kill" missions, no. It's not about Oblivion.
Personally for me “A Shadow over Hackdirt" is favorite quest It refers us to the story of H.P. Lovecraft’s “The Shadow Over Innsmouth”. When I read the story itself - I got goosebumps, and passing this quest I caught something like a “Vietnamese flashback”. It was just awesome! Or as an example, a quest with the purchase of a cheap mansion with ghosts, where you have to rid the house of the disease. Or the one where we were looking for the missing artist in the painting. And don't froget about the quests of the dark brotherhood and the guild of thieves? My advice to you - be sure to go through them, you will not regret it.

And since I was talking about quests - I didn't play in game's  addons before, but I had the pleasure to go through them this year. It's worth it. "Shivering Isles" is one of the most atmospheric add-ons I've ever played. Spending time in this, it really seemed to me that I'm starting to go a little crazy like the people on these islands... 
"Knights of the Nine" are good too, but the islands simply overshadowed everything they could...

[*][h1]Graphics[/h1]
As for the graphics - I played the “clean” version, without graphic modifications, and the graphics didn't spoil the gameplay at all, and the amazing starry sky is worth it... Still as beautiful as is could be...Even in 2019, I was surprised at its beauty! And knowing what mods can do with this game - I can say with responsibility - the graphics are good. Yes, sometimes the draw-distance is frightening, the edges seem unstressed, the animations are crooked, but after such an amount of time ... Damn, this is definitely worth respect! 
[/list]

What can I say in summary? The game doesn't require a powerful PC for itself, a lot of memory on the hard drive, but the picture still can be good. It's still interesting to do some quests, make you unique character with his unique story, to decide the fate of people and do whatever you want. You'll be always able to save the empire, but not to complete every side-quest :)

If you are new to playing Oblivion, here's some advice for your early run, do these as soon as you're free to roam:

Head to Weye (directly to the West of the Imperial City) and do the quest where you kill Slaughterfish, you'll get a ring that gives you Waterbreathing - basically making Argonian a laughably irrelevant race pick and Potions of Sea an easy sell if you ever loot them. Waterbreathing can be surprisingly handy and you can always swap rings around

Head to Aleswell (North of the Imperial City) and do the Quest there, you get a free place to stay and safe containers, effectively making buying a house unnecessary for a majority of your run

Deliver the Amulet to Weynon priory and you can get a free horse from Prior Maborel, exploring the wilderness can give you a good range of locations to loot and fight in for the sake of levelling skills and getting loot. Jauffre gives you a load of free items too.
It is good, what can I say it is the right balance between old(avoiding the bad bits of new games) and new (avoiding the jank of old games(for the most part))

I've invested countless hours into the Elder Scrolls and Fallout games, but none hold the wealth of dear memories like Oblivion does. Oblivion does atmosphere incredibly well, the soft lighting, the beautiful vistas and gorgeous forests populated with fantastical creatures really scratches the fantasy world itch for me. That being said it does have a myriad of problems that come with it and I imagine it can feel rather dated without the rose-tinted glasses of nostalgia, but if you can get past the somewhat jank combat, unintuitive leveling system and hearing the same 15 voices throughout the entire game, you'll find a gem. The magic in this game is incredibly open and is the last game that gives you the freedom to create your own spells as silly or broken as you'd like.

The Oblivion gates are the elephant in the room, they feel samey and bleak, when one would imagine that the physical representation of Mehrunes Dagon, whose domains include not just destruction and revolution, but change, ambition and energy would be more interesting than an orange island with a bunch of lava. Beyond that, Sean Bean is fucking incredible and hard carries the main story with his performance of Martin.

The shining gem of this game is the Dark Brotherhood storyline. It's an incredibly experience riddled with intrigue and missions where you can exceed what is asked of you by eliminating targets with unique stipulations I.E. making it seem like an accident by dropping a wall mounted head on the target, and faking the death and subsequently resuscitating of the target. I'll leave the rest of them as the experience is probably the best part of the game. 

In short, this game holds some of my best videogame memories and I don't think I'll ever have the same type of relationship with a game as I've had with Oblivion. That may be simply be due to becoming older and losing that childish sense of wonder but nevertheless, this game fucks, hard.
Playing this in Oct 2022 and still an enjoyable game.  Sure the graphics don't match up to today's standards, but the size / scope / depth of the game still competes with everything current.

Despite being the best game I have ever played, it was still really buggy, even after I started using console to fix them.

Things to watch out for: 
1. When doing Wizards Guild quest for recommendation, the amulet quest, don't take the amulet without beating up the enemy boss, otherwise after you take the amulet to that granny, she won't give you the dialogue to finish the quest, although you can get around that with console, it's still better to just not skip the cut scene and just kill the damn wizard.
2. While doing fighters guild quest, Azani Blackheart, be sure to wait for Orynn to get his fat a$$ to the domain before finishing the quest, otherwise he gets stuck in the previous dungeon and even if you talk with him, you can't finish the quest and advance the fighters guild quest line.
3.When doing quest in Shivering Isles for the calm pants, only give one cake to the beggar otherwise he gives 2 and the quest gets broken, you can't finish the quest or get rid of those pants, unless you use console to drop one pair of pants or finish quest forcefully through command etc..
4. You can get stuck in a lot of places in oblivion, but that can be solved by pressing " ` " button on the keyboard to open the console and inputting "tcl" to toggle the collision off and after you get unstuck, you can just do it again to toggle collision on.

Tip: the amount of bonus attributes you get when you level up for a certain stat depends on your skills that correspond to that certain stat.

2006 was one of the most beautiful years of my life. I helped half of my school mates with IT projects in exchange for money so I can afford in summer to buy a 128MB graphic card so I can play this amazing game. Amazing times.

I remember thinking how insanely technical the character creation was for this game. Before I owned an Xbox 360, my first experience was with it on display of the second (or was it third?) story of the Virgin Mega Store in Downtown Disney, Orlando FL. I played a little of the tutorial but when you're on vacation in Disney even during the evening, you aren't gonna spend all your time playing Oblivion in a music store. 

When I finally got the game and an Xbox 360, I made a woodelf archer. And after I had made it a good way through the main storyline, my character promptly contracted the disease that turns you into a vampire and slowly but surely as I sought a cure I just couldn't do it fast enough. That, or I think there was a witch I was supposed to meet that ended up no-showing? Probably was an early glitch. Was super sad though at that time, haha.

Later when in college my sister got the game and started having phone conversations with me about it. We'd talk about quests and NPCs and things we'd found. After she got the game was when I started playing again and finally pulled through to the end. And yes, my new character did contract the disease-- which promptly in the early stages I had wiped away from my character. Duh!

To this day I still have fond memories of the game. I still know it as the game with far more secrets and less linearity than its older brother Skyrim. And although it says I've only played it for 50 hours here, I definitely put in my 1 to 200 hour stint(s) on that Xbox 360. And just like the others, there are mods to bring the game closer to new games in style and look. The community is fun and wide reaching. But this IS about the game.

And for the game? I say it's great. It's freaking awesome in fact. Give it a go! You'll have some amazing adventures and limitless fun much like in many Elder Scrolls titles. You have absolutely nothing to lose except your money and your time and your life.
Honestly, it's a solid title. It's dated fairly well, still holds up somewhat and better than Skyrim (without mods).
Shitty ass game
yes

There is a mod called Oblivion Character Overhaul. Now, i absolutely recommend playing this game. Several times, in fact. But NOT WITHOUT THAT MOD. I don't know who designed the faces of the NPCs in this game, but it's possible they only know what people look like from a rough description. 

It took a few re-installs to get this thing going with mods, but now that it's going, it's going. I'm running twenty or so mods and an ENB, and I've had two crashes in 27 hours. I'd say that's bloody amazing for a bethesda game. The gameplay is solid, the combat is more action than RPG (no more hidden dice rolls). There is a low to medium amount of actual role-playing. High amount of exploration. Quests are good at giving you enough clues to figure it out without having to hold your hand through the whole thing. 

The world design is absolutely amazing. I've heard it said that all of Cyrodiil looks samey. Believe me it doesn't. Bruma, in the north, resembles Skyrim. The woods around Leyawiin, in the south, have a distinct swampy, marshy vibe. Every major city has it's own vibe, it's own distinct architecture, it's all designed quite beautifully. The dungeons on the other hand, do tend to feel samey. Once you've seen one cave, you've seen them all. 

The character design is done very well. It's difficult to have variety when you've only got, like, six voice actors, but somehow most NPCs end up feeling quite unique. At least the one's that have a quest attached. Patrick Stewart and Sean Bean are bloody amazing in this, and it makes me wish more games would hire bigger name actors. 

The sound design is good. Atmosphere is a bit lacking in some locations. Caves and dungeons are fine, but a bit of background bustle in towns and inns and whatnot would've made things feel a bit more lively and natural. The music on the other hand, is breathtaking. This may well be my favourite The Elder Scrolls soundtrack. It's unique, while still retaining that TES vibe. There are melodies and motifs in common with previous TES games. Absolutely marvellous.

Knights of the Nine DLC:
A bunch of dungeon diving with interesting lore-diving. The armour/weapons you get from this quest is not worth it, as you must keep your infamy at no more than 1. If you go over you can't use the armour until you go to 9 *UNMARKED* shrines that are all over the map. It's just... wut. 

Shivering Isles DLC:
It's an interesting change to Cyrodil's traditional fantasy setting, but it started feeling overbearing after awhile, and it's not a short DLC. I personally found the story boring. A daedric prince (Sheogorath, prince of madness) gets you to do some stuff because another daedric prince (Jyggalag) wants to take over his realm. I just feel like it could've been a fun exploration of oblivion and daedra, but instead it's just a series of fetch quests. Doubt I'd play it again.

Jokes aside, it's pretty much that in most aspects except for story/writing. The main story is fine, but the random sidequest stuff was more my jam. Shivering isles story was actually a lot more interesting than the main one for me.

On technical side of things, it works fine, just add the unofficial patches and you're golden. Crashed maybe a few times over ~70h, so that's fine. Got corrupted save once when it crashed while saving, but since i quicksave often it was no problem. The shivering isles dlc on the other hand was real crashfest, sometimes crashing 3 times in 15min, but sometimes fine for a few h.

Gameplay feels kinda dated now, but still acceptable, although the UI was kind of a pain, and some leveling bs was just stupid. Cmon, merchantile is ok as a skill, but why there are a bunch of items that greatly exceed the maximum value that you can sell the items for even at max level? I finished the game with 30+ daedric warhamers, cuirass and some others stuffed in a chest, because they felt stupid to sell for like half their maximum price, but i got maxed the skill and find out that you just cant sell it for more anyway... Just some stupid stuff like that.
Magic was fun, until you ran out of keybninds for it and had to scroll trough probably 100+ spells to find the one you wanted to use now... At the endgame the combat had just become tedious, so just equipped random items with melee/magic reflect and became a hedgehog who just had to heal and repair armour once in a while and enemies just died while you were just passing trough.
So, idk, the game is good, the content is aplenty, the writing is solid enough that i read like half the books i found, and if you want some changes or even more content the modding community has a bunch to offer.
What else do you need?

[h1]raw art[/h1]
Although I may view other games as being objectively better, The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion is the single-player game I will always go back to.

Bethesda tried to recreate little parts of reality in the interactions between customized NPCs and their scheduled AI. They failed horribly and created instead listless deformed humanoids that lack the intelligence to do little more than bump into one another and echo the same conversation they heard from their previous collision. They lack the social awareness not to steal apples in front of a crowd of guards, nonchalantly stumble over corpses in the town square, or calmly approach a man wearing the recently murdered Emperor's robes.

These NPCs do not resemble human beings at all, questionably apart from their character models. They are insane, compulsive, and often ghoulish creatures. (Searching through random NPC houses will commonly unearth status within the Mythic Dawn, Dread Father shrines, and other signs of repulsive activity.) It is inspiring in a way to see a thing so close yet so distant in reference to human society.

Bethesda realized all of this in a moment of unbearably historic revelation and started work on the game that marks their self-actualization -- Shivering Isles. The people of Sheogorath's realm are each driven mad and suffer from individualistic fixations. Creating a society of manic and demented people is precisely what Bethesda was meant to do with their perfect skillset of idiosyncratic writing, AI that requires specific targets and times, awkward animations, and ugly character models. Instead of accidentally creating a weird RPG, they intentionally directed their labor to the highest-valued function. 

As a whole, there is an impossible amount of content to experience. For nearly 10 years of consistent play, every new game has revealed new quests (some that don't appear in the journal) that I somehow missed. The quests are consistently hilarious. Exploring is vastly rewarding, as you can discover schedules, backgrounds, and dark secrets of NPCs. There are a fair amount of treasure and unique items hidden about the world, as well. (This contrasts with Skyrim's limited content that ends in repeating quests and NPCs that reveal all there is to know about themselves in 20 minutes of town dialogue.)

This game is terribly optimized, does not run well on a modern computer even though this was released in 2006. There are only like 10 different voice actors (so you'll run into people talking to each other with the same voice), if you don't like staring at the NPC's potato faces you'll have to install a mod to replace their ugly heads (not sure what Bethesda was thinking when they designed these faces. Even the previous Elder Scrolls installment, Morrowind, had better faces). If you don't want to waste countless minutes repairing your weapons and armor (which is necessary, because when degraded it will reduce damage and protection), you'll have to install a mod for that as well. The UI is garbage for PC, but thankfully there's a mod that replaces it with Skyrim-like UI. The combat has no impact, you just click the LMB until the enemies drop dead - but be careful, avoid leveling up too much or you'll run into spongy enemies and bandits with daedric gear. The dungeons feel boring, lifeless and uninspiring. 

The main positive point in this game is the guild quests, which are better than Skyrim. But the main quest is just as bad if not worse than in Skyrim. I uninstalled this game after the main story had me close Oblivion Gates in every major city. I had enough of closing these gates after the first one. Even if you speed run through them just to get to the sigil stone you still have to figure out the main path while avoiding the piles of enemies that stack behind you - overall it takes much longer than killing a single dragon, which also eventually become an annoyance in Skyrim (although a far lesser one). 

I purchased this game on the back of hype from nostalgic fans, and because Skyrim is one of my favorite games of all time. As someone who does not suffer from nolstagia, I would advise you to avoid this game if you dislike having to install mods to fix every thing that Bethesda could not bother to implement (even simple things such as the ability to de-nock arrows) and if you can't get stable 60 FPS.
