It's a great work of art that is top tier for role-playing. It has dedicated lore that is faithful to the franchise universe chronology, and it's extremely realistic in its content. It has one of the best magic systems that justifies the lore in Elder Scrolls. It's got a complete finished story, including approx. 8 DLCs; it delivered what it aimed to do. And everything including the very soundtrack has a story and purpose, which it all circles around and becomes a whole. The immersion levels in this game are also off the charts, including amazing architecture, nature, and general atmosphere. I have played this game many many times and I recommend this video game to any fan of role-play and general video game enthusiast. 

It has negatives, including bugs/glitches, and mainly gameplay focused flaws, but I can see past these with ease as they don't hinder gameplay too much. However, if you like playing third person, playing a bowman or a sorcerer is the worst, and it decreases the score of the game a little. I don't mind whichever so for me it doesn't matter too much, but it is undeniably a score decrease and it limits your accessibility. The biggest negative is that it has aged badly aesthetically including those gameplay flaws I mentioned earlier. I would still recommend the game for any role-play fans and general video game enthusiast. It is that good. 

As a great fan of the forthcoming mentioned games, this game is comparable to legendary games like Ocarina of Time, Breath of the Wild, Dark Souls and Skyrim, which Oblivion at one point also contained innumerable secrets and many thousands of hours worth of analysis! A legendary game to say the least!

[TL;DR at the bottom] 

Oblivion is a confused experience. I have no idea how else to put this – It’s just an extremely unique game that constantly switches between bouts of genuine charisma, intrigue and sublime writing to being a broken, horrendous mess that stretches itself out way too thin in almost every aspect. 

To get the biggest issue out of the way: Oblivion is infamous for its technical issues. Deservedly so. It requires a lot of legwork to even get running; Despite Oblivion arguably having started the modding trend, it’s a bit of a headache to actually customize and no matter how many community fixes and patches you apply – at the end of the day, the game will still crash a ton. Funnily enough, despite the main game being an absolute nightmare – the Shivering Isles expansion ran entirely crash free, which leads me to believe that (most) of the crashes I encountered are likely tied to Cyrodiil’s cell generation. 

Now: Crashes, Non-loading Architecture, Lagspikes, Quest Softlocks, Duplicating Items, Spellmaking and Enchanting glitches; All of that aside as most reviews already tackle these, there is another thing that Oblivion is rather infamous for and it’s ultimately what makes this game an utterly miserable experience to go through, regardless of its other merits:

Oblivion’s balancing is flawed twofold: Your actual leveling process is similar to Morrowind, where performing actions, such as jumping, levels up a correlated skill, such as Acrobatics; That skill is then also tied to an Attribute, such as Endurance, Agility etc. Once a certain numbers of these skills have been increased, the player gains a level up that numerically is dependent on the exact skills that have been leveled up during the course of the previous level. This is a really disgusting way of saying that without planning, the player is going to end up gimping themselves in regular gameplay as their level-ups will result in less points gained per attribute than their enemies.

This is due to Oblivion scaling up the enemy spawn-table alongside the player’s level. This will hilariously eventually lead to situations where the player may enter some random cave to be greeted by Liches as regular enemies. Bandits eventually wearing Glass and Daedric, as if it’s some sort of MMO. The big issue with this, further than it being extremely unimmersive, which is true across the game for a variety of reasons anyhow, is that it slows down the already badly paced game tremendously. 

“Pacing” is a bit of a subjective term and a lot of it is tied to Oblivion wanting to feel more grandiose than it is. For example, to join the Mages’ Guild, the player is asked to perform a fetch quest for each of the different cities across Cyrodiil; The Fighters’ Guild intersperses its story with random Mercenary quests – it makes narrative sense, sure, but the result as per gameplay are hours upon hours of essentially empty dungeon-crawling that feels remarkably unrewarding as it is, without the game adding to it through its scaling. 

This is not to say that Oblivion is difficult. In fact, it’s very easy – similarly to Morrowind, just due to the stats and how the game at its fundamental level handles player power. The difference though is, that Oblivion is much less “explosive” than Morrowind. Within ten hours of gameplay, I was immune to magic. Due to me playing a Breton and finding accessories to support my innate resistance. I could’ve chosen to be completely immune to physical damage by the later half of the main story too – the issue being more that you being tanky is also very true for enemies. The end result for me was a choice between playing on regular or high difficulties – or the easiest being reasonably no different, other than how long I would take to crawl through a dungeon. The actual, palpable difficulty is the same. 

My point being is that the DNA of Oblivion’s combat is inherently dysfunctional. Being broken is good – but Oblivion just misses the mark by having gutted some of the freedoms that Morrowind used to have that would have allowed this sort of scaling to function and continuing that trend into Skyrim through more and more streamlining. 

Likewise Oblivion’s story is being joked about a lot. The small clips of one of their one-and-a-half voice actors needing to repeat a line; Beggars switching between voices because it’s the same guy putting on a different persona, the radiant dialogue etc.; Though Oblivion genuinely is quite well written – Side quests, not guilds, but genuine on-the-street side quests are among the most well developed I’ve seen in an RPG, but it suffers from the exact previous factor of the game being so utterly unimmersive due to its very design, that whenever Oblivion hits, or ties to hit an actual note, it is immediately contrasted by the actual freak-show that is its world. 

There are countless examples to point at, but one that I absolutely adored when it happened, but in hindsight really isn’t a good show of what, I *think* the game tries to be, happens during the Fighters’ Guild. [spoiler]During the finale of the Fighters’ Guild, the PC inadvertently murders an entire village. You help capture an enemy Mercenary and aid in his torture before raiding their headquarters for the greater good. When completed, you are announced the new head of the Guild and go back to re-recruit a friend who initially rejects because he took on a painting hobby. Said painting stands in the corner of the room and is a crayon drawing of him torturing the mercenary.[/spoiler] It’s surreal. It is such violent tonal whiplash, that I genuinely burst out laughing thinking this was due to some mod. But it’s not – and it happens again and again.

Another example of this would be the Adoring Fan – an elf sidekick that is functionally immortal. Just closed that apocalyptic demon gate? By Azura, by Azura, by Azura – It’s the grand champion. The game is very aware of this too, but seemingly just rides the wave and tries to hit the serious notes regardless. 

And funnily enough for one part of the game, it somehow works. The Shivering Isles are phenomenal. They’re a unique setting with a reasonably tight design all throughout – and, whether by dumb chance or luck, or whatever else – I didn’t experience a single crash or buggy quest there either. 


[u]TL;DR[/u]
+ Fantastic Sidequests
+ Fairly unique setting, although the game struggles to make use of it throughout many of its quests. 
+ Shivering Isles actually functions lol

+/- Ridiculous tonal whiplash throughout the story; The game oozes charm at the cost of immersion. 
+/- Pacing; While you may not become an Archmage during an afternoon like in Skyrim, almost anything is stretched out over what often feels like filler fetch-quests and overly extensive dungeon-crawls.

- Hopelessly broken. Crashes and bugs are absolute commonplace regardless of the fixes you may apply.
- Balance; both for player and enemies is nonexistent and made infinitely worse by scaling spawn-tables.

In a weird sense, I enjoyed replaying Oblivion. It was my first Bethesda game and I have a fair bit of nostalgia for it. Having now gone back through and played it all again from Morrowind to Daggerfall to Skyrim to even peripheral titles like Enderal and now back to Oblivion, I never ever want to even play another second of it. And this is not because the game itself – the concept and world of Oblivion - is “bad” – it is good, but the flaws it does have are so fundamental and so rotten that the minute-to-minute experience just is kind of miserable. It may be worth recommending it for the unique experience it offers, or even just for the Shivering Isles, but that is a lot of weight to put on that expansion’s shoulders; And the legwork that is required to even get the game to run in any capacity at all, too, is an enormous ask which ultimately just isn’t really worth it.

Oblivion is still surprisingly good and I’ll try using this review to highlight some important things a player might be considering about playing this game on recent times.

[h1]1)You can use mods, but you don’t have to:[/h1]
When I was planning my most recent play of Oblivion, I though it would be necessary the use of mods. I’ve delayed starting this game for a while because of this - since Oblivion is not easy to mod as Skyrim is. Truth is that I’ve started totally vanilla and stayed that way through the end of a 100h campaign and I can say that this game holds up pretty well without any mods.

The game is still beautiful, the art is incredible, the whole visual is still appealing somehow. Mechanics works pretty well and etc. I know mods can improve a lot of things but I think modding Oblivion is not a requirement to enjoy the game today.

[h1]2)You should play on first person perspective:[/h1]
That goes for every Bethesda games mostly. Third person is janky and not cool. It works for when you want to see your character and that’s it. If you want to play a third person game I suggest going for another game. Oblivion is a first person game and this is a game change thing for me.

[h1]3)Keyboard and Mouse are game changes:[/h1]
I was always a controller guy and I had a lot of fun playing Oblivion on my old PS3 back in 2010, but that was there. Playing with KM is so much better that I can’t even tell and this is something that can totally change how you feel the game. And it’s not only about using hotkeys and having a more free control of the camera movement. It’s about just everything! Even the bad menu navigation that were based on consoles works better with KM in my opinion.

[h1]4)Some builds works better than others gameplaywise:[/h1]
The best mechanics for me is sword and shield, magic and not so much playing stealthy. That tip works for Skyrim as well. Playing a stealth build works nicely in some way, however, the mechanics are a bit dated for a stealth game - and also makes exploring dungeons way too long and a bit boring in my opinion, specially compared to newer entries on stealth mechanics over the past 15 years. So, my tip for making the best of the gameplay is playing with magic plus/or weapons and shield and going wide open exposing yourself in combat.

You can actually do what you want and playing stealthy can be a lot of fun as well. It works in the end! Just consider what I am saying specially if you feel that the game is dragging. Also, because I didn’t try all the possible builds as well so I’m just saying what I feel rather than try to set some rules here. 

[h1]5)The combat feels like “Doom or Quake” and it’s awesome:[/h1]
The combat is way more fast paced than Skyrim - and that actually depends on your build as well. Playing with a no armor mage I felt I was like the doom guy shooting magic instead of a gun, and it was awesome. On another play I tried sword and shield with heavy armor and it was way slower, but even so, more arcadish than what I feel when I play Skyrim - which is slower and heavier. 

That said, for me the most important thing to note is the timing of the enemies attacks. It is way more easier to dodge compared to Skyrim. Which makes running around and dodging multiple incoming attacks more manageable in Oblivion. And sometimes I felt like playing Quake, or Doom, for real. This makes the Oblivion combat fun and kind of unique, more closer to boomers shooters I think!


[h1]6)Pure mage is pure fun:[/h1]
Playing as pure mage is unique in Oblivion due to the quantity of spells you have at your disposal. You can do just about everything with magic: you can walk over water, breath under water, become invisible, control other players and creatures, open chests, bring objects to your hand using telekinesis, create space on your inventory by increasing how much weight you can carry, detect others around using life detection, summon creatures to help you in battle, etc. Mix all that with alchemy options and I had the best experience as a mage ever in an RPG game. The fact that you have a dedicated and separated button to magic instead of equipping as a weapon helps as well since you can use enchanted weapons with magic in a more practical way. Skyrim has the dual cast benefit, which is absent here, but I think I prefer Oblivion way. 

Oblivion has a spell efficiency mechanic that benefits no armor use. My mage wears common clothes, lol. What I did to deal with the no protection problem was using shield spells and later enchanting my clothes with  stacking shield spells as well. You can be a truly overpowered beast playing as pure mage in Oblivion and it’s so much fun since you’ll use magic for everything, all the time.

[h1]7)Sword and shield play:[/h1]
Later I did a play with a second character using a traditional sword and shield approach, but trying a custom class that included alchemy and restoration spells. The heavy armor makes the combat slower and you need to study the timing on investing attacks and raising the shields way more. It takes more attention and makes the game way harder. I think the sword fighting of Oblivion and Skyrim are still very good for a first person melee combat. It holds up pretty well and it is a different game than playing with a pure mage. 

[h1]8)The dialogs are better than I was expecting:[/h1]
There is tons of Oblivion memes on the internet regarding the fun dialog and AI. Bethesda tried what they’ve called ‘radiant AI’ for the time and it was a bit of marketing and a bit of a flaw because of not reaching the level of promising and ambitious it was intended. However, Oblivion is not a dumb game. It’s the opposite actually, since quests and story lines tend to have better explanations than what they did in Skyrim, for example. In Skyrim characters tend to be more direct to the point and this is a bit rough sometimes in my opinion. Oblivion has pretty decent lines and explanations and can be really engaging even on some small quests. That was something I wasn’t expecting so it was a nice surprise.    

[h1]Conclusion:[/h1]
Oblivion is still a pretty decent game that can be surprisingly good even on vanilla. Gameplay is up to date, visuals can be surprisingly beautiful sometimes, the text is decent, and exploration is rewarding. Highly recommended for anyone, because I’ve never felt as I was playing an old game, for real.

Very bad graphics, exploitable glitches and the levelling system is broken. Every time you level all enemies get stronger, while you improve your skills and attributes, but if you do this poorly you will be much weaker than your enemies. As a result at higher levels it becomes a button mashing (attack) game unless you utilise all aspects of the games mechanics (alchemy, magic, enchanting/enchanted gear and skills). However, the main story and faction quests (especially shivering isles, dark brotherhood and thieves guild) are great fun that enthrals the player into the world and lore. Its old and flawed but worth the fun if discounted.

I love this game so much. I've but hundreds of hours into it on my old XBox 360, and it was my first introduction to the Elder Scrolls series. So, I'm going to try and break this down, while trying to stay unbiased:

Positive: The province of Cyrodiil is really big, with dozens and dozens of locations to explore! The stories are imaginative and expansive, and the quests are some of the best and most creative ones I've ever played! (but not ALL of them). Speaking of quests, there are so many cool side quests, that they can be a really fun distraction from the main story for a while! The setting feels authentic, and this game has a knack for immersing you in the world! 

Negative: This game's graphics haven't aged well. Some of the shaders are pretty, but... the NPCs are a little bit nightmarish... This game also has a lot of bugs, so you have to be patient with it. The combat is fun, but can be a bit lackluster and boring after a while.

Additional Stuff: The main story of this game is really good, and the Oblivion Gate stuff is fun too! (Although, they can sometimes be annoying). The epic conclusion (which I won't spoil) made my jaw drop when I first saw it. (Granted, I was 12). I can't stress enough how cool some of the quests are. Here's an example: 

A local painter has gone missing. You go to his house and ask his wife if you can see his workshop. When you enter his studio, you see an unfinished painting, and an open window. When you approach the painting, you get sucked into it! Once inside, you find the painter. He explains that his grandfather was a terrible painter, who got a magic paintbrush from one of the gods after she took pity on him. With the paintbrush, you can enter the painting and paint the environment perfectly, and that's why the look so life-like. When his grandfather died, it was passed down to him. One day, an thief sneaked into his studio, hopped into the painting, and stole the brush. He also painted a bunch of trolls so he couldn't be followed. But the thief was killed by the trolls on the other side of the painting. You have to kill the trolls and get the brush, so you and the painter can get out.

Whenever I try and think of my favorite quest in Oblivion, this is what always comes to mind. It's just such a creative idea!
Anyways, sorry for the long review, I just want to be thorough. I will always love this game, and recommend this game 100%. 8.75/10

The fact that Todd Howard made this after he joined the chess club really says a lot about society. The Elder Scrolls: Chess Club is a one of a kind creation from the maestro himself, Todd Howard. You can feel that you're in a chess club environment in this game than any other chess club games, not even Skyrim doesn't have this much chess club experience. The first 3 hours of the game really digs you in to the whole chess club theme and it doesn't stop there, it won't ever stop chess clubbing. The whole entire game is a chess club itself. I feel like a chess club. Everyone is a chess club. I EAT, DRINK, POOP AND PISS CHESS CLUB. I LOVE CHESS CLUB. 


I WOULD RATE THIS GAME A CHESS OUT OF CLUB. TRULY A CHESS CLUB GAME.
Best

I played probably 1000 hours of Skyrim between PC and console (a lightweight compared to many, I know), and despite 3 or so attempts, I could never seem to get myself to play beyond the opening sequence of Oblivion due to the potato faces and general clunkiness. Well, with the help of a few mods, I have finally dove into a proper playthrough of Oblivion, and I have to say that I am very. very glad that I finally took the leap and put in some effort with this game. The world is very charming, and I am beginning to seriously consider the idea that it might actually be the better game compared to Skyrim. The faction system has been more intriguing, the story has me gripped much more than Skyrim's main quest, and the character progression is very deep and rewarding. I am still in what feels like the early stages of the playthrough 40+ hours in, and I am feeling like I just might have to see the main quest through to completion (something I never did with Skyrim somehow after all this time). Very fun, albeit dated and clunky game. Highly recommended for anyone considering looking back on older Bethesda titles after enjoying some of the newer stuff. I might have to keep going backwards and finally try Morrowind after this.
